choices.text: Cataract surgery rate is defined as total number of cataract surgeries performed per million population
A target cataract surgery rate of 3000 per million
Cataract surgery rate is a true rate
It is an indicator of success of blindness control

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about cataract surgery rate.
questions.solution:
Cataract surgery rate is not a true rate because it measures number of surgeries performed per million population per year and not  the incidence.
Time component and follow up is necessary to calculate rate.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 63.

choices.text: Cases are spread over 5 or more cities
At least one or more laboratory confirmed H1N1 case

questions.text: At what point is a pandemic of H1N1 suspected?
questions.solution:
An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people refers to pandemic.
Only some pandemics cause severe disease in some individuals or at a population level.
Characteristics of an infectious agent influencing the causation of a pandemic include : the agent must be able to infect humans, to cause disease in humans and to spread easily from human to human .
Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

Among the given options, the best option is option 2.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 108.

choices.text: Closure of school will not lead to reduction in contact between children.
Children are the most common affected population by swine flu.
Increased rates of transmission due to more opportunities for contact.

questions.text: A swine flu outbreak calls for the closure of schools. Which of the options is not a valid reason for this?
questions.solution:
Closing of school during an outbreak of swine flu leads to a reduction in contact between affected and unaffected children and hence, helps in controlling incidence.
Hence, the first option is wrong.
All other options are correct.
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 138.

choices.text: Seen only in wild birds and not in domestic poultry
It causes serious illness leading to death of the patient

questions.text: Up to this point, there hasn't been an epidemic of H5N1 avian flu. What is the primary justification behind this?
questions.solution:
Pandemic : An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people.
  • Only some pandemics cause severe disease in some individuals or at a population level.
  • Characteristics of an infectious agent influencing the causation of a pandemic include : the agent must be able to infect humans, to cause disease in humans and to spread easily from human to human .
  • Examples are influenza pandemics and cholera pandemics.

Due to ineffective human-to-human transmission, H5N1 Avian flu has not turned into an epidemic till now.
Poor human-to-human transmission does not let H5N1 spread fast and rapidly to turn into an epidemic/pandemic.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: To determine the connection between smoking and lung cancer, a study was conducted. The connection was found to be stronger in those who exercised less and weaker in those who exercised more. Exercise, in this case, happens to be a:
questions.solution:
Definitions of terms in options.
  • Bias : An intentional/unintentional but systematic mistake/error in the design, recruiting, data collecting, or analysis that causes a false estimate of the true impact of exposure on the outcome.
  • Confounder: The distortion of the association between health outcome and exposure by an external, third variable called a confounder.
  • Effect Modifier: Effect modifier is a variable that differentially (positively and negatively) modifies the observed effect of a risk factor on disease status.
Its distinct from confounding; it occurs when the magnitude of the effect of the primary exposure on an outcome (i.e., the association) differs depending on the level of a third variable.

In the above question- its clear - the primary exposure is smoking and outcome is lung cancer and exercise is effect modifier causing difference in magnitude of observed effect. (incidence of lung cancer)
Hence, option (3) is the correct answer.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 80, 81.

questions.text: The Chandler Index is a crucial epidemiological tool. What is the least likely application for it?
questions.solution:
Chandler’s index is the average number of eggs of hookworm per gram of stools.

Applications
  • Chandler's index is used in epidemiological studies of hookworm disease.
  • By this index, worm loads in different population groups can be compared, and also the degree of reduction of egg output after mass treatment.
  • The impact of control program can also be assessed by the index.
There is no clinical significance of the Chandler Index with respect to individual case severity or prognosis.
Hence the option (1) is the answer.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 286.

questions.text: In which cancer is screening ineffective
questions.solution:
Screening is not useful in testicular tumors because it has delayed presentation.
 
Screening methods
Cervical Cancer
• Pap smear
• Liquid based cytology
• HVP DNA testing
• Visual screening		 Colorectal cancer
• Faecal occult blood tests (FOBT)
• Sigmoidoscopy
• Colonoscopy
Breast cancer
• Mammography
• Clinical breast examination		 Oral cancer
• Visual inspection



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 153.

questions.text: A researcher wishes to conduct a study of lipid levels in the blood of smokers and non-smokers. However, he is now concerned that smokers may differ from non-smokers in their diet, activity, and so on. This is referred to as:
questions.solution:
The researcher is concerned that the smokers in the query may have different dietary, exercise, and other habits from non-smokers. Selection bias is the name for this issue.
  • Bias is any systematic error in the determination of the association between the exposure and disease. The relative risk estimate may increase or decrease as a result of the bias; it reflects some type of non-comparability between the study and control groups. The possibility of bias must be considered when evaluating a possible cause and effect relationship.
  • Many varieties of bias may arise in epidemiological studies.
  • Some of these are :
(a) Bias due to confounding : Mention has already been made about confounding as an important source of bias. This bias can be removed by matching in case control studies.
(b) Memory or recall bias : When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.
(c) Selection bias : The cases and controls may not be representative of cases and controls in the general population. There may be systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. The selection bias can be best controlled by its prevention
(d) Berkesonian bias : A special example of bias is Berkesonian bias, termed after Dr. Joseph Berkeson who recognized this problem. The bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases (i.e., hospital cases and controls). 
(e) Interviewer’s bias : Bias may also occur when the interviewer knows the cases from the controls. This prior information may lead him to question the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding a positive history of the suspected causal factor. A useful check on this kind of bias can be made by providing equal time to interview both the case and control or by giving a self administered questionnaire to the cases and control. This type of bias can be eliminated by double-blinding .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 82.

questions.text: When compared to prior years, the number of non-communicable disease cases has gradually increased. What do you name this trend?
questions.solution:
The term 'secular trend ' implies changes in the occurrence of disease over a long period of time, generally several years
or decades. There may be progressive increase or decrease in the occurrence of disease.
Examples includes
  • coronary heart disease,
  • lung cancer and
  • diabetes
which have shown a consistent upward trend in the developed countries during the past 50 years or so, followed by a decline of such diseases as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria and polio.

Epidemiologists have identified three kinds of time trends or fluctuations in disease occurrence.

1. Short-term fluctuations. Eg epidemics
Il. Periodic fluctuations. Eg seasonal outbreaks
Ill. Long-term or secular trends

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: What does sensitivity measure?
questions.solution:
Sensitivity is defined as the ability of a test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is “true-positive” out of the total diseased(true-positive +false negative).
A 90 per cent sensitivity means that 90 per cent of the diseased people screened by the test will give a “true-positive” result and the remaining 10 per cent a “false-negative” result.
 
Diseased (TD) Healthy (TH)
Test Positive True positive (Tp) False Positive (Fp) PPV\(=\frac{\text{(TP)}}{\text{(TP)+(FP)}}\)
Test Negative False Negative (FN) True negative (TN) NPV\(=\frac{\text{(TN)}}{\text{(FN)+(TN)}}\)
Sensitivity\(=\frac{\text{(TP)}}{\text{(TP)+(FN)}}\) Specificity\(=\frac{\text{(TN)}}{\text{(FP)+(TN)}}\)


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155.

questions.text: To identify a disease state, a new test(Test B) is shown in red line. Both healthy and ill populations are subjected to the test. Which is shown in the graph below. Which of the following statements about the test is accurate?
questions.solution:
Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Both sensitivity and specificity are lower in the test represented in red (Test B) compared to the test represented in black(Test A). 

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present. 
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 —false-negative rate. 

Specificity is the proportion of all people without the disease who test negative. It is the probability of the test being negative when the disease is absent. 
Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 —false-positive rate. 

Test B has an increased number of true positives and true negatives as well as increased number of false positives and negatives, compared to Test A. 
Hence, leading to decreased sensitivity and specificity. 



Hence, the 3rd  option is correct.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 155, 156, 157.

choices.text: Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases
Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same

questions.text: For metastatic melanoma, a radiotherapist recommends a novel medication combination combining immunotherapy and chemotherapy. It increases survival time. Which of the following statements is accurate in this case?
questions.solution:
Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease that occur in a specific population over a certain period of time. The novel treatment does not prevent new cases of melanoma, so the incidence remains the same.

Prevalence refers to the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time. Since the new treatment increases survival time, patients live longer with the disease. As a result, the prevalence of metastatic melanoma increases because more people are living with the condition over time.

Relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as :

P=IxD = incidence x mean duration

Example (for a stable condition)
Incidence = 10 cases per 1000 population per year
Mean duration of disease = 5 years
Prevalence = 10 x 5 = 50 per 1000 population

This concept is important in understanding how advances in treatment can affect population health statistics.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: A study was conducted by a team of obstetricians and psychiatrists to compare postpartum depression in mothers of male and female babies using the Edinburgh depression scale (EPDS). Which test should be used to compare the results?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (3): Chi square test

CHI-SQUARE
  • The most important nonparametric test is the chi-square (ÓÅ∏2) test, which is used for testing hypotheses about nominal scale data.
  • Chi-square is basically a test of proportions, telling us whether the proportions of observations falling in different categories differ significantly from those that would be expected by chance.
Here, in the question ,there is comparison of postpartum depression (qualitative data) between 2 independent groups. The severity of PPD using the scale is measured. Hence, Chi square test is the answer for this question.




Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 32.

questions.text: Which of these studies is the best for evaluating exposure and outcome?
questions.solution:
Cohort study is best to evaluate exposure and outcome, especially for rare exposures.
In cohort study, cases and control groups are compared after following over a period of time. However, (randomized) clinical trial may be best to study treatment intervention and outcome after randomized groups are formed with control/intervention arms.
 
  • A cohort study is a type of research study design in which one or more samples, referred to as cohorts, are studied over time with the goal of determining which initial participant exposure characteristics (risk factors) are linked to certain diseases or outcomes.
  • Results from individuals in each cohort are measured throughout the study, and connections with particular traits are identified.
  • It proceeds from 'cause to effect'.
Note : On the other hand, a case-control study begins with the disease, moving from "effect to cause."

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 83.

questions.text: A researcher randomly chose samples from a population and plotted their means on a line graph. This distribution is referred to as:
questions.solution:
The probability distribution of a particular statistic based on a random sample is known as a sampling distribution or finite-sample distribution in statistics.
Three different distribution types are:
  • A sample distribution is an observed distribution of the values that a variable is seen to have for a sample of individuals.
  • A population distribution is a theoretical representation of the range of values that a variable can assume within a population of people.
  • A sampling distribution is a theoretical distribution of the values that a given sample statistic assumes across all feasible samples of a particular size.
Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 15.

questions.text: What does a medication that doesn't treat an illness but instead lessens its symptoms and prolongs survival lead to?
questions.solution:
• Prevalence: Percentage of a population that has a condition at a certain period of time, and it depends on the average length of the disease as well as the rate at which new cases are developing.
  • The rate at which new illness cases are added to the population is measured by incidence (and becoming prevalent cases).
The average sickness duration is crucial since there are only three ways to quit being a prevalent case:
  • get well,
  • move out of the population, or
  • pass away.
Prevalence is equal to (Incidence Rate) x (Average Duration of Disease)

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about randomization in clinical trials?
questions.solution:
The validity of generalized (causal) inferences in scientific investigation is known as external validity,and it is typically based on experiments and is known as experimental validity.
In other words, it refers to how broadly generalizable a study's findings are to different contexts and populations. The randomization process cannot guarantee this.
The external validity in a randomised control trial can be increased by random sampling.
Randomization procedures provide the best opportunity for achieving these objectives -
  • Minimising bias.
  • Producing a balanced comparison.
  • Quantifying errors that can be attributed to chance.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 90.

questions.text: 40 to 50 instances are reported by a health clinic per week in the neighbourhood. There are typically 48 cases this week. This kind of event is known as:
questions.solution:
A healthy center reports 40 to 50 cases in a week in the community. This week there are 48 cases normally. This kind of occurrence is called endemic, as there is constant presence of a disease in the defined geographical area.
 
  • Endemic refers to the constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area or population group, without importation from outside; may also refer to the “usual” or expected frequency of the disease within such an area or population group, that is, more than 2 Standard Deviations. 
  • The word sporadic means scattered about. The cases occur irregularly, haphazardly from time to time, and generally infrequently (100).
  • Epidemic: The occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness, specific health related behaviour, or other health-related events clearly in excess of normal expectancy. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 101.

questions.text: Select the correct response when two screening tests are taken in series:
questions.solution:
• When 2 screening tests are done in series, there is increased specificity and decreased sensitivity. In contrast to doing either test alone, there is a net decrease in sensitivity when two sequential tests are utilised, but a net gain in specificity when those who test positive by the first test are brought in for the second test.
 
  • When two tests are run simultaneously, there is a net increase in sensitivity but a net decrease in specificity as compared to running either test separately. When 2 screening tests are done in parallel, there is decreased specificity and increased sensitivity

Reference: Medical Biostatistics, 3rd edition, Page no 56.

questions.text: In the past year, there were 4050 births in a certain demographic. 50 babies were born still. 50 babies passed away within the first week, compared to 150 in the remaining 28 days of the neonatal period. What is the rate of neonatal mortality?
questions.solution:
Total number of births in one year = 4050
Number of stillbirths in that year = 50
Hence, total number of live births in that year = 4000
Total number of infants dying in the first 7 days = 50
Total number of infants dying in the next 28 days = 150
 Hence, total number of infants dying in the first 28 days of birth = 200

NMR = under 28 day deaths/total number of live births in that year = 200*1000/4000
NMR = 50

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 644.

questions.text: Why hasn't leprosy been completely eradicated yet?
questions.solution:
• Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, has not been completely eradicated due to several factors, including:

  • No effective vaccine: While there are some vaccines that may provide partial protection, there is no universally effective vaccine for leprosy.
  • Highly Infectious but low pathogenicity: Leprosy is not highly infectious in the way some diseases are; it requires prolonged close contact for transmission.
  • Only humans are reservoir: This limits the options for controlling the disease, as humans are the sole host.
  • Long incubation period: The long incubation period (often several years) makes it difficult to identify and treat cases promptly, allowing transmission to continue.

  • The most significant reason contributing to the persistence of leprosy is likely the long incubation period, as it complicates control efforts and makes early detection challenging.

    So, the best answer would be 4. Long incubation period.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 362-378.

questions.text: Someone discovered a link between eating fatty foods and ailments brought on by obesity. He accomplished this by gathering information from hospitals and food producers, respectively. What is such a study called?
questions.solution:
An ecological study is an epidemiological study in which data is collected from individuals in certain populations, such as a country.

In this case, the investigator obtained an increased incidence of obesity related ailments  due to a diet high in fatty foods from the health authorities and food industry of the country.

This type of study is useful for determining associations between environmental factors like diet and disease and can help identify potential risk factors for a given condition.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: Which of the following can't be used to eliminate bias?
questions.solution:
Multivariate analysis is the study of two or more variables simultaneously in order to make conclusions about the relationships between them. It is performed after the study has been completed, with the goal of examining the collected data.

By contrast, activities such as matching, blinding, and randomization are typically done during the experimental process itself.

Many varieties of bias may arise in epidemiological studies.
Some of these are :
(a) Bias due to confounding : Mention has already been made about confounding as an important source of bias. This bias can be removed by matching in case control studies.
(b) Memory or recall bias : When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.
(c) Selection bias : The cases and controls may not be representative of cases and controls in the general population. There may be systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. The selection bias can be best controlled by its prevention
(d) Berkesonian bias : A special example of bias is Berkesonian bias, termed after Dr. Joseph Berkeson who recognized this problem. The bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases (i.e., hospital cases and controls).
(e) Interviewer’s bias : Bias may also occur when the interviewer knows the hypothesis and also knows who the cases are. This prior information may lead him to question the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding a positive history of the suspected causal factor. A useful check on this kind of bias can be made by noting the length of time taken to interview the average case and the average control. This type of bias can be eliminated by double-blinding .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 80, 81.

questions.text: According to a study, pure vegetarians had a lower incidence of colon cancer than non-vegetarians, and this led researchers to the conclusion that beta-carotene is protective against cancer. This may not be the case since vegetarian subjects may be eating a high-fiber diet that lowers their risk of developing cancer. This is an illustration of:
questions.solution:
A confounding factor is at play in the given study as the presence of high fiber content in vegetarian food is protective against carcinoma colon, which could interfere with the observed protective effect of beta-carotene present in vegetarian food. Therefore, this serves as an example of confounding factor.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 79.

choices.text: To differentiate co-primary cases from secondary cases
To prevent infection to the contacts of the infected person

questions.text: Application of Incubation period is all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
The duration of isolation is determined by the length of time that a person is able to transmit the disease to another person. This is known as the communicability of the disease. Additionally, the effectiveness of the chemotherapy prescribed to treat the disease can have an impact on the transmission of the infection. Thus, the duration of isolation will depend on both the duration of communicability of the disease and the effect that the chemotherapy has on its infectivity.

Incubation period is of fundamental importance in epidemiological studies :

(a) Tracing the source of infection and contacts : In the case of a disease with a short incubation period ranging from a few hours to a few days, it is relatively simple to trace the source of infection-and “follow the trail” of the spread of infection as in the case of food poisoning, bacillary dysentery or typhoid fever. The position is quite different with diseases whose incubation period is of medium length (10 days to 3 weeks) or longer. So many things will have happened and such varied contacts taken place that the cause-effect relationship becomes “diluted”. We will have a whole gamut of possible causes from among which we have to single out the main cause. Once the source of infection is traced, then only it will be possible to institute appropriate control measures.

(b) Period of surveillance : Incubation period is useful in determining the period of surveillance (or quarantine) which may be advised . This period is usually equal to the maximum incubation period of the disease.

(c) Immunization : Prophylactically, a knowledge of incubation period helps us to prevent clinical illness by administering human immunoglobulins and antisera during the incubation period of the disease.

(d) Identification of point source or propagated epidemics : In a point source epidemic, all the cases occur within one incubation period of the disease; in a propagated epidemic, cases occur later than the known length of the incubation period.

(e) Prognosis : Incubation period can also be used in estimating the prognosis of a disease. In some diseases (e.g., tetanus, rabies), the shorter the incubation period, the worse the prognosis of the disease. Thus prognosis is related to the incubation period of the disease .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 107, 108.

questions.text:
15225 hypertensive individuals were randomly assigned to the intervention group (new medicine) and the control group (old drug) in a clinical trial.
The table below lists the research study's findings. Determine the relative risk (RR) and absolute risk reduction (ARR)?
 
Control group
(old group)		 Intervention
group (new drug)
Developed HT complication 1800 1620
Did not develop HT complications 13425 13605
Total subjects 15225 15225
questions.solution:
In the given situation, absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 1% and relative risk (RR) is 0.9.

Calculation:

• IC = Incidence of events (hypertensive complications) in the control group = 1800/15225 =0.118 =11.8%

• TI = Incidence of events (hypertensive complications) in the treatment group = 1620/15225 = 0.106 =10.6 %

• Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is also known as risk difference.

• ARR = IC-IT =11.8-10.6 = 1.2%

Relative risk (RR) = IT/IC = 0.106/0.118 = 0.9

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 86.

choices.text: If it is a rare disease, this can be considered positive
Highly likely that patient has the disease
Highly unlikely that patient has the disease
If the prevalence is high, then the patient has the disease

questions.text: A patient is subjected to an extremely sensitive test by a doctor, and the outcome is positive. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
• A sensitive test, if it is positive confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common. 
  • Sensitivity of a screening test is its ability to identify correctly those who have disease.
  • It is the ability of a test to detect true positives out of the entire diseased population ( true positive + false negative ).
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 152.

questions.text:
In a statistical analysis to determine how a medicine might affect a patient's blood sugar level, the test indicated a significant difference even though there wasn't one.
What are the most likely causes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the likely null hypothesis will be that both the drugs are essentially same. This is also true in reality. 

The alternate hypothesis will be that these 2 drugs have significant difference between them. 

The above question states that there is significant difference between these 2 drugs ( p < 0.05 ), so the null hypothesis is rejected. But we are aware of the fact that in reality the null hypothesis is correct.  This is a type 1 or alpha error. 

Definition- When an alterative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and null hypothesis is true, it constitutes a type 1 or alpha error.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 24, 25.

questions.text: A infant of 18 months was brought to the clinic who had not yet been immunised. Which of the following vaccines may be administered?
questions.solution:
A baby who is 18 months old who has never been inoculated and is being brought to the clinic for the first time can receive the  OPV and DPT booster.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: To determine the average blood pressure in each town, a study was conducted in three states. Each home in the three villages was visited by the health workers who were assigned to the area. Each community's average blood pressure was determined and compared. What kind of research methodology is this an example of?
questions.solution:
The study given in the question is Cross sectional study.

Cross Sectional Study :
  • An observational study method which examines cross-sectional data, which is information gathered from a population or a representative subset at a particular point in time.
  • Cross-sectional studies are more useful for chronic than short-lived diseases.
  • For example, in a study of hypertension, we can also collect data during the survey about age, sex, physical exercise, body weight, salt intake and other variables of interest. Then we can determine how prevention of hypertension is related to certain variables simultaneously measured.
  • Such a study tells us about the distribution of a disease in population rather than its etiology.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 84.

choices.text: There is no association present between the factor and the disease
There is positive association between the factor and the disease
There is negative association between the factor and the disease

questions.text: The risk ratio in a cohort study to investigate the relationship between a factor and disease was determined to be 1. What does this demonstrate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: There is no association present between the factor and the disease

The risk ratio or relative risk is the probability of disease in an exposed group to the probability in an unexposed group.
RR = incidence in exposed/incidence in non-exposed

The interpretation of RR is done as follows:



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: The prospectively evaluated, double-blinded, randomized clinical trial represents the 'gold-standard' for providing evidence for therapeutic decision marking. This was first proposed by the father of evidence based medicine:
questions.solution:
Father of evidence based medicine is David Lawrence Sackett.

David Lawrence Sackett OC FRSC (November 17, 1934 – May 13, 2015) was an American-Canadian physician and a pioneer in evidence-based medicine. He is known as one of the fathers of Evidence-Based Medicine. He founded the first department of clinical epidemiology in Canada at McMaster University, and the Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine. He is well known for his textbooks Clinical Epidemiology and Evidence-Based Medicine.

Online reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Sackett

questions.text: Positive predictive value is a function of sensitivity, specificity, and
questions.solution:
• PPV =Sensitivity x Prevalence/[ Sensitivity × Prevalence + 1( - Specificity) × (I - Prevalence)],
    thus PPV, is a function of sensitivity, specificity and prevalence.
 
  • While the sensitivity and specificity of a test depend only on the characteristics of the test itself, predictive values vary according to the prevalence (or underlying probability) of the disease. Thus, predictive values cannot be determined without knowing the prevalence of the disease—they are not qualities of the test per se, but are a function of the test’s characteristics and of the setting in which it is being used.
  • The higher the prevalence of a disease in the population, the higher the PPV and the lower the NPV of a test for it.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 76.

questions.text: Which of the following does not include the infant mortality rate?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate is defined as the number of deaths of children under 1 year of age per 1000 live births within a given period.

As, stillbirth includes death of unborn fetus, it does not form part of infant mortality rate.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text: The hair of a girl is white. In addition to her, 40% of her classmates experience this issue. The other villagers in the same region don't have any residents with white hair. Her sibling, who is staying with an aunt in a village nearby, is also normal and does not have white hair. Which statement best describes why her hair is likely to be white?
questions.solution:
Given scenario is :
The girl and 40% of her classmates have white hair. Her sibling living in the nearby village is normal and has no white hair.

In the given question, the girl and many of her classmates from a single geographical area, in this case, the school) have developed grey hair, answer can be environmental as the girl's brother living in a different village does not have white hair, the cause of the white hair is unlikely to be genetic. Similarly, as many other children from the same school have white hair, the cause is also unlikely to be nutritional.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: By 2010, what will the worldwide under-five mortality rate be?
questions.solution:
Under 5 mortality rate in the world by 2010 was 6 million.

Despite population growth in developing regions, the number of deaths of children under 5 has declined from 12.7 million in 1990 to almost 6 million in 2015 globally.

The number of children under 5 years old who die each year fell by a third between 1990 and 2010, from more than 12 million deaths to 7.6 million, new data from Unicef, the World Health Organization, and other agencies show.

Overall about 12 000 fewer children died every day in 2010 than in 1990, the baseline year for measuring progress, the agencies said in their report.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 522.
                  BMJ 2011; 343 doi: https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d6013 (Published 21 September 2011)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design to assess in quick time the strength of the association between smoking and lung cancer?
questions.solution:
The quickest way to establish a cause-and-effect link is through case control. Clinical trials and cohort studies are more precise, but they also take much longer and cost more money.

Case control studies, often called “retrospective studies” are a common first approach to test causal hypothesis. In recent years, the case control approach has emerged as a permanent method of epidemiological investigation.
The case control method has three distinct features :

a. both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study

b. the study proceeds backwards from effect to cause; and

c. it uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an inference.

By definition, a case control study involves two populations — cases and controls. In case control studies, the unit is the individual rather than the group. The focus is on a disease or some other health problem that has already developed.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: Which of the following is utilised to choose patients based on potential variables that will influence the outcomes?
questions.solution:
• Stratified random sampling involves dividing the population into subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics or variables that are expected to influence the outcomes (e.g., age, gender, socioeconomic status). Then, random samples are taken from each stratum. This method ensures that each subgroup is appropriately represented in the final sample, which helps in making more accurate inferences about the entire population.
 
  • Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting every nth individual from a list after a random starting point. It does not specifically consider the influence of variables on outcomes.
 
  • Simple random sampling: In this method, every individual in the population has an equal chance of being selected. It does not account for any specific variables that might affect outcomes.
 
  • Cluster sampling: This involves dividing the population into clusters (usually based on geography or other natural groupings), then randomly selecting some clusters and including all individuals within those clusters in the sample. It is used mainly for practical reasons when a population is spread out, but it does not specifically address variables influencing outcomes.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

choices.text: Incidence decreases when a program is effective
Vaccination strategies decrease the incidence of a disease
Newer and more effective treatment modalities decrease the incidence
Incidence implies the number of new cases detected over a fixed time

questions.text: Pick the statement that is untrue about 'incidence'.
questions.solution:
Newer and more effective treatment modalities do not decrease the incidence. Incidence is a measure of the probability of occurrence of a given medical condition in a population within a specified period of time. Effective treatment modalities can decrease the prevalence of a disease, not the incidence of that disease.

Incidence rate is defined as “the number of NEW cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time”. 

This suggests even if newer and more effective modalities occur, new cases are bound to occur.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: If blind school surveys were used to estimate the prevalence of blindness instead of population-based surveys, the results would show:
questions.solution:
Studies that are based on a population are more beneficial than school screenings since they take into account "school-aged children" and not just those who are attending school.
An evaluation of the prevalence of blindness based solely on surveys conducted in blind schools would result in an underestimation of the total number of blind individuals in a population, which includes those who are in blind schools.

Online reference: Gibbons et al. BMC Public Health 2014, 14:147 http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2458/14/147.

questions.text: What is movement across socioeconomic levels called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Social Mobility

Social mobility is the change in a person’s socioeconomic status either in comparison to their parents i.e. Inter-generational mobility or in their own lifetime i.e. Intra-generational mobility. It can occur in any direction, upgradation or downgradation.

Social mobility

Indian society is rigidly based on caste system. There is little social mobility, i.e., people do not change their caste or religion. In other words, Indian society is a “closed-class” system. There are societies known as the “open class societies” where movement of the social ladder is unrestricted, on the basis of achievement or gaining wealth. Open class societies are therefore more progressive where people according to their ability can go up the social ladder. In closed-class systems, it is difficult to make reforms without meeting resistance of the people.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 744.

questions.text: The incidence of each of the following varies between rural and urban areas, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
This a factual question.

Recurrent TB prevalence was generally high in both urban and rural settings. The risk of mortality and lost to follow-up was higher among rural patients. We recommend a well-organized Directly Observed Therapy strategy adapted to setting where heightened TB control activities are focused on areas with poor treatment outcomes.

Chronic bronchitis is more common in rural areas and Lung cancer and Tuberculosis is more common in urban areas. 

Online Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6938018/

questions.text: A neighbourhood has 1,65,000 people living there on June 1st, according to records ,22 new cases of tuberculosis were reported overall between January 1 and June 31, 2017. There were 220 TB cases that were officially reported in the community. What is the number of TB cases per 10 lakh people in this community?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  133
The question is asking about incidence of TB in the community .
Number of new cases in a neighbourhood of 1.65 lakh = 22
Number of new cases in community of 10 lakh = 10 x 22/1.65 = 133

questions.text:
A disease has a 4 per 1000 population incidence rate and a 2-year duration.
Determine the prevalence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 8/1000

Prevalence is the proportion of cases, all old and new at a given point or for a period of time within a defined population.

Prevalence depends on incidence and duration.
The formula is:
Prevalence = Incidence x Mean duration
P = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 Ans.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.

questions.text: What procedure is used for disposing of cytotoxic and outdated medications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Incineration at temperature >1200 0 C
  •  Burning or incineration is an excellent method of disinfection.
  • Inexpensive articles such as contaminated dressings, rags and swabs can be disposed off by burning.
  • Addition of sawdust, paper, kerosene or other combustible material aid in burning.
  • Faeces can be disposed off by burning.
  • Burning should not be done in open air; it is best done in an incinerator.
 Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: The study unit for ecological research is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Population

The unit of ecological study designs is population.
Ecological study includes correlation between variables. A third party source of information is taken. E.g. Alcohol consumption in a state is estimated from alcohol tax data.

Epidemiological studies can be classified as observational studies and experimental studies with further subdivisions 

1. Observational studies

a. Descriptive studies   
b. Analytical studies
(i) Ecological or Correlational, with populations as unit of study
(ii) Cross-sectional or Prevalence, with individuals as unit of study
(iii) Case-control or + Case-reference,  with individuals as unit of study
{iv) Cohort or Follow-up, with individuals as unit of study

2. Experimental studies or Intervention studies

a. Randomized or  Clinical trials with patients as controlled trials trials unit of study
b, Field trials with healthy people as unit of study
c. Community trials or Community intervention trial with communities as unit of study.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: The definition of risk among exposed by risk among non exposed is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Relative risk

 
  • Relative risk or risk ratio is the incidence of disease among exposed to incidence among non-exposed.
  • It is calculated with the help of cohort study.
  • RR = I (exposed) / I (non-exposed)
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: Ideally, two live vaccinations should be spaced out by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 4 weeks
  • Ideally, two different live vaccines should be given 4 weeks apart.
  • This prevents interference of the first vaccine with the second one.
NOTE:
  1. Two doses of the same vaccine are also the most effective if given in a 4 week apart duration.
  2. It ensures optimal immune response.
  3. Decreasing the interval between doses in a multiple-dose vaccine series may interfere with antibody response and protection.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text:
Susceptible person developed disease within range of IP after coming in
contact with primary case -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Secondary attack rate

Secondary attack rate is defined as the number of secondary cases which arise within one incubation period of the first case among susceptible people/close contacts.

SAR = Total no. of secondary cases in an area /          * 100
           (Total susceptible population – primary case)

The denominator consists of all persons who are exposed to the case. More specifically, the denominator may be restricted only to “susceptible” contacts, if means are available to distinguish the susceptible persons from the immune .
The primary case is excluded from both the numerator and denominator.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 108.

choices.text: Early Neonates with birth weight more than 1000 g

questions.text: The perinatal mortality rate is governed by which of the following numerator
questions.solution:
PERINATAL MORTALITY RATE= Late Fetal Death (28 weeks gestation or more) + Early Neonatal Death (Within 7 days of life)  /(Live birth + Late Fetal Death)*1000




Perinatal mortality rate is defined as the ratio of late fetal and early neonatal deaths with birth weights greater than 1000 grams to every 1000 live births with birth weight greater than 1000 grams.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 618.

questions.text: The best indicator of the difference in incidence between the exposed and non-exposed groups is:
questions.solution:
Attributable risk ratio = (Incidence in exposed group - Incidence in unexposed group) / Incidence in exposed group 
OR
Attributable risk = Risk ratio - 1

 
  • Attributable risk (AR) is a measure of how much of an effect a particular risk factor might have on a particular health problem.
  • It is calculated by subtracting the incidence of the health problem among non-exposed individuals from the incidence of the health problem among exposed individuals.
  • AR is useful for determining the relative importance of a particular risk factor, as it compares the risk associated with the exposure to the base-level risk seen in the general population.
  • AR provides insight into the extent to which the health problem is due to the exposure and can help health professionals target intervention strategies more effectively.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text: A researcher aims to demonstrate the link between smoking and COPD. He gathered medical information from a government hospital and sales data on cigarettes from the finance and taxation division. This serves as an illustration of which study design ?
questions.solution:
In epidemiology, ecological studies are used to understand the relationship between outcome and exposure at a population level, where 'population' represents a group of individuals with a shared characteristic such as geography, ethnicity, socio-economic status of employment.
  • What differentiates ecological studies from other studies is that the unit analysis being studied is the group, therefore inferences cannot be made about individual study participants.
  • On the other hand, details of outcome and exposure can be generalized to the population being studied.
  • Examples of such studies include investigating associations between units of grouped data, such as electoral wards, regions, or even whole countries.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: A research was conducted to evaluate the level of undernutrition in young children. 100 kids each from urban and rural areas were chosen. Of them, 20 urban and 30 rural individuals  were determined to be undernourished. Which of the above statistical tests is used to the date sets comparison?
questions.solution:
Chi square is used to compare two data sets to determine the likelihood of their observed differences being the result of random chance.

  • It is used to evaluate the statistical significance of differences between observed and expected values within a set of data.
  • It compares the differences between groups in data to make sure the differences are statistically significant.
  • Chi square is used for testing the association between two categorical variables.
  • It measures the goodness-of-fit of an observed data set to a theoretical one.
  • Chi square tests can be used to determine if there is a significant difference between an expected distribution and an observed one.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 34.

questions.text: The most effective quantitative approach for analysing previous research studies is:
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is the best quantitative method to study previous research studies.

questions.text: A medicine does not cure an illness; it only lowers the death rate. Which of the following is true in this situation?
questions.solution:
Prevalence of a disease refers to the total number of cases of that disease in a community at a particular point of time.
Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases of that disease that arise in a community for a specified period of time.

According to question, the new drug helps reduce mortality of a disease but doesn’t cure the disease. So the total no. of cases in the community will keep rising as survival of diseased people is increased. There is no change in incidence of the disease as nothing is done to prevent the occurrence/increase the occurrence of the disease.

Therefore, the prevalence of the disease increases while the incidence remains the same.

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent steps is not included in the case-control study?
questions.solution:
Follow up is a part of cohort study not case control study. Also known as retrospective study.

It has 3 distinct features—

1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of study. 

2. Study proceeds backwards from effect to cause. 

3. Uses a control or comparison group to support or refuse an inference.

Steps—

1. Selection of cases and controls.

2. Matching

3. Measurement of exposure

4. Analysis ( Odd’s ratio is calculated)

questions.text: Which method is best for determining how strongly exposure and outcome are associated?
questions.solution:
The best suited study to asssess the strength of association between exposure and outcome is cohort study.

  • Also known as prospective study or incidence study.
  • Proceeds from cause to effect.
  • Cohorts are identified prior to the appearance of the disease under investigation.
  • The study groups so defined are observed over a period of time to determine the frequency of disease among them. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: All the following steps apply to meta-analysis, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• Meta - analysis is a method of statistical analysis that pools summary data (Eg : means, relative risk, etc) from multiple studies for a more precise estimate of the size of an effect.
  • It also estimates the heterogenecity of effect sizes between studies.
  • 4 steps of meta- analysis—

       1. Identification

        2. Selection

        3. Abstraction

        4. Analysis.

Randomisation is not a step in meta - analysis.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 90.

questions.text: What does the external validity of a test imply?
questions.solution:
• External validity is the validity of applying the conclusions of a scientific study outside the context of that study. It represents the extent to which the results of a study can be generalised to and across other situations, people and times.
  • Internal validity is the validity of conclusions drawn within the context of a particular study.
NOTE:
  • Internal validity: are the results of the study valid for the sample of patients who were actually studied. Internal validity is increased by randomisation.
  • External validity: are the results of the study valid for the population from which the sample in the study was drawn. If the external validity of a study is such that it applies to other populations as well, it is said to be generalizable. External validity is increased by random sampling.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 68.

NATURAL HISTORY OF DISEASE

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the relationship between prevalence and sensitivity, specificity, and PPV?
questions.solution:
1. A screening test's positive predictive value (PPV) is dependent on its sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence of disease in a population.

Sensitivity- the ability of a test to correctly identify true positives.

Specificity- the ability of a test to correctly identify true negatives.
 

 

The “predictive value of a positive test” indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease in question. The more prevalent a disease is in a given population, the more accurate will be the predictive value of a positive screening test.

questions.text: Which epidemiology study provides the most reliable results when comparing two drugs in clinical trials?

Evidence pyramid in research-

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Evidence Based Medicine (EBM)?

The principle of evidence-based medicine (EBM) is that actual evidence, rather than opinion, must be the primary scientific basis for making clinical decisions; different types of evidence are judged to be of different value.

Systematic reviews and Meta-analysis are components of EBM.

questions.text: An association between the sale of anti-asthmatic drugs and a rise in mortality from anti-asthmatic side effects was discovered in a UK study. This kind of research is an illustration of:

questions.text: If a disease has a very low prevalence when compared to its incidence, it suggests:
questions.solution:
If the prevalence is very low as compared to the incidence of disease it implies disease is very fatal or it is easily curable.

Because,
Prevalence=incidence × duration
If the prevalence is very low then either incidence is low or duration is short and duration is short if the disease is easily curable or very fatal.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: For Randomized Control Trial (RCT) to assess dating in adolescents, a study was done by selecting random schools, random classes, then random sections and then random students. This is an example of:

Multistage sampling is the taking of samples in stages using smaller and smaller sampling units at each stage.

questions.text: The pattern of change of disease trends of mortality and morbidity where the pandemics infection are replaced by degenerative and man-made disorders as the main cause of morbidity and the most frequent cause of fatality is known as:
questions.solution:
The pattern of change of disease trends of mortality and morbidity where the pandemics infection are replaced by degenerative and man-made disorders as the main cause of morbidity and most frequent cause of fatality is known as epidemiological transition.
  • The epidemiologic transition describes changing patterns of population distributions in relation to changing patterns of mortality, fertility, life expectancy, and leading causes of death.
  • The burden of disease pattern of developed, developing high mortality, and developing low mortality countries in the world differ substantially. This phenomenon reflects what is known as the “epidemiological transition’.
  • As life expectancy increases, the major causes of death and disability in general shift from communicable, maternal and perinatal causes to chronic, non-communicable ones.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 35.

questions.text: 500 people in a population of 5000 had myopia as of January 1, 2011, and nine new cases had developed by December 31, 2011. Determine the incidence?
questions.solution:
Incidence for given data is 2%

Incidence=(no. of new cases/total population under risk)×1000
Incidence= 9/(5000-500) × 1000=
(9/4500)×1000=2%

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: What will happen if several screening tests are conducted Consecutively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Increased positive predictive value 

Conducting several screening tests consecutively is also known as testing in series. It increases Positive predictive value.
 

Testing in Series

  1. Sequential Testing: In series testing, individuals undergo multiple tests in a predefined order. For a patient to be classified as positive in a series of tests, they must test positive on all tests in the sequence.

  2. Effect on Sensitivity and Specificity: The overall sensitivity and specificity of the series of tests are affected by the sensitivity and specificity of each individual test and their combined performance.

Positive Predictive Value (PPV)

  • Definition: PPV is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease.
  • Calculation: PPV depends not only on the sensitivity and specificity of each test but also on the prevalence of the disease in the population being tested.
  • Impact of Series Testing:

    • PPV tends to increase with sequential testing in series. This is because as more tests are added, the likelihood of false positives decreases, especially if individual tests have less than perfect specificity.

    • The formula for PPV when tests are conducted in series is:

      PPV=True Positives in the entire series/Total number of Positive results in the entire series

Negative Predictive Value (NPV)

  • Definition: NPV is the probability that individuals with a negative test result truly do not have the disease.
  • Calculation: NPV depends on the sensitivity and specificity of each test, as well as the prevalence of the disease.
  • Impact of Series Testing:

    • NPV generally improves with sequential testing in parallel or simultaneous testing. This is because the probability of correctly ruling out disease (true negatives) increases as more tests confirm a negative result.

    • The formula for NPV when tests are conducted in series is:

      NPV=True Negatives in the entire series/Total number of Negative results in the entire series

Reference: Medical Biostatistics, 3rd edition, Page no 56.

questions.text: What is a secondary wave of cases a feature of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Point source epidemics

Secondary waves and an exponential rise in number of cases is seen in Point source multiple exposure epidemics. Person to person transmission occurs.

Point source epidemics can be either single exposure or multiple exposure.
  • Single exposure – cases occur within 1 IP. Only one wave is seen called primary wave.
  • Multiple exposure – Cases present in more than 1 IP but person to person transmission is not seen. Secondary waves are present.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 72.

questions.text: Which form of prevention uses rifampicin to prevent meningococci in contacts of a case?

Giving Rifampicin to contacts of meningococcal cases is a form of primary mode of prevention as the risk factor is already present.

choices.text: Provided once 100% of the population in the given community is vaccinated

questions.text: Which of these is true about herd immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Develops by clinical & subclinical infections
 
  • Herd immunity is the protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunisation.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of a population is immune to a disease.
  • It develops by occurrence of clinical and sub clinical infection in the herd.
  • It is not necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population. The proportion of immune individuals  above which a disease no longer spreads  is called herd immunity threshold.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 117.

Sensitivity of a screening test  is the probability of a person testing positive when he’s actually having a disease.

Option 1 : Specificity is defined as the probability of  a non-diseased person testing negative .
