questions.text: Every fifth house in a neighbourhood is visited by an investigator for the malaria monitoring indicator. The method of sampling being used is called-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Systemic random sampling

Selecting every nth individual is known as Systematic random sampling. It is a type of random sampling where every individual has a known and equal chance.

Types of sampling



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: The null hypothesis was confirmed and accepted in an epidemiological investigation. In actuality, the null hypothesis was incorrect. The study's error is of the following type:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Type 2



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 33, 34.

questions.text: How can you compute incidence rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Cohort study 

A long-term follow-up cohort study can compute incidence rate. Here a cohort group of individuals with common characteristics are selected and divided into two groups, one having risk factors and other without risk factors.

Prevalence is measured with cross-sectional study.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: Which of the following will result in an increase in illness prevalence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Longer duration of disease

Longer duration of disease leads to increased prevalence as the number of new individuals getting affected remain the same (incidence remains same)  and since there is no cure or death the number of people suffering from the disease at a given point in time is increased.

Reason:
Prevalence=incidence × duration

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.

choices.text: Achieve comparability between study and control groups

questions.text: Double blinding in clinical studies is done for what reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Avoid observer and subject bias

Blinding is done to reduce and prevent bias.
  • Single – subject is blind.
  • Double – subject and observer both are blind.
  • Triple – subject, observer, analyser are blind.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 98.

choices.text: Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis
Time between usual time of diagnosis and outcome

questions.text: How is lead time defined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis

Lead time is the duration between first possible time when disease can be detected and the usual time of diagnosis.

  • Lead time is defined as the amount of time gained by early detection of a disease through screening. It is the difference between the time of diagnosis through screening and the time of diagnosis without screening.
  • Therefore, the correct option is 2. Time between point where the diagnosis is made by screening test to usual diagnosis.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because it refers to the time between diagnosis and treatment, which is not the same as lead time.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because it refers to the time between disease onset and outcome, which is also not the same as lead time.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because it refers to the time between usual time of diagnosis and outcome, which is again not the same as lead time.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 149.

questions.text: Epidemiological triangle for infectious diseases differs epidemiological triad with respect to ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Time

Host, agent and environment are the three factors present in both epidemiological triad and epidemiological triangle. The difference in both is “time” which is a part of epidemiological triangle.

            
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 39, 40.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following traits apply to health indicators.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Affordability

Health indicators measure different aspects of health of a population.
Examples include – life expectancy, infant mortality, disability rates

Characteristics of health indicators :
  • Valid
  • Reliable
  • Sensitive
  • Specific
  • Feasible
  • Relevant
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 24.

questions.text: Educating kids to support a healthy lifestyle is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Primordial prevention

Educating kids to support a healthy lifestyle is a method to prevent introduction of risk factors in their life. It is a primordial form of prevention.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 48.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'Case-Control Study' is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: It is a prospective study

Case control study is a retrospective study.

The case control method has three distinct features :
a. both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
b. the study proceeds backwards from effect to cause; and
c. it uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an inference.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: With the exception of____all of the following are selection bias in case-control studies
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hawthorne bias
  • Hawthorne Bias: In case of cohort studies or long term cohort studies, when the person under observation shows change in behaviour e.g A smoker being studied for lung cancer risk stops smoking. This is known as Hawthorne bias.
  • Berksonian bias – Specific to hospital based case control studies. Ideally cases = controls but in hospitals the admission rates of controls is lesser and thus a bias emerges.
  • Volunteer bias – When participants are allowed to choose if they want to be a part of the sample. It leads to a sample that is not representative of the population as whole.
  • Neyman bias – In conditions with high rate of mortality, many diseases are missed due to the death of the cases.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about propagated epidemics is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  No secondary waves occur

Propagated epidemic shows secondary waves, which appear as successive peaks in a graph.
Person-to-person transmission occurs.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 73.

questions.text:
There are 100 youngsters living in a boarding house, and 15 of them have received the measles vaccine. 10 cases of measles occurred on the first of the month during an outbreak, and 35 cases on the eleventh. How common are measles secondary attacks?
1. \(35/85\times 100\)
2. \(35/75\times 100\)
3. \(35/100\times 100\)
4. \(45/85\times 100\)
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  \(35/75\times 100\)

The formula for secondary attack rate is


 
Total new cases = 35
Primary cases = 10
Total susceptible population = 100 – 15 (vaccinated)
Primary cases are excluded from both numerator and denominator.

SAR = 35/( 85 -10) x 100 = 35/75 x 100

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: Which sampling technique does the WHO most frequently employ to gauge immunisation coverage levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Cluster sampling

The Expanded Program on Immunisation (EPI) by WHO employs Cluster sampling to measure immunisation coverage levels.
210 children in 30 clusters with 7 children in each are taken.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 148.

questions.text: A good index of the severity of an acute disease is expressed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Case fatality rate 

A good index of the severity of an acute disease is expressed by Case fatality rate.
  • The formula for calculating the Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is:
        CFR = (Number of deaths from the disease / Number of confirmed cases of the disease) x 100
  • Case fatality rate represents the killing power of a disease.
  • It is simply the ratio of deaths to cases. The time interval is not specified.
  • Case fatality rate is typically used in acute infectious diseases (e.g., food poisoning, cholera, measles).
  • Its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited, because the period from onset to death is long and variable.
  • The case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics because of changes in the agent, host and environmental factors. Case fatality is closely related to virulence.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Direct standardization is done with an objective to compare the mortality rates between two countries. This is done due to the differentiating factor of -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Age distributions 

It is necessary to do direct standardisation while comparing two countries due to the differentiating factor of age distribution. If standardisation is not done, the mortality rate will be higher in a country with more elderly population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Choose the Term of sampling, where a village is divided into five relevant subgroups for the purpose of a survey. Individuals from each subgroup are then selected randomly.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Stratified sampling 
  • Stratified random sampling involves dividing the population into subgroups or strata based on specific characteristics that are relevant to the study.
  • Within each stratum, a random sample is drawn, and the size of the sample from each stratum is proportional to the size of that stratum in the overall population.
  • Researchers often use stratified random sampling when the population is Heterogeneous.                

Types of sampling


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: Choose the term of sampling where region is divided into 50 villages for the purposes of a survey. 10 villages are then selected randomly for the purpose of a study.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Cluster Sampling
 
  • Cluster sampling involves dividing the population into smaller, more manageable groups or clusters. Once the clusters are defined, a random sample of clusters is selected. Then a random subset of individuals within the selected clusters is included in the final sample.
  •  Simple random sample : This is done by assigning a number to each of the units (the individuals or households) in the sampling frame. A table of random numbers is then used (see page 853) to determine which units are to be included in the sample. Random numbers are a haphazard collection of certain numbers, arranged in a cunning manner to eliminate personal selection of unconscious bias in taking out the sample. With this procedure, the sample is drawn in such a way that each unit has an equal chance of being drawn in the sample. This technique provides the greatest number of possible samples.
  • Systematic random sample : This is done by picking every 5th or 10th unit at regular intervals. For example, to carry out a filaria survey in a town, we take 10 per cent sample. The houses are numbered first. Then a number is selected at random between 1 and 10 (say four). Then every 10th number is selected from that point on 4, 14, 24, 34, etc. By this method, each unit in the sampling frame would have the same chance of being selected, but the number of possible samples is greatly reduced.
  • Stratified random sample : The sample is deliberately drawn in a systematic way so that each portion of the sample represents a corresponding strata of the universe. This method is particularly useful where one is interested in analysing the data by a certain characteristic of the population, viz. Hindus, Christians, Muslims, age-groups etc. - as we know these groups are not equally distributed in the population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of WHO STEP wise approach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, psychological measurement is not a component of WHO STEP wise approach. 

STEP approach of WHO is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non communicable diseases. It includes:
 
  1. Questionnaires containing questions regarding behavioral risk factor like tobacco use. 
  2. Physical measurements in the form of blood pressure, height, weight. 
  3. Biochemical methods in the form of blood glucose, lipids. 

Mental health and suicide may be included in optional behavioral risk factors but it is the least preferrable option among others.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 47, 287, 373, 394, 452.

questions.text: You are posted at an urban PHC. You received 1 open vial of pentavalent vaccine and 1 open vial of MMR vaccine after 2 days of a vaccination drive. Cold chain requirements were fully met. What will you do ?
questions.solution:
According to open vial policy, MMR vaccine once reconstituted should not be reused. Hence, it is discarded. 

On the other hand, Pentavalent vaccine follows open vial policy and therefore can be reused upto 28 days.
 

In immunization programs, open vial policies (OVP) guide whether a vaccine vial can be used after being opened, provided certain conditions are met. These conditions include adherence to the cold chain, proper handling, and sterility. According to the World Health Organization (WHO) and national guidelines:

  1. Pentavalent vaccine (DTP-HepB-Hib):

    • It is a liquid vaccine, and if stored properly (cold chain maintained at 2–8°C) and sterility is ensured, it can be used for up to 28 days after opening as per the multi-dose vial policy.

  2. MMR vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella):

    • This is a lyophilized (powdered) vaccine that requires reconstitution with a diluent before use. Once reconstituted, it must be used within 6 hours or discarded, as it is more prone to contamination and loses potency rapidly.


Appropriate action: Since the MMR vial has been open for 2 days, it must be discarded. The pentavalent vaccine, if stored properly and meeting the multi-dose vial policy, can still be used.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 121.

choices.text: Children from the same community, not having blood cancer, not exposed to water
Children from the same community, not having blood cancer, exposed to water
Children from the hospital, not having blood cancer, not exposed to water
Children from the hospital, not having blood cancer, exposed to water

questions.text: Number of children from a particular community were found to have blood cancer. It was presumed that there is some chemical in the water supplied that might have caused the blood cancer. It was decided to conduct a case-control study to find the association of this chemical with the occurrence of blood cancer. Children having ALL and exposed to water was taken as cases. What group of children will constitute control?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, children who belong to same community and not suffering from blood cancer as well as not exposed to water can be taken as controls. 
 
  • Children from the community who do not have the disease will be considered as the control group for the case-control study. The key criterion for selecting a control group is that they must be free from the disease being studied. They should closely resemble the cases in all aspects except for the absence of the disease.
 
  • Typically, the control group consists of individuals who have not been exposed to the disease or the factor being investigated. Hence, the best option for this study is to use children attending the OPD without the disease and without exposure as the controls.
 
  • Case-control studies, also known as retrospective studies, work by tracing the effect back to its cause and are conducted after both exposure and outcome have occurred. These studies focus on health issues or diseases that have already developed. They are less time-intensive and avoid the risk of attrition since follow-up is not required.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 79-83.

choices.text: Give injection Benzathine penicillin for 5 years or until the age of 18 years, whichever is later
Give injection Benzathine penicillin for 10 years or until the age of 25 years, whichever is later

questions.text: A 12 years old girl is suffering has clinical manifestations of rheumatic fever. She had no carditis.Which of the following is true regarding secondary prevention?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The secondary prophylaxis  after an episode for a patient who weighs less than 27 kg is 6,00,000 IU of benzathine penicillin once in 3 weeks for 5 years or till the age of 18, whichever is longer. 
 
  • Secondary prevention of rheumatic fever involves the use of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent recurrent attacks, which can lead to rheumatic heart disease.
  • In a patient with rheumatic fever but no carditis, the recommended duration of secondary prophylaxis is 5 years or until 18 years of age, whichever is later.
  • Injection Benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units intramuscular every 3–4 weeks) is the standard regimen for secondary prophylaxis.


Other options 

  • Option 2 is applicable for patients with carditis and residual heart disease.
  • Option 3 (lifelong prophylaxis) is used in special cases, such as those with severe valve disease or after valve surgery.
  • Option 4 (single dose) is inadequate for secondary prevention.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 433. 434.

choices.text: Drinking of green tea increase the chances of diabetes mellitus
Drinking of green tea decreases the chances of diabetes mellitus
Drinking of green tea has no effect over development of diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A cohort study was undertaken to calculate the association of drinking green tea with the development of diabetes mellitus. The value for relative risk came out to be 0.86. What will be your inference?
questions.solution:
Green tea reduces the risk of diabetes mellitus is the correct statement since the risk ratio is 0.86. 
                                         
                           


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 86.

choices.text: Use vial if inner square lighter than outer circle
Use vial if inner circle lighter than outer square
Use vial if inner square same as outer circle
Use vial if inner circle same as outer square

questions.text: For VVM1, identify the correct statement?
questions.solution:
• A vaccine vial monitor is a thermochromic label put on vials containing vaccines which gives a visual indication of whether the vaccine has been kept at a temperature which preserves its potency.
 
  • It consists of an inner square and outer circle.


     



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 117, 121.

choices.text: If smoking is eliminated as risk factor there will be 95% reduction in annual incidence of lung cancer cases among the exposed
If smoking is eliminated as risk factor there will be 95% reduction in annual incidence of lung cancer cases among the population

questions.text: The population attributable risk calculated between smoking and lung cancer is 95%. Identify the correct statement
questions.solution:
• Population attributable Risk is the contribution of that risk factor to burden of the disease/deaths due to the disease.






Reference:  Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 86.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding genetic screening of the newborn? 
(i) Screening tests define the risk of transmission of a genetic disorder 
(ii) Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests
(iii) Screening of a disease requires genetic mapping 
(iv) Screening always involves invasive procedure.
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the true statement regarding genetic screening of the newborn is:

(i) Screening tests define the risk of transmission of a genetic disorder.

Genetic screening tests for newborns are designed to identify the risk or presence of certain genetic disorders. They aim to identify newborns who may have an increased risk of developing or carrying genetic conditions. These tests can provide information about the likelihood of a genetic disorder being transmitted from the parents to the newborn. However, it is important to note that screening tests do not provide a definitive diagnosis of a genetic disorder but rather assess the risk or probability. 

The other statements are not true:

(ii) Diagnostic tests are typically more accurate than screening tests. Screening tests identify individuals who have an increased risk of a specific condition, while diagnostic tests confirm or rule out a specific condition.

(iii) Genetic mapping is not always required for screening tests. Genetic screening tests may utilize various methods.

(iv) Screening tests do not always involve invasive procedures. In fact, many newborn genetic screening tests can be conducted using non-invasive methods, such as a blood sample obtained from a heel prick.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 148 .

questions.text: In a study among two groups of people working in an aniline dye factory, bladder cancer among factory workers is compared to bladder  cancer among office workers for the last 20 years. The past work records are obtained from the offices. What type of study is performed?
questions.solution:
A retrospective cohort study (or "historical" cohort study) is one in which the outcomes have all occurred before the start of the investigation.

  • The investigator goes back in time, sometimes 10 to 30 years, to select his study groups from existing records of past employment, medical or other records and traces them forward through time, from a past date fixed on the records, usually up to the present.
  • This type of study is known by a variety of names : retrospective cohort study, "historical" cohort study, prospective study in retrospect and non-concurrent prospective study.
  • Study time is often of shorter duration because predictor measurements have already been made and documented. In addition, such studies can be less costly and time-consuming than prospective cohort studies. 


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 84.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Longitudinal observational and Analytical study?
questions.solution:
Cohort study is an example of Longitudinal observational and Analytical study.
Cohort study is considered to be most reliable means of showing an association between cause [risk factor} and disease.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page. No: 70, 71, 83.

questions.text: Which of the following studies progresses from cause to effect?
questions.solution:
A cohort study is an analytical study that progresses from cause to effect, examining individuals who have been exposed to a particular risk factor but have not yet developed the disease. It is also referred to as a forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, or longitudinal study. A well-designed cohort study is considered one of the most reliable methods for demonstrating an association between a cause or suspected risk factor and the subsequent development of disease.

Types of Epidemiological Studies:
1. Observational Studies: These studies allow nature to take its course, where the investigator measures outcomes without intervening.
       a)Descriptive Studies: Focus on describing the occurrence of a disease within a population, primarily for hypothesis formulation.

       b)Analytical Studies: Explore the relationship between health status and other variables for hypothesis testing.
           • Ecological Studies
           • Cross-Sectional Studies
           • Case-Control Studies
           •Cohort Studies

2. Experimental Studies (Intervention Studies): These involve active attempts to change a disease determinant or its progression, similar to experiments in other scientific fields, aimed at hypothesis confirmation.
• Randomized Controlled Trials
• Field Trials
• Community Trials
This classification helps in understanding the design and purpose of different epidemiological studies, guiding researchers in selecting the appropriate methodology for their investigations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) guidelines are used for reporting the results of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). To enhance the quality of health research reporting, specific standards have been established based on the type of study conducted. Many journals now require authors to complete the appropriate checklist aligned with these standards before submitting their work for publication. 



Reference : Essential Edidemiology : An Introduction For Students and health Professionals, Page no 264,303 .

questions.text: A group of 30,000 women was observed over 10 years to monitor the development of breast cancer. Among them, 1,200 women who developed breast cancer were given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. Additionally, 2,000 women from the same cohort who did not develop breast cancer were selected as controls and were also administered the questionnaire. What is the classification of this type of study?
questions.solution:
• A nested case-control study is a type of case-control study conducted within a cohort study.
 
  • In this design, the cases consist of cohort members who developed the disease under investigation at a specific point during the follow-up period. Each case is paired with one or more controls — individuals who did not develop the disease but are otherwise similar to the cases in terms of age and gender.
 
  • The exposures of both cases and controls to the risk factor are then compared. Essentially, nested case-control studies provide an interim analysis of the exposure and outcome data within a cohort study.


 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 84, 85.

questions.text: A study was conducted to compare MMR vaccine history in children with autism and children without autism. What kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned above is characteristic of a case-control study, where children with autism are classified as cases, while those without autism serve as controls.

A case-control study is an observational study used to test hypotheses. In this design, participants are divided into two groups: cases, which consist of individuals with the disease of interest, and controls, comprising individuals without the disease. The odds ratio is used to measure the strength of the association between a risk factor and the outcome in these studies.

Other options:

Option C: A cross-sectional study assesses a single snapshot of a population at a specific point in time, allowing results to be generalized to the entire population.
Option B: A cohort study classifies subjects into those with exposure and those without exposure. This type of study provides a relative risk, which is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among the exposed group compared to the incidence among the non-exposed group. If the study were to categorize children based on whether they received the MMR vaccine or not to explore any association with autism, it would be classified as a cohort study.
Option A: A clinical trial is a form of experimental or interventional study focused on evaluating therapeutic agents, primarily drugs.

questions.text: Infectivity is also known as?
questions.solution:
Infectivity, also referred to as the secondary attack rate, describes the ability of an infectious agent to establish a new infection in a susceptible host. For diseases that are transmitted directly, infectivity is quantified through the secondary attack rate (SAR), which indicates the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the infection after being exposed to a primary case. This metric reflects the disease's communicability.

Calculation of Secondary Attack Rate (SAR):
SAR=(Number of exposed persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/ (Total number of susceptible close contacts).

Incubation Period:
The incubation period is the interval between the invasion of an infectious agent and the appearance of the first signs or symptoms of the disease. During this time, the agent replicates within the host, accumulating to levels sufficient to manifest as a disease.
Calculating the incubation period accurately can be challenging; therefore, the time interval between the onset of symptoms in the primary case and the subsequent secondary case is utilized as a measure of the incubation period. This interval is referred to as the serial interval.

questions.text: How much per cent of GNP does WHO recommend being spent on the healthcare sector?
questions.solution:
• WHO recommendation: Countries should spend at least 5% of their Gross National Product (GNP) (or GDP) on the healthcare sector.

  • India: Currently spends much less (~1.5–2% of GDP on public health), which is below the WHO recommendation.

  • This underfunding is a major reason for high out-of-pocket expenditure by patients in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding single exposure point source epidemic ?
questions.solution:
The true statement regarding a single exposure point source epidemic is that it is explosive in nature.

Single exposure point source epidemics arise from a brief and simultaneous exposure to a harmful agent. This type of epidemic has several key characteristics:
  • It exhibits a single peak with no secondary waves in case numbers.
  • The epidemic tends to be explosive, with a clustering of cases occurring within a narrow time frame.
  • The epidemic curve typically shows a sharp, rapid rise and fall, as all cases fall within one incubation period.
  • The exposure in these epidemics can result from either an infectious agent or a contaminant in the environment, which could be present in air, water, food, or soil, as well as from industrial chemicals or pollutants.
Examples of such epidemics include food poisoning outbreaks and the Bhopal gas tragedy in India, which was caused by methyl isocyanate.

questions.text: Identify the graph given below:
questions.solution:
A propagated epidemic curve shows multiple peaks, each separated by an incubation period — representing person-to-person transmission (e.g., measles, COVID-19, chickenpox).
Each successive wave appears higher than the previous one as more individuals become infected.

Other options:

  • Common source, continuous exposure: Shows a plateau-like curve — cases remain elevated as long as exposure continues.

  • Point source, single exposure: Sharp rise and fall in cases — all exposed at once (e.g., food poisoning).

  • Modern epidemic: Not a recognized epidemiological term.


Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition - Page no 72, 73

questions.text: Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis is done in many countries to protect the home population. What form of prevention is this?
questions.solution:
• Primary prevention aims to prevent the occurrence of disease before it happens.

  • Screening immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis helps in identifying and preventing transmission to the host population, thus preventing the disease from occurring in others.

  • This does not treat an existing case (which would be secondary or tertiary prevention) but reduces risk and incidence.

Other options:

  • Secondary prevention: Early detection and prompt treatment to halt progression (e.g., TB screening in high-risk contacts).

  • Tertiary prevention: Reducing complications or disability in established disease.

  • Primordial prevention: Preventing the emergence of risk factors themselves (e.g., promoting healthy lifestyle to avoid hypertension).


Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition 149

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a disease who die from that disease within a specified period. It is a direct measure of the virulence (severity or lethality) of the causative agent.

Other options:

  • Secondary attack rate: Measures transmissibility among contacts, not virulence.

  • Survival rate: Related to prognosis but not commonly used in outbreak assessment.

  • Incidence rate: Measures new cases over time; it reflects spread, not severity.



Reference: Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 66

questions.text: Which of the following is helpful in predicting the virulence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a disease who die from it within a specified period. It reflects the severity or virulence of the disease. Higher CFR indicates a more virulent pathogen.

Other options:

  • Prevalence: Measures the total number of cases at a point in time; reflects burden, not virulence.

  • Proportional mortality rate: Proportion of deaths due to a specific disease among all deaths; does not directly measure virulence.

  • Incidence: Measures new cases over time; indicates spread but not severity.



Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 66

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
The overall burden of disease is assessed using the disability-adjusted life year (DALY), a time-based measure that combines years of life lost due to premature mortality (YLLs) and years of life lost due to time lived in states of less than full health, or years of healthy life lost due to disability (YLDs).
DALY = YLL+YLD

The quality-adjusted life year (QALY) is a generic measure of disease burden, including both the quality and the quantity of life lived. It is used in economic evaluation to assess the value of medical interventions. One QALY equates to one year in perfect health.

Health-adjusted life expectancy (HALE) is the average number of years that a person is expected to live in good health by taking into account years lived in less than full health due to disease and/or injury.

DFLE stands for disability-free life expectancy. It's a measure of health expectancy that indicates how many years a person is expected to live without any activity limitations. DFLE is also known as healthy life years (HLY).

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
• Prospective Cohort Study:

    • Definition: A type of observational study where subjects are followed forward in time from exposure to outcome.

    • In this case:

      • Exposure = Maternal smoking during pregnancy

      • Outcome = Birth weight of the baby

      • Smoking data is collected during antenatal visits, and babies are followed up after delivery → this is forward-looking (prospective).

      • The cohort (pregnant women) is classified based on exposure status (smokers vs non-smokers), and the outcome (low birth weight) is observed afterwards.

        Other Options:

  • 1. Retrospective Cohort:

    • Exposure and outcome have already occurred when the study begins.

    • Here, the outcome (birth weight) is yet to occur → not retrospective.

  • 3. Case-Control:

    • Starts with the outcome, then looks backward for exposure.

    • This study starts with exposure → not case-control.

  • 4. Cross-Sectional:

    • Measures exposure and outcome simultaneously at a single point in time.

    • This study involves follow-up, so it's not cross-sectional.

      SUMMARY OF EPIDEMIOLOGICAL STUDIES:

       

      Study Type Start Point Direction Exposure Measured? Outcome Measured? Example
      Prospective Cohort Before outcome Forward in time Yes (before outcome) Yes (after exposure) Smoking during pregnancy → followed to assess birth weight of babies
      Retrospective Cohort After both exposure & outcome Backward in time Yes (from records) Yes (from records) Occupational asbestos exposure → past cancer incidence from records
      Case-Control After outcome Backward in time Yes (retrospective) Yes (already known) Low birth weight babies → check maternal smoking history
      Cross-Sectional At a single point in time None (snapshot) Yes Yes Survey current smoking status and current birth weight

questions.text: Which of the following is used to reduce the selection bias in a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Selection bias occurs when the participants selected for a study are not representative of the target population or when the allocation of participants to different groups (e.g., intervention vs. control) is not truly random.

How Randomization Helps:

  • Randomization is the process of assigning participants to different groups purely by chance.

  • It reduces selection bias by ensuring that each participant has an equal chance of being placed in any group.

  • It balances both known and unknown confounding variables between groups.

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

Option Why It's Incorrect for Reducing Selection Bias
Written informed consent Ensures ethical participation, not related to bias reduction.
Intervention Is the treatment being tested, not a bias-reducing method.
Selecting the population Careful selection may improve generalizability but may introduce, not reduce, selection bias.

Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 24th edition page no 87

questions.text: The average GFR in a group of 100 participants is 85 ml/min, with a standard deviation of 25. What is the 90% confidence interval range?
questions.solution:
Range or 90% confidence interval in the given question is 81-89.

Confidence Intervals
The Lower Limit and Upper Limit estimates for the Statistic are given as:
Lower Limit: statistic - C x SE (statistic)
Upper Limit: statistic+ C x SE (statistic)
.Standard Error, SE= {Standard Deviation / n1/2}      where, n = sample size


Confidence coefficient:

C = Confidence coefficient = 1.65 for 90% confidence interval 
                                            = 1.96 for 95% confidence interval ,its approx 2
                                            = 2.58 for 99% confidence interval, its approx 3

In this question:
n1/2= 10; SD = 25
SE= 25/ 10 = 2.5
Lower limit= 85- (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 - 4 = 81
Upper limit= 85+ (1.65 x 2.5) = 85 + 4 = 89

Hence, 90% CI will be 81-89.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 19.

questions.text: The blood pressures of 200 people were measured. The data's first quartile BP was 94 mm Hg, while the third quartile was 110 mm Hg. How many patients have blood pressures that fall between the third and fourth quartiles?
questions.solution:
In the given question, fifty patients have blood pressures between the 3rd and 4th quartile.

Quartile:
In descriptive statistics, the quartiles of a ranked set of data values are the three points that divide the data set into four equal groups, each group comprising a quarter of the data.

A quartile is a type of quantile.

The first quartile (Q1) is defined as the middle number between the smallest number and the median of the data set.
The second quartile (Q2) is the median of the data.
The Third quartile (Q3) is the middle value between the median and the highest value of the data set.

First quartile (designated QI) also called the lower quartile or the 25th percentile (splits off the lowest 25% of data from the highest 75%).
Second quartile (designated Q2) also called median or the 50"' percentile (cuts data set in half).
Third quartile (designated Q3) also called the upper quartile or the 75"' percentile (splits off the highest 25% of data from the lowest 75%).

Interquartile range (designated IQR) is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles. (IQR= Q3- QI)

In the given question, between every two quartiles one/ fourth of the total number of patients are present, i.e.
200/4 = 50 patients.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: The box plot below depicts the distribution of three sets of data around the mean. What is the correct order of inference from this box plot?
questions.solution:
The direction of the tail, or the direction of the values with the least frequency, designates whether a set of data is positively or negatively skewed.
  • The data set is divided into quartiles using a boxplot.
  • A "box" (hence the name) extending from the first quartile (Ql) to the third quartile (Q3) makes up the body of the boxplot.
  • A line is drawn inside the box at Q2, at the midpoint, designating the median of the data set.
  • The box has two whisker-like lines that protrude from the front and back. The back whisker extends from Q3 to the largest non-outlier, and the front whisker extends from Q1 to the smallest non-outlier in the data set.
  • If there are any outliers in the data set, they are shown as independent points.
On rotating clockwise, 
1st pic= normal distribution
2nd pic= negatively skewed as tailing or elongation is on left side.
3rd pic = positively skewed as tailing or elongation is on right side.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text:
The scatter plot below depicts the association between weight and height in four separate samples.
What is the net correlation coefficient if all four samples have the same coefficient of correlation of 0.6?
questions.solution:
The slope of the graph provides the coefficient of correlation.
The net correlation coefficient will remain at 0.6 because the slopes of all four populations are the same, at 0.6.
  • Correlation coefficient is a linear link between two variables which can be measured by the value r, and is also known as the linear correlation coefficient or the Pearson product moment correlation coefficient.
  • If there is a “perfect” linear relationship between the two variables so that it is possible to know the exact value of one variable from knowledge of the other variable, the correlation coefficient r will be exactly ±1.00.
  • If there is absolutely no relationship between the two variables, so that it is impossible to know anything about one variable on the basis of knowledge of the other variable, then the coefficient will be zero.
  • Coefficients beyond ±0.5 are typically regarded as strong, whereas coefficients between 0 and ±0.5 are usually regarded as weak. 
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 36.

questions.text: What is the following data description called?
questions.solution:
• In a specific table called a "Stem and Leaf Plot," each data value is divided into a "stem" (the initial digit or digits) and a "leaf" (usually the last digit).
  • To help visualize the shape of a distribution, a stem-and-leaf display is a tool for presenting quantitative data in a graphical style, comparable to a histogram.
  • Two columns are divided by a vertical line in a straightforward stem-and-leaf layout. The stems are in the left column, and the leaves are in the right column.
In order to give the reader a fast overview of distribution, stem-and-leaf displays are helpful for illustrating the relative density and shape of the data. The majority of the original numerical data is retained, frequently in complete fidelity. They are helpful for identifying outliers and emphasizing data as well.


Online reference: https://statisticsbyjim.com/graphs/stem-and-leaf-plot/

questions.text: The mean systolic blood pressure was measured in a sample population of elderly females and came out to be 125 mm Hg with a standard deviation of 10. 95 percent of people would have blood pressure above:
questions.solution:
Confidence Intervals
C = Confidence coefficient
= 1 for 68% confidence interval
= 1.96 for 95% confidence interval
= 2.58 for 99% confidence interval
= 3.29 for 99.9% confidence interval
This suggests that the range between Mean - 2 SD and Mean + 2 SD covers 95% of the population.
A value less than Mean - 2 SD will be found in about 2.5% of the population. (Or, 5% divided equally on both sides.)

Here,
Mean = 125
SD = 10
Mean - 2SD = 145 (95% confidence interval lower limit)
Mean - SD = 135 (68% confidence interval lower limit)

The average person's blood pressure will be over 105 mm Hg in 97.5% of cases, and over 115 mm Hg in roughly 84%.
Extrapolating, 95% of people will have blood pressure that is in between 105 and 115 mm Hg i.e. 110 mm Hg.

questions.text:
In a clinical trial, a patient group's blood pressure was assessed both before and after the intervention.
Which of the following tests would be appropriate for a significance test?
questions.solution:
• Paired t-test compares study subjects at 2 different times (paired observations of the same subject) on parametric data. 
     
  • Unpaired t-test (aka Student's test) compares two different subjects.
  • The paired t-test reduces inter-subject variability (because it makes comparisons between the same subject), and thus is theoretically more powerful than the unpaired t-test .

In the question, blood pressure was measured in a group of patients before and after treatment, Paired t-test will be suitable as a test of significance.


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 34.

questions.text:

two independent groups after treatment?
questions.solution:
Research volunteers at two different times are compared on parametric data using a paired t-test (paired observations of the same subject).
A t-test that contrasts two unrelated subjects is known as a student's test.

Answer : Unpaired t-test is a good statistical test since blood pressure was measured after treatment in the question between two independent groups.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best for figuring out the limit for a test's positive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ROC is used to evaluate the test's sensitivity and specificity.
  • The probability ratio, which is crucial for establishing the test's threshold, is found using the tangent to the curve.
  • The specificity diminishes with increasing sensitivity.
  • The tangent of the curve aids in determining the test's accuracy criterion, which is high sensitivity without sacrificing specificity.
Each point on the ROC curve represents a sensitivity/specificity pair corresponding to a particular cutoff point or decision threshold.
A test that discriminates perfectly between the presence and absence of disease would have an ROC curve that passes through the upper left corner (100% sensitivity, 100% specificity)—so the closer the curve is to the upper left corner, the higher the overall accuracy of the test. A completely random test (e.g., coin tossing) would give an ROC “curve” that is actually the red line.

The shape of the curve therefore reflects the quality of the test; the better the test, the more the curve moves to the upper left. This can be quantified in terms of the area under the curve (AUC); the worst case is 0.5 (the red line), and the best is 1.00 (upper left-hand corner). A “good” test is one with a high rate of true positives and a low rate of false negatives over a reasonable range of cutoff values; in other words it has a high AUC as the curve moves towards the upper left corner.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 74.

  • Positive slope – Positive correlation

questions.text: To determine the average intraocular pressure, a study was done. IOP was measured in 400 individuals, with a mean value of 25 mm Hg and an SD of 10 mm Hg. What would be the range of IOP for 95% of the population?
questions.solution:
The LL and UL estimates for the Statistic are given as: 

Lower limit: Statistic - C*SE (statistic)

Upper limit: Statistic + C*SE (statistic) 

Standard error, SE= {standard deviation/√ n)}

  n = sample size

 

C= Confidence coefficient

1.96 for 95% confidence interval

Hence, in this question,

N = 400 

SD = 10

=>SE =0.5

Mean statistic = 25 mm Hg

Now for 95% confidence interval, C = 2 approximately 

95% CI= 25 - 2*0.5 to 25 + 2*0.5 = 24-26 mm  Hg.

Hence, 95% CI of IOP will be 24 to 26 mm Hg.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 21, 22, 23.

questions.text: The hemoglobin levels of pregnant females in a community was found to have a mean of 10.6 g /dL and a standard deviation of 2 g/dL. What is the minimum hemoglobin level below which 5% of the pregnant females will have their hemoglobin levels?
questions.solution:
Since the mean is 10.6 and SD is 2, therefore,
It can be concluded that
  • 68% of the population will have hemoglobin values between 10.6 minus two (8.6) and 10.6 plus two (12.6), while
  • 95% of the population will have hemoglobin values between 10.6 minus four (6.6) and 10.6 plus four (14.6).
  • The lowest 5% of the population will have values between 8.6 (34% of the population) and 6.6 (2.5% of the population), so the answer is 7.32.

questions.text: Area under Normal curve with \(\pm\)1 SD:
questions.solution:
Area under the Normal curve with +/- 1SD is 0.68.

In a normal distribution, about 68% of the data falls within ±1 standard deviation (SD) from the mean. This means:

  • Approximately 34% of the data lies between the mean and +1 SD.
  • Approximately 34% lies between the mean and -1 SD.

So, if you consider the area under the curve from -1 SD to +1 SD, it accounts for about 68% of the total area under the normal distribution curve.
 

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: Hemoglobin's mean value in a sample of 2000 people is 13.5 gm, which follows a normal distribution curve. What proportion of people have hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm?
questions.solution:
In a population with a normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode are all the same.

As a result, the median here is also 13.5, dividing the population into two equal halves.
As a result, 50% will be on either side of 13.5.
Hence, the percentage of people with hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm is 50.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

choices.text: Comparing the proportion of means of 2 groups
Comparing the proportion of means of more than 2 groups

questions.text: What is the statistical "Q" test used for?
questions.solution:
Q test is used for identification and rejection of outliers.

  • An outlier in statistics is an observation point that is separated from other observations. 
  • An outlier can be caused by measurement variability or by experimental error. 
  • Outliers can occur by chance in any distribution, but they are frequently indicative of either measurement error or a heavy-tailed distribution in the population.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 62.

questions.text: These are all continuous variables, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Blood Groups A, B, ABO are not an example of continuous variables. They are examples of discrete variables. 

  • A quantitative variable may be continuous or discrete if they are typically obtained by measuring or counting, respectively.
  • If it can take on two particular real values such that it can also take on all real values between them, the variable is continuous in that interval.
  • Continuous variables may take any value (typically between certain limits).
  • Most biomedical variables are continuous (e.g., a patient’s weight, height, age, and blood pressure).
  • However, the process of measuring or reporting continuous variables will reduce them to a discrete variable; blood pressure may be reported to the nearest whole millimeter of mercury, weight to the nearest pound, and age to the nearest year.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 3.

questions.text: Despite the fact that there is a difference, a study cannot find a meaningful correlation between two variables. What kind of error is this?
questions.solution:
• A type II error, also known as an error of the second kind, occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but erroneously fails to be rejected. It is failing to assert what is present, a miss.
 
  • A type I error, also known as an error of the first kind, occurs when the null hypothesis (H0) is true, but is rejected. It is asserting something that is absent, a false hit.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 28.

questions.text: The following criteria are used to determine how strongly a risk factor is linked to a disease:
questions.solution:
Strength of association  in epidemiological studies refers to the degree to which an exposure (like a risk factor) is linked to an outcome (like a disease).

  • It is measured by relative risk (RR) in Cohort studies and Odds ratio in Case control studies.

 Cohort study: The strength of association is often expressed using relative risk (RR), which compares the incidence of the outcome in the exposed group to the incidence in the unexposed group.

  • RR = I (exposed) / I (non-exposed)


Case control study : The strength of association is typically measured using odds ratio (OR), which compares the odds of exposure in cases to the odds of exposure in controls.
 
  • Interpretation: An OR greater than 1 suggests a positive association, while an OR less than 1 suggests a negative association. Like RR, the distance from 1 indicates the strength of the association.
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 81.

questions.text: What will the 95% confidence interval (CI) be given a sample size of 100 and an estimated prevalence of 10%?
questions.solution:
A confidence interval indicates where the population parameter is likely to reside.
  • For example, a 95% confidence interval of the mean [9 11] suggests you can be 95% confident that the population mean is between 9 and 11.
  • Confidence intervals also help you navigate the uncertainty of how well a sample estimates a value for an entire population.


95% CI= P+_ 2SE (proportion)
= 10+_ 2 square under root of 900/100
= 10 +_ 2 * 3 = 4-16


So, (2) option is correct.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: In a hospital, 30 children's APGAR scores were collected, and the majority of the values were 7 or higher. What conclusions can you draw from this data distribution?
questions.solution:
Since, more number of children have a higher APGAR score, the tail of the distribution curve will be towards the left.
Hence, the data will be negatively skewed.

1)Negative skew: The left tail is longer; the mass of the distribution is concentrated on the right of the figure.
  • The distribution is said to be left-skewed or skewed to the left.
  • Negative Skew: Mode> Median> Mean

2)Positive skew: The right tail is longer; the mass of the distribution is concentrated on the left of the figure.
  • The distribution is said to be right-skewed or skewed to the right.  
  • Positive Skew: Mode < Median < Mean

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 8.

questions.text: You have been asked to create a study for a condition with a 10% population prevalence. 5% alpha error must be maintained with 20% relative precision and 20% power. How many people will actually be included in the study's sample?
questions.solution:
Sample size is calculated with the help of formula:

N = (Z^2 )* p (1-p) / d2

Where,
N = sample size
Z = 1.96 for 95% confidence (alpha error = 5% means 95% CI)
p = Estimated population prevalence (10%)
d = Acceptable relative precision (20%)

N = [(1.96)^2]× 0.10 × 0.90 / [(10/100*20/100)^2]
     = 864

So, option B (900) will be correct answer.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

questions.text: The prevalence of a disease in a population is estimated to be 50%. A range of 45 to 55% with 95% certainty is of interest to an investigator. The study needs a minimum sample size of:
questions.solution:
Step 1: Determine the population size (N): An accurate calculation requires knowledge of the population size; however, if the population size is unknown, an estimate can be used.


Step 2: Calculate the margin of error (E).
E can be calculated using the formula,
E = Z*√(p*(1-p))/√n, where
Z is the desired level of confidence (1.96 for 95% confidence),
p is the desired prevalence (0.50 for 50%), and
n is the desired sample size.


Step 3: Calculate the sample size (n).
The sample size can be calculated using the following equation:
n = (Z^2 * p * (1-p))/E^2, where
Z is the desired level of confidence (1.96 for 95% confidence),
p is the desired proportion (0.50 for 50%), and
E is the desired margin of error (0.05 for 45-55%).

The resulting sample size for a 95% confidence interval with an expected 50% prevalence and an allowable margin of error of 5% is 384.

Note: The error of margin in a any study is allowed to be upto 5%.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

questions.text: In a population of 100 people, 80% are found to be infected with Candida glabrata. What will the range of prevalence for the candida glabrata infection be if the test is repeated with a 95% confidence level?
questions.solution:
To calculate the range of prevalence for Candida glabrata infection for 95% confidence levels we will use the formula for Binomial Confidence Intervals:

 Lower Limit = n * (p - Zα*sqrt(p*(1-p)/n)}
 
 Upper Limit = n * (p + Zα*sqrt(p*(1-p)/n)}

Where,

n = total number of individuals in the population

p = observed prevalence of the infection

Zα = The alpha level associated with the confidence interval (usually 1.96 for 95% confidence)

For this example,

n = 100

p = 80%

Zα = 1.96

Therefore, Lower Limit = 100 * (0.8 - 1.96*sqrt(0.8*(1-0.8)/100)} = 72.72%
Upper Limit = 100 * (0.8 + 1.96*sqrt(0.8*(1 - 0.8)/100)} = 87.28%

Therefore, the range of prevalence for Candida glabrata infection for 95% confidence level is 72.72% to 87.28%.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 22.

questions.solution:

 Values beyond the range are considered insignificant, but increasing the confidence interval will cause the insignificant values to become significant.

9840 out of 9920 who tested negative genuinely lacked the disease
Therefore,
  • Test negative in Disease negative = 9840 --TRUE NEGATIVE
  • Test negative in Disease positive = 9920-9840=80 -FALSE NEGATIVE

SENSITIVITY =


SPECIFICITY =


Therefore for this question,

SENSITIVITY =   × 100 =33%

questions.text: 90 people in a population of 1000 tested positive for DM during a screening. Then, 100 out of 100 gold standard tests were positive. Do the sensitivity calculations.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 90/100

According to the question,
90 people out of 1000 tested positive
100 out of 100 gold standard tests were positive.

Therefore,
Test positive and Disease positive = 90 ( TRUE POSITIVE )
Test negative but Disease positive = 100-90= 10 ( FALSE NEGATIVE )

Sensitivity =TRUE POSITIVE/(TRUE POSITIVE +FALSE NEGATIVE) 
                  = 90/100


Hence, Sensitivity = 90/100.

questions.text: In a research study, the median value was 200, and the standard deviation was 20. Then, 68% of the population will lie between which of given two ranges.
questions.solution:
This means that
  • 68% of all observations would have a value between 180 and 220, with the mean value of 200 being in the center.
  • Reason: Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the median. i.e. 200±20.
  • The majority of the data will be seen in the middle around the mean, and fewer observations will be seen at the extremes.
  • In a normal distribution, almost half the observations will lie on either side of the mean in a symmetrical way.
  • 95% of the observations will lie within two standard deviations, and
  • 99% of the observations will be within three standard deviations.

questions.text: In order to compare the variation in one data set with another,  what do we do
questions.solution:
The coefficient of variation (CV) is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation σ to the mean μ,
  • CV= standard deviation/ mean.
  • It shows the extent of variability in relation to the mean of the population.
  • The coefficient of variation should be computed only for data measured on scales that have a meaningful zero (ratio scale) and hence allow relative comparison of two measurements (i.e., division of one measurement by the other).
Reference: Fundamentals of Biostatistics (Rosner, Fundamentals of Biostatistics), 7th edition, Page no 20, 21.

questions.text: If one variable is known, you can determine another one by:
questions.solution:
Coefficient of regression is a statistical measure used to explain how one variable changes with respect to another.
  • It is formulated as a linear equation of the form y = mx + b, where y is the dependent variable, m is the slope or coefficient of regression, x is the independent variable, and b is the y-intercept.
  • If one variable is given, the coefficient of regression allows us to determine the slope of the linear equation and the relationship between the two variables.
  • Once the slope is determined, the equation can be used to find the other variable.
  • To do this, one must simply plug in the given value for x and solve for y. The result of this calculation should be the corresponding y-value for the given x-value.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 38.

questions.solution:
The Chi-square test is a statistical technique used to determine the relationship between two independent qualitative variables.
  • This test can be used to compare two discrete variables, such as gender or whether something occurred or not, and can tell us whether there is a connection between the variables.
  • It can be used to compare items such as race, religion, political affiliation, and educational level.
  • However, it cannot be used for continuous variables such as heart rate/min or age. For quantitative data comparison of 2 groups Student's t test is used.

choices.text: 6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.

questions.text:
Referring to the illustration, a homogenous sample was divided into 4 groups, with a 0.6 correlation coefficient between each group's weight and height.
What will be the combined overall correlation of the full group?
questions.solution:
The total will be equal to 0.6 because it comes from homogeneous samples.
 

Correlation coefficient is used to gauge how closely two variables relate to one another. 

The most common correlation coefficient is Pearson's correlation, aka Pearson's R, is frequently employed in linear regression.

  • If the correlation coefficient is 1, it means that there is a fixed proportional increase in the other variable for every increase in the positive variable. 
  • If the correlation coefficient is -1, it means that for every positive increase in one variable there is a negative decrease of fixed proportion in the other.
  • Zero indicates that there is neither a positive nor a negative rise for every increment. These two are not related.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the equivalence margin graph is/are correct?

(i) A represents Superiority of new treatment
(ii) I represents Inferiority of new treatment
(iii) E represents Non inferior treatment
(iv) C is inconclusive
questions.solution:
1. EQUIVALENCE MARGIN GRAPH



A represents Superiority of new treatment
I represents Inferiority of new treatment
E represents Non inferior treatment
C represents equivalence
 

 Equivalence Margin Graph

 

  1. Comparator Line (or Reference Line):

    • This is a central line representing the efficacy of the standard or comparator treatment.
    • It’s usually positioned at zero or at a fixed point, indicating the established baseline for comparison.

  2. Equivalence Zone (or Equivalence Margin):

    This is a range around the comparator line, bounded by upper and lower margins. It defines the range within which a new treatment is considered to have "equivalent" efficacy to the standard treatment. For example, an equivalence margin might be set as ±5 units around the comparator. If the efficacy of a new treatment falls within this range, it’s considered to be equivalently effective.
  3. Superiority and Inferiority Regions:
    • To the right of the equivalence zone is the superiority region, where treatments exceeding the comparator's efficacy are plotted.
    • To the left of the equivalence zone is the inferiority region, where treatments that are less effective than the comparator are plotted.
    • These regions help researchers see if a treatment is significantly better or worse than the comparator.
 



A superiority trial is done to show that the new drug is superior to the standard drug.
A non inferiority trial is done to show that the new drug is not worse than the standard drug.
This is done for newer interventions or drugs that may be less costly, less invasive and have fewer side effects.



Online reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24228861/

questions.text: You work at PHC as a medical officer. Transferring 50 patients with anti-hypertensive needs from the periphery to your PHC. 40 persons must take amlodipine (5mg PO). Amlodipine should not be used by 10 persons, thus they must begin using Lisinopril instead (10mg PO).PHC will receive drugs once each month. In total, how many medications will you order, and what will the reorder factor be?
questions.solution:
You may determine how many of each item you need to order by using the reorder factor, which is a numerical value. 

It calls for keeping enough product on hand to meet demand until your next reorder, as well as an extra buffer to guard against unforeseen increases in demand or delays in delivery or pickup. 

If supplies are supplied once a month, the reorder factor is 2 (1 x 2 = 2).
If supplies are delivered every three months (3 x 2 = 6), the reorder factor is 6.
If supplies are delivered every six months (6 x 2 = 12), the reorder factor is 12.

Tablet Amlodipine:40 x 1 x 30= 1200 tablets are required in a month

Tablet Lisinopril: 10 x 1 x 30 = 500 tablets are required in a month.

Total number of drugs required combined: 1500 tablets

Reorder factor for supplies delivered once a month is 2.

1500 x 2 = 3000 tablets has to be ordered in a month.


Online reference: 9. Rettig RA, Earley LE, and Merrill RA Editors. Food and Drug Administration Advisory Committees in Committee to Study the Use of Advisory Committees, Institute of Medicine;1992.

questions.text: Hb was calculated in a blood sample using a novel method. The test was run ten times. The reports were: 9.5, 9.2, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5, and 12.1. Standard tests determined that the accurate value of Hb was 10.2. The new method includes the following features:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Low validity and low reliability

RELIABILITY –
  • It signifies to the fact that a test if repeated on the same individual or material under same conditions it must give consistent results each time.
  • Also known as REPEATABILITY, REPRODUCIBILITY, PRECISION

VALIDITY –
  • It refers to what extent the test accurately measures what it is intended to measure
  • Also known as ACCURACY

In the given question ,
  • The test is repeated again and again and it’s giving different result each time. Therefore, the reliability is low
  • The test when repeated again and again the values are all haphazard and mostly not close to the actual value of 10.2 given by the standard test. Therefore, the validity or accuracy is low.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 68, 69.

questions.text: Which is the best method to compare new tests to gold standard test?
questions.solution:
Best method to compare new test and gold standard test is Bland and Altman analysis.
  • Bland-Altman analysis is a statistical method, which allows the clinician to compare two different measurement techniques.
  • Bland-Altman graph plots the difference between two techniques against their averages.
  • Typically used to compare measurement techniques against a reference value, especially when the reference value may not have a true gold standard.
Online Reference: Bland, J. M., & Altman, D. G. (1986). Statistical methods for assessing agreement between two methods of clinical measurement. The Lancet, 1(8476), 307-310. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(86)90837-8.

0.68*200= 136

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: What do the lowest mode and highest mean indicate?
questions.solution:
Highest mean and lowest mode indicates positive skewing.

Sequence of decreasing trend of central tendencies in case of positive skewed distribution is:
  • Mean>median>mode
Sequence of increasing trend of central tendencies in case of negative skewed distribution is:
  • Mean<median<mode



In both of these, the mode is simply the most frequently occurring score (the highest point on the curve); the mean is pulled up or down by the influence of a relatively small number of very high or very low scores; and the median lies between the two, dividing the distribution into two equal areas under the curve.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 9.

questions.text: What will happen if we increase the sample size in a study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Results will be more reliable

Larger studies provide stronger and more reliable results because they have smaller margins of error and lower standards of deviation. Therefore, on increasing sample size, results will be more reliable.

NOTE:
The standard error is dependent on the size of the samples: standard error is inversely related to the square root of the sample size, so that the larger n becomes, the more closely will the sample mean represent the true population mean. This is the mathematical reason why the results of large studies or surveys are more trusted than the results of small ones—a fact that is intuitively obvious.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: What is the best definition of "Urban" and "Rural," two qualitative categories into which data is divided?
questions.solution:
Option 2, "Ordinal data," is the correct answer for the given question.
  • Urban and rural are qualitative categories that are used to describe the characteristics of a geographical area. Urban areas are typically densely populated areas with a high concentration of buildings, businesses, and infrastructure. In contrast, rural areas are sparsely populated areas with a low concentration of buildings and infrastructure.
  • Ordinal data is a type of data that can be ranked or ordered, but the differences between the values are not necessarily equal. In the case of the given question, "urban" and "rural" are qualitative categories that can be ranked based on their level of urbanization. However, the difference between the two categories is not necessarily equal.
  • Therefore, the best definition for "urban" and "rural" is "ordinal data."
  • To further clarify, here are brief definitions of other types of data: - Normal data: A type of data that follows a normal distribution, also known as a bell curve. 
  • Interval data: A type of data that has equal intervals between values, but there is no true zero point.
  • Ratio data: A type of data that has equal intervals between values and a true zero point.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 3.

questions.text: What is the name of the combination of two variables described by a common third factor?

  • SPURIOUS ASSOCIATION -  An observed association between a disease and suspected factor may not be real.
  • INDIRECT ASSOCIATION – It is a statistical association between a characteristic variable and disease due to the presence of another factor.
  • DIRECT ASSOCIATION –
    • ONE TO ONE CAUSAL RELATIONSHIP- Two variables are causally related if a change in one  variable is followed by a change in the other variable.
    • MULTIFACTORIAL RELATIONSHIP- When multiple factors are involved specially in case of non communicable diseases, a common event can be produced by each factors and that is also considered as a causal factor.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 95.
