questions.text: Methods used to describe collection of data are included under?
questions.solution:
The methods used to describe a collection of data are included under "Descriptive Statistics" (Option 3). Descriptive statistics involve organizing, summarizing, and presenting data in a meaningful way. This includes measures such as central tendency (mean, median, mode), measures of dispersion (range, variance, standard deviation), graphical representations (histograms, bar charts, scatter plots), and other techniques that provide a summary and description of the data.

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 78 .

questions.text: Two doctors examined 200 CXR. The Kappa statistic was found to be 0.71. What is the inference?
questions.solution:
Kappa Coefficent -
0.8-1.0- Perfect
0.61-0.8 - Good
0.41-0.60- Moderate
0.21-0.4- Fair agreement
0.1-0.20- Slight agreement.

Reference: McHugh ML. Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic. Biochem Med (Zagreb). 2012;22(3):276-82. PMID: 23092060; PMCID: PMC3900052.

questions.text: Identify the graph given below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a line graph, which is a type of graph used to visualize trends over time by connecting individual data points with a continuous line.

Explanation:

A line graph is typically used to depict changes in a variable over a continuous period, making it ideal for showing trends, patterns, and fluctuations. The x-axis usually represents the independent variable (e.g., years, time periods), while the y-axis represents the dependent variable (e.g., population, growth rate). In this graph, the data points are connected with a blue line, demonstrating the trend in population changes over time.

Other options

  • Histogram – A histogram is used to represent frequency distributions, where data is grouped into ranges (bins) and displayed as adjacent bars. Since this graph does not contain bars or frequency intervals, it is not a histogram.

  • Frequency Polygon – A frequency polygon is a graphical representation of a histogram that uses a line to connect midpoints of class intervals. Since this graph does not represent frequency distributions, it is not a frequency polygon.

  • Trellis Line Graph – A trellis line graph is a type of visualization where multiple small line graphs are arranged in a grid to compare multiple groups or categories. This image contains only a single line graph, so it does not fit this definition.

choices.text: Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for descriptors of central tendency except:
questions.solution:
The mode is not influenced by extreme values in a data set.

The mean, however, is sensitive to every value in the distribution. Therefore, it is the measure of central tendency most affected by extreme values (option B). The mean is typically not appropriate for describing skewed distributions, but it tends to remain stable across repeated samples from the same population. Compared to the mode or median, the mean is less prone to fluctuations between different samples from the same population.

To find the median, the data must be arranged in ascending or descending order, and the middle value is selected. This process requires considering the entire data set before the median can be determined (option C).

The mode is the most frequently occurring value in a frequency distribution. It is not affected by extreme values and can also be used to describe qualitative data (option D).

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 943 .

questions.text: The formula given in the image corresponds to-
questions.solution:
The formula given above is used to calculate the standard deviation.

Standard deviation (or o) is a measure of how dispersed the data is in relation to the mean. Data clustered around the mean have a low standard deviation, while data that are more spread out have a high standard deviation. A standard deviation close to zero indicates that data points are close to the mean, whereas a high or low standard deviation indicates data points are respectively above or below the mean.

Variance (option B) is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution. It is numerically equal to the square of the standard deviation.

Mean (option C) is obtained by adding together the individual observations and then dividing by the total number of observations.

Median (option D) divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores.


 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 943,944 .

questions.text: All of the following may be used to find the normalcy of data except:
questions.solution:
The Mantel-Haenszel method is used to calculate the adjusted odds ratio during stratified analysis, not to assess the normalcy of data.

A histogram and a box whisker plot are visual tools to evaluate if a dataset follows a normal distribution. A normal distribution curve is a type of histogram.

However, visual representations alone may not be sufficient to determine normality. This is where the Shapiro-Wilk test comes into play. It assesses how closely a dataset fits a normal distribution. The test first orders and standardizes the sample data, then evaluates how the sample quantiles align with standard normal quantiles. The Shapiro-Wilk test is particularly useful for small sample sizes.

Stratified analysis is performed to minimize confounding. In such cases, multiple odds ratios are generated for each data stratum. These are then combined to produce an adjusted odds ratio, reflecting the exposure‘s effect after accounting for the confounding factor. The Mantel-Haenszel method is used to achieve this adjustment.



Reference : Essential Edidemiology : An Introduction For Students and health Professionals,  Page no 464,465 .

questions.text: In Kaplan Meier survival curve, the bands used for the confidence interval is?
questions.solution:
• The Hall-Wellner bands are used for confidence intervals in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve.
  • When employing standard statistical software, the upper and lower confidence interval limits are calculated at each time point.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, along with Gill bands and Nair‘s Equal Precision confidence bands, are commonly used for this purpose.
 
  • The Kaplan-Meier plot visually represents the number of individuals surviving over a specific time period. Typically, the plot displays two or more groups, such as treated versus untreated individuals.
  • The graph consists of steps, as survival is a discrete variable. The image below illustrates a Kaplan-Meier plot, with dotted lines indicating the upper and lower bounds of the 95% confidence interval



Reference: Sachs, M.C., Brand, A. & Gabriel, E.E. Confidence bands in survival analysis. Br J Cancer 127, 1636–1641 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41416-022-01920-5. URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41416-022-01920-5

questions.text: The urban area of Delhi has 4000 population with different religions. Research is being done to study the dietary habits of the population. Which of the following techniques can be used to obtain a study sample?
questions.solution:
In this vignette, the researcher aims to conduct a dietary survey on a population with individuals from various religions (heterogeneous population). By stratifying the sample based on religion and selecting a specified number of participants from each religious group, the final sample will accurately represent individuals from all religions, ensuring comprehensive and unbiased results.

Such a sampling process where, a heterogenous population is subdivided into homogenous subgroups (In this case based on religion) and then samples are drawn from each subgroup is known as stratified random sampling.

This sampling process enables adequate representation of all stratas of the population adequately, and therefore Stratified random sampling is the most appropriate method for this study.

Other Options:

questions.text: Calculate the dependency ratio in the given family. Mr J, age 70 years, Mrs J age 60, their son's age 32 years, his wife's age is 30 years and grandson is 5 years old.
questions.solution:
The dependency ratio for this family will be 66.6%.
The dependence ratio is the percentage of people below 15 and above 65 years by the number of people between 15-65 years. Ref - Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition • Page No:565

questions.text: Which of the following is the correlation coefficient (R) of the given scattergram?
questions.solution:
The given scattergram demonstrates a strong positive correlation between X and Y Variables. A scattergram is a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along the two axes. Each point on the graph signifies a pair of values from the same observation. The pattern of the resulting points reveals if any correlation exists. A scattergram with positive correlation (R-value > 0) means high values of one variable are associated with high values of another variable. One with a negative correlation (R-value < 0) means high values of one variable are associated with low values of the other variable. In strong positive correlation R- value will be >0 and <1 but closer to 1 than 0
In strong negative correlation R- value will be <0 and >-1 but closer to -1 than 0.              

Ref- High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health - 4th Edition • Page No 36,37

questions.text: In a normal curve, what is the percentage of the distribution that falls within two standard deviation of the mean?
questions.solution:
In a normal curve, the area on either side of the mean will include :
Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within +1 standard deviations of the mean.
Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within 2 standard deviations of the mean.
Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within +3 standard deviations of the mean.

Ref- Biostatistics, epidemiology and public health 4th edition Page 11-12

questions.text: Endemic goitre is generally found in iodine deficient high altitudes, thereby showing an association between altitude and endemic goitre. This is an example of which kind of relationship?
questions.solution:
Endemic goitre occurs due to iodine deficiency and iodine deficiency is seen in high altitude states. Thus iodine deficiency is a common factor for both goitre and high altitude states resulting in an apparent association between two variables, when no association exists. This is hence an example of indirect association.
Indirect association is an association between a variable and disease due to the presence of another factor, known or unknown, that is also known as the "confounding" variable.
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition • Page nos 95, 96

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between the occurrence of cancer and pollution levels in their environment. He chose a district with a large number of factories and collected data on cancer in the native population from the district hospitals and the local health centers. What is this type of study known as?
questions.solution:
Correlation study is a type of analytical study which analyzes the health status and its relation with other variables. It is also called ecological study and it uses population as a unit of study.

Ref- Park textbook of PSM 25th edition page 70

questions.text:
A study is conducted to identify the association between smoking and the development of lung cancer in a community. Based on the data, 12 smokers and 24 non smokers developed lung cancer . Calculate the relative risk for this community.
Developed lung cancer Did not develop lung cancer Total
smokers  12  88  100
non smokers  24  76  100
questions.solution:
Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study.
Relative risk = incidence of lung cancer among smokers / incidence of lung cancer among non smokers
In the given case relative risk =0.5.
  •  RR = 1 indicates no association.
  •  RR >1 indicate increased risk of outcome.
  •  RR <1 indicate reduced risk of outcome.

Ref- High Yield Biostatistics, epidemiology and Public health 4th edition page 53-54

questions.text: In a study about the age of a small population, the highest value 36 was mistakenly recorded as 63. What will happen to the mean and median of the data?
questions.solution:
• Mean is sensitive to extreme values. Recording 36 as 63 will increase the total sum, so the mean increases.

  • Median is the middle value when data is ordered. Since only the highest value was changed and the position of the middle value(s) does not change, the median remains the same.

Other options:

  • Neither mean nor median will increase: Incorrect, mean will increase.

  • Both mean and median will increase: Incorrect, median remains unchanged.

  • Median will increase, mean will remain the same: Incorrect, mean is affected, median is not.


Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - Page no 943

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about "Awareness regarding Pap smear". They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution:
The relationship between the mean, median, and mode in a favorably skewed data set is as follows: mean > median > mode. The only choice that is consistent with the criterion mean > median > mode is for the mean, median, and mode in this instance to be 25, 23, and 20, respectively.

The value that appears the most frequently in the data collection is represented by the mode. A distribution is referred to as bimodal if two values have the same greatest frequency. A distribution is deemed multimodal if more than two values occur with the same greatest frequency.

When values are sorted in order, the median is the value that splits the data set in half evenly. When the number of values is even, the median is determined by

Reference:High yield biostatistics epidemiology and public health 4th edition page no 8,9

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small, uneducated village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
Pictogram
• Pictograms are a visually engaging way to present information
• These are meant to convey data to the ‘man in the street’ who finds it difficult to comprehend complex charts
• Small pictures or symbols are used to present the data
• The number of pictures is proportional to the frequency size
• One picture depicts a fixed number
• A fraction of a picture can be used to represent a smaller number
• Pictograms are not effective for visualizing large sets of data.

questions.solution:
Window period:
  • Time between first infection & when the test can reliably detect that infection.

Incubation period:
  • Time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease in question.

questions.text: Tuberculin testing is a low-cost and widely available test. Which of the following scenarios has a high failure rate in test interpretation?
questions.solution:
When there is a high percentage of immunized people in the population due to a high BCG coverage rate, there is a significant failure rate in the interpretation of the tuberculin test.

The tuberculin test has lost its sensitivity as a gauge of the true prevalence of infection in nations with high BCG coverage, which also results in tuberculin hypersensitivity.

Atypical mycobacteria infection and the "boosting effect" of a second dosage of tuberculin eliciting a stronger reaction than the first could both overstate the genuine prevalence rates of infection.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 216.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is cured with the following treatment?
questions.solution:
For both multibacillary and paucibacillary leprosy, WHO has created blister pack medicine kits.
 
  • The single lesion paucibacillary leprosy blister pack medicine kit comes with everything needed to administer the three drugs just once. 
  • Any patient who has a positive skin smear must get the MDT multibacillary leprosy treatment regimen.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses' life cycles is most similar to the one described below?
questions.solution:
The figure quite clearly depicts that the life cycle shown is that of the Japanese Encephalitis Virus.
  • In contrast to the other choices described above, humans are dead ends and incidental hosts in the life cycle of these viruses.
  • Humans, cattle and horses are dead-end hosts as the disease manifests as fatal encephalitis.
  • Swine play a crucial part in the epidemiology of the disease by acting as an amplifying host.
  • Infection in swine is usually asymptomatic.
  • The most significant vector is the Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which prefers to feed on cattle as compared to humans.

questions.text: What is the duration of the measles isolation period?
questions.solution:
Period of isolation for measles is from onset of catarrhal symptoms to 7 days after onset of rash.
Individuals diagnosed with measles should be isolated during this period to prevent the spread of the virus, especially to those who are unvaccinated or have weakened immune systems.
 
The period of communicability of measles is 3 days before and 3 days after the appearance of rash.

questions.text: Which other disease also uses droplets as a means of transmission and requires isolation, like TB?

  • The role of fomites in the spread of the infection appears to be very small, unless they are freshly contaminated.
  • When an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, tiny droplets containing the bacteria can be released into the air. People nearby can inhale these droplets and become infected.

questions.text: Sputum samples for TB testing, according to RNTCP, are placed in two containers with the following labels:
questions.solution:
The sputum samples are labeled with a serial number and a suffix A/B with regard to the spot/morning samples respectively.
  • Early morning specimen is always labelled as "B”, while the first spot specimen is labeled as "A”,
  • It is important to label sputum containers properly.
  • Sputum containers should always be labeled on the side, and never on the lid, as the lid from one container may be placed on another container resulting is specimens being labeled incorrectly.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 214.

questions.text: How many days must pass after acute flaccid paralysis in order to detect any residual weakness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 60 days

60 days after the onset of clinical symptoms the patients with acute flaccid paralysis are evaluated to detect the presence of any residual weakness.

Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) is an infectious disease caused by a number of viruses, including poliovirus.
  • Due to the dangerous nature of the virus, AFP surveillance is conducted by health departments all over the world to monitor for and prevent transmission.
 
  • As part of an AFP surveillance program, all cases of AFP are re-evaluated for residual paralysis at 60 days, to determine whether or not the paralysis was caused by poliovirus.
 
  • This helps health departments determine whether or not a given outbreak is ongoing or has ceased.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 242.

questions.text: The following descriptions of the annual rate of infection (ARI) for tuberculosis are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 1% ARI corresponds 75 new cases of smear positive TB per 100,00 population

ANNUAL INFECTION RATE :-
  • It is defined as the percentage of population under study who will be newly infected by tuberculosis among the non infected during the course of 1 year.
  • It is the annual risk of getting infected in a given community.
  • It is also known as ‘ TUBERCULIN CONVERSION INDEX ‘
  • 1% annual risk of infection corresponds to 50 new smear positive cases of pulmonary TB per 100,000 general population
  • It is one of the best parameters for evaluating the tuberculosis problem and its trend.
  • The higher is the rate the higher is the problem.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: The ESI Act's extended sickness compensation for tuberculosis is
questions.solution:
The Employees’ State Insurance (ESI) Act provides extended sickness benefit for tuberculosis.

  • This benefit is provided as an extension of the benefit covered under the Act of 1948.
  • Under this benefit, a patient suffering from tuberculosis is entitled to full payment of medical expenses, along with temporary disability benefit and up to two years of extended sickness benefit allowance.
  • During the extended sickness benefit period, the claimant may be eligible to receive up to forty percent of the pay which the insurer would have earned during the same period.
  • Additionally, the insurer may be entitled to a re-imbursement of up to twenty percent of the remaining sixty percent of the wages.
  • The extended sickness benefit also includes a subsistence allowance of up to one hundred and seventy five rupees per day for up to two years, and a cumulative sum of up to Rupees twenty five thousand for hospital dues.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 944.

questions.text: If prospective screening is carried out, what is the case?
questions.solution:
Prospective screening refers to the practice of examining individuals within a population in order to identify those who may have a certain condition or disease.

  • This form of screening has been used in public health strategies since the 1800s as a way to detect, prevent and/or treat a range of conditions, including cancer, infection and infectious diseases.
  • Screening allows potential issues to be detected and treated earlier than they would be without screening, enabling better outcomes and reduced mortality rates due to the condition.
  • It also helps reduce the spread of infectious diseases, as those identified can be treated and prevented from passing it on to others used in immigration.
  • Screening programs are often the first line of defense in identifying, diagnosing and treating health conditions, before further treatment is required.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 152.

questions.text:
Malarial Vector indices is included in which of the following
a. Human blood index
b. Biting density 
c. Slide positivity rate
d. Inoculation rate
questions.solution:
Malarial Vector indices
 
  • The average number of anopheline bites per day per person is known as the man biting rate (biting density). Standardized vector catch on human bait is used to determine it.
  • The percentage of female anopheles with one sporozoite in their saliva is known as the sporozoite rate.
  • Inoculation rate: This is calculated by multiplying the rate of man-biting by the rate of infectious sporozoites.
  • The percentage of freshly fed female anopheline mosquitoes whose stomachs contain human blood is known as the human blood index. It reveals the anthrophilism's level.
  • Mosquito density: This term is typically represented as the quantity of mosquitoes caught per hour of labour.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 307.

choices.text: 1 to 5 years is high risk age group
Virus shedding present before the patient present with symptoms

questions.text: Which is not true for influenza virus
questions.solution:
Secondary attack rate is 5 to 15%: This statement refers to the percentage of people who become infected after being exposed to an infected individual.
  • For influenza, the secondary attack rate typically ranges from 10% to 30%, so this statement is generally accurate.
 
  • 1 to 5 years is a high-risk age group: Young children, particularly those aged 6 months to 5 years, are considered a high-risk group for severe influenza complications. This statement is accurate.
 
  • Virus shedding present before the patient presents with symptoms: Influenza virus shedding can begin 1-2 days before symptoms appear, which is why the virus is highly contagious even before symptoms manifest. This statement is accurate.
 
  • Aquatic birds are reservoirs: Aquatic birds, particularly wild ducks and shorebirds, are indeed the natural reservoirs of influenza A viruses. This statement is accurate.
Given this analysis, all the statements are true, except for the potential nuance in the secondary attack rate, which might vary slightly depending on the context. However, the generally accepted secondary attack rate range for influenza does fall within the 5% to 15% range.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 172.

choices.text: To reduce the disease so that it is not a public health problem

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: To reduce the disease so that it is not a public health problem

A FEW IMPORTANT DEFINITIONS REGARDING DISEASE TRANSMISSION OF MALARIA WHICH ARE FREQUENTLY ASKED ARE :-
 
  • MALARIA CONTROL – It is defined as the reduction in the malaria disease burden so that it is no longer a public health problem.
  • MALARIA ELIMINATION – It is defined as the reduction in the mosquito borne malaria transmission.
  • MALARIA ERADICATION – It is defined as the permanent reduction in the worldwide incidence of the disease to zero.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 302.

questions.text: Intensified malaria control under the national framework for malaria elimination is done for :
questions.solution:
The national framework for eliminating malaria has the following goals:
 
  • By 2022, all 26 states that have cat 1, cat 2 or cat 3 status in 2014; Stop malaria transmission and No indigenous cases.
  • In all Indian states, malaria incidence will be less than 1 cases per 1,000 people by 2024.
  • indigenous transmission will be stopped in all Indian states by 2027.
  • malaria would be eradicated and re-establishment avoided by 2030.
      
  • States with API more than or equal to 1:  Technically speaking, this definition of intensified malaria control in a region is correct.
  • Zero incidence of malaria: Malaria incidence must be lessened rather than eliminated.
  • No longer a health problem: No, by 2024, the incidence will be fewer than 1/1000 cases.
  • 3 consecutive years no local transmission in the state: may be correct, but the criteria of 3 years are not true.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest death rate after clinical manifestation?
questions.solution:
• Rabies has the highest death rate after clinical manifestation. Once clinical symptoms of rabies appear, the disease is almost universally fatal. Despite the availability of a vaccine and post-exposure prophylaxis, untreated rabies leads to death in nearly 100% of cases after symptoms develop.
  • Ebola: While Ebola has a high mortality rate (ranging from 25% to 90%, depending on the outbreak and healthcare availability), it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies after clinical symptoms appear.
 
  • Nipah: Nipah virus infection also has a high mortality rate, which can range from 40% to 75%, but it is still not as high as rabies after symptoms manifest.
 
  • Zika: Zika virus typically causes mild illness, and the death rate associated with Zika is very low compared to the other viruses listed.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 322.

questions.text:
To whom does the following life cycle belong
   
a. Leptospirosis
b. Yersinia pestis
c. Hanta virus
d. Salmonella typhi
questions.solution:
Given life cycle belongs to Leptospirosis.
 
  • Transmission is through water or food contaminated with animal urine.
  • Life cycle shows transmission from rodent carrier with the organism being expelled in its urine, from where it contaminates the mud and soil present nearby. Then it gets consumed by Mammalian reservoirs, including cows and humans, which then excrete the free living leptospira which are then picked up by the rodents.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 338.

choices.text: Start ART and add ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and add ART after 2 weeks

questions.text: Determine the ideal course of action for a patient who has been diagnosed with both HIV and TB?
questions.solution:
Due to immunological suppression, HIV infection increases the likelihood that a new M. tuberculosis infection will develop into TB illness quickly.
Start TB treatment first, followed by ART as soon as possible after starting TB treatment within the first 8 weeks of treatment to prevent IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome), which occurs due to immune response from dead HIV viral proteins. 
 

HIV-positive TB patients with profound immunosuppression (e.g., CD4+ < 50/μl) should receive ART within the first two weeks of initiating TB treatment.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 235.

questions.text: Which form of disinfection involves cleaning a cholera patient's faeces?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Concurrent

CONCURRENT DISINFECTION :-
  • Concurrent disinfection is the immediate disinfection of all contaminated articles and body discharges during the course of the disease
  • It is done immediately, then and there during the course of illness.
  • It includes cleaning the isolation unit daily with effective disinfectant
TERMINAL DISINFECTION :-
  • Terminal disinfection means disinfection of the patients unit and all the articles used after the discharge, transfer or death of the patient who was suffering from the contagious disease
  • It is done after the patient has recovered from a communicable disease or has died after suffering from a communicable disease.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 275.

questions.text: The recommended pre-exposure prophylaxis schedule for Rabies in high risk individuals like veterinarians is
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  3 doses on day 0, 7, 21
 

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for rabies involves administering a series of vaccinations to individuals at risk of exposure to rabies virus, such as veterinarians, animal handlers, and travellers to rabies-endemic areas.
The standard PrEP regimen for rabies vaccination typically involves a 3-dose schedule administered over a period of time.
As per the NCDC - Guidelines for Rabies-pre exposure prophylaxis should be done with two doses on day 0,7 and a booster dose either on day 21/28. (Total 3 doses).

Individuals who have received successful pre-exposure rabies immunization require only two booster doses of the vaccine on days 0 and 3 if exposed to RABV. Administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is not necessary.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 326.
https://ncdc.mohfw.gov.in/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Guidelines-for-Rabies-Prophylaxis.pdf

questions.text: Identify the mosquito that is considered as the most sophisticated.
questions.solution:
The Anopheles mosquito is often considered one of the most sophisticated due to
  • its role as the primary vector for malaria,
  • a complex and highly adaptive parasite.
  • specialized behaviors and adaptations that make it particularly effective at transmitting the disease, such as night-biting habits and
  • a preference for biting humans, making it a highly efficient vector.

questions.text: Exception to transmission of infection by Vectors is-
questions.solution:
Ingestion is not a typical mode of transmission for vector-borne diseases.

Vector-borne transmission typically occurs through mechanisms such as
  • regurgitation (where the vector, like a mosquito, regurgitates infectious agents into the host while feeding),
  • rubbing of infected feces (as seen with some insect-borne diseases like Chagas disease), or 
  • contamination with body fluids.


Ingestion refers to the consumption of contaminated food or water and is not how vectors typically transmit infections.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 106.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a non deliberate cultural practice leading to anti-mosquito effect:
questions.solution:
Use of alkaline detergent is considered a non-deliberate cultural practice that can have an anti-mosquito effect because 
 
  • it can kill mosquito larvae or
  • reduce mosquito breeding sites by altering the pH of water sources.   


The other options (larvicidal agents, bed nets, and repellents) are deliberate and intentional methods used to control mosquito populations or prevent bites.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: All of the following factors are responsible for resurgence of malaria, Except:
questions.solution:
Use of bed nets actually helps in reducing malaria transmission by protecting people from mosquito bites, especially at night.

The resurgence of malaria is mainly due to
  • drug resistance in the parasite,
  • insecticide resistance in vectors, and
  • antigenic mutations in the parasite that help it evade the immune response.


Thus, bed nets are a preventive measure, not a factor in the resurgence.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 311.

  • Yellow fever is endemic in parts of Africa and South America, but not in India.

choices.text: Hepatorenal syndrome may occur in upto 50% of patients

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about leptospirosis ?
questions.solution:
Rats are indeed the prime reservoirs of Leptospira,the bacteria that cause leptospirosis.

The other statements are incorrect:
  • fluoroquinolones are not the first-line treatment(doxycycline or penicillin is more commonly used). Doxycycline is the DOC. 
  • person-to-person transmission is very rare, and
  • hepatorenal syndrome does not occur in up to 50% of patients—though it can occur in severe cases, it's not that common.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 338.

choices.text: Late stages of yaws involve heart and nerves

questions.text: What is not true about 'yaws'?
questions.solution:
Option 4, "Late stages of yaws involve heart and nerves," is not true.
  • The late stages of yaws involve bone and joint destruction, but do not typically involve the heart or nerves.
  • However, it should be noted that if yaws is left untreated, it can progress to a more severe form of the disease called tertiary yaws, which can affect multiple organs including the heart and nervous system.
  • Yaws is a chronic bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum pertenue.
  • The disease is transmitted through direct contact with the skin of an infected person, typically during childhood.
  • The infection causes lesions on the skin, bones, and cartilage, which can lead to disfigurement and disability if left untreated.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 390.

questions.text: As per Mc Keown's theory, rate of mortality deduction from Tuberculosis was result of -
questions.solution:
In a 1962 article, Mc Keown concluded that “the rise of population was due primarily to the decline of mortality and the most important reason for the decline was an improvement in economic and social conditions.”
Among these conditions, the most significant was improved diet.

Online reference: https://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/full/10.2105/AJPH.92.5.730

questions.text: About the mosquito Anopheles, all of the following are true, except:
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1. "Eggs have no floats". 
1. Eggs have no floats - This statement is incorrect. Anopheles mosquito eggs have floats, which help them to float on the water surface. The floats are made up of a gelatinous material and are attached to the sides of the egg. These floats enable the eggs to survive in water bodies such as ponds, lakes, and puddles.
2. Larvae rest parallel to water surface - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito larvae rest parallel to the water surface. They breathe through a tube called a siphon, which they use to obtain air from the surface of the water.
3. Rudimentary siphon tube - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito larvae have a rudimentary siphon tube, which they use to obtain air from the surface of the water.
4. Spotted wings - This statement is true. Anopheles mosquito wings have spots. The spots are a characteristic feature of the mosquito and can be used to identify the species. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 895.

questions.text: What kind of mosquito is referred to as the "tiger mosquito"?
questions.solution:
The Aedes mosquito, particularly Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is commonly known as the "tiger mosquito" due to the distinct black and white striped pattern on its body and legs, resembling a tiger's stripes.
  • These mosquitoes are vectors for several diseases, including dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  • Aedes aegypti is more common in urban areas and is a primary vector for dengue fever.
  • Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is more adaptable to different environments and can spread the same diseases as Aedes aegypti.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 897.

questions.text: Among the following, which is a live vaccine?
questions.solution:
Live attenuated vaccines-
  • Oral Sabin polio vaccine,
  • MRV Vaccine (Measles, Mumps, Rubella, and Varicella),
  • Nasal influenza vaccine,
  • Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG) vaccine,
  • Varicella vaccine,
  • Rotavirus vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: The period of quarantine for asymptomatic contacts of a cholera patient should be:
questions.solution:
The period of quarantine for asymptomatic contacts of a cholera patient is typically 5 days.
  • This period is chosen based on the incubation period of the cholera bacterium, Vibrio cholerae, which is usually between 2 to 5 days.
  • Quarantining contacts for 5 days helps ensure that if they were exposed and became infected, they would show symptoms within this time frame, thus preventing further spread of the disease.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 273.

questions.text: A patient was having productive cough since 4 weeks. He was diagnosed as a case of pulmonary TB and was started on ATT under National TB elimination Program. He took all the medications timely and after completion of intensive and continuation phase, both of his sputum smear tested negative for AFB. Patient status is:
questions.solution:
• Presence of negative sputum at the end of treatment implies status of patient as cured. 
 
  • Option 2- Treatment completed- A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that his sputum smear or culture is negative. 




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 188, 191, 193, 201.

questions.text: A person had a history of travelling to African country. Following his return after 3 days, he developed fever, headache, body ache, jaundice, and hemorrhagic manifestations. Despite treatment, he died. Vaccine of which of the following strain, if give prophylactically, could have saved him from dying:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is of Yellow fever. 
 
  • People travelling to yellow fever endemic regions should receive yellow fever vaccine which is a live vaccine based on 17D strain. 
 
  • The validity of vaccine begins 10 days post vaccination and continues lifelong.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 328, 329.

choices.text: Removing stray dogs and vaccinating all pet-dogs
Administer Rabies vaccine to the general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a cost-effective and rational approach for controlling Rabies in an urban area?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the most cost effective and rational approach for controlling rabies is to reduce the stray dog population and vaccinating all pet dogs. 

Rabies is caused by Lyssavirus type 1 and carries a mortality rate of ~100%. 
 
  • Testing all the dogs for Rabies: This is not practical or cost-effective because rabies testing requires euthanizing animals for laboratory diagnosis. Testing every dog is neither scalable nor humane.
  • Increase lab facilities: While this can improve rabies diagnostics, it is not a direct or cost-effective measure for controlling rabies. Priority should be given to prevention (dog vaccination and population management) over expanded lab facilities.
  • Removing stray dogs and vaccinating all pet dogs: This approach addresses the primary source of rabies transmission—unvaccinated dogs. Vaccinating at least 70% of the dog population (both stray and pet) is the cornerstone of rabies control, as dogs are the main reservoir of the virus in urban areas.
  • Administer Rabies vaccine to the general population: This is unnecessary and prohibitively expensive. Providing post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) to those bitten by potentially rabid animals is a more cost-effective and rational alternative.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 302, 303, 307.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hand sanitizer cannot be used?
questions.solution:
• If hands are visibly soiled then washing with soap and water for at least 60 seconds is recommended.
  • Hand sanitizers are effective in reducing microbial load on hands in most situations, but they are not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with organic matter (e.g., dirt, blood, or bodily fluids).
  • In such cases, washing hands with soap and water is necessary.

Other options:
 
  1. Before examining a patient: Hand sanitizer can be used to disinfect hands.
  2. After examining a patient: Hand sanitizer is appropriate to reduce potential contamination.
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings: Hand sanitizer can be used effectively in this situation as well.



Reference: Hand sanitizer Guidelines and Recommendations, CDC guidelines. URL: https://www.cdc.gov/clean-hands/about/hand-sanitizer.html#:~:text=Don't%20use%20hand%20sanitizer,with%20soap%20and%20water%20instead.

questions.text:
Dog bite with bleeding from affected bite. What are the correct statements? 
(i) Inject vaccines -0, 3,7,14, 28 days 
(ii) Clean with soap for 10 mins 
(iii) Single dose of equine rabies IG given 40 IU/kg 
(iv) Suture the wound 
(v) Category 3 wound
questions.solution:
1. (i) Inject vaccines - 0, 3, 7, 14, 28 days
    Correct. For Category 3 bites (high-risk, bleeding wounds), the rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) schedule involves vaccinations on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28. (IM regime)

  2. (ii) Clean with soap for 10 minutes
    Correct. Washing the wound thoroughly with soap and water for 10-15 minutes is critical for reducing viral contamination and the risk of rabies transmission.

  3. (iii) Single dose of equine rabies IG given 40 IU/kg
    Correct. For Category 3 wounds, a single dose of equine rabies immunoglobulin (ERIG) at 40 IU/kg is administered, primarily infiltrating the wound site with the remaining dose given intramuscularly.

  4. (iv) Suture the wound
    Incorrect. Suturing is typically not recommended for rabies-prone wounds as it may trap the virus. If necessary, delayed suturing is performed after wound treatment and RIG administration.

  5. (v) Category 3 wound
    Correct. A dog bite that results in bleeding is classified as a Category 3 wound, requiring immediate PEP (vaccination and immunoglobulin).


     

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 324-326.

questions.text: This Kit is used for treatment of which disease?
questions.solution:
This is a kit used for treatment of malaria.

Components:
 
  • Artemisinin Derivative: A fast-acting drug that rapidly reduces the parasite load.
  • Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine (SP): A slow-acting partner drug that eliminates residual parasites and prevents resistance development.

Indications:
 
  • Primarily used in areas with Plasmodium falciparum malaria where resistance to other therapies is common.
  • Often employed in regions where SP retains efficacy.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 308-310.

questions.text: A patient with satellite skin lesion presents to the hospital. He also has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The treatment best suited would be?
questions.solution:
It is a case of Leprosy with 1 hypo-pigmented Lesion and 1 thickened Nerve making it a paucibacillary leprosy case and the treatment would be multi-drug therapy for 6 months. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 366 .

questions.text: Endogenous transmission of which of the following disease is found in India?
questions.solution:
• Endogenous transmission of Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is found in India (Option 2).
 
  • CCHF is a viral disease caused by the Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus. Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks (Genus Hyalomma)
  • In India, the presence of CCHF was confirmed for the first time in Gujarat as a nosocomial outbreak in 2011. Since then, multiple outbreaks/sporadic cases have been reported from different districts of Gujarat. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 520, 531, 562, 661.

questions.text:
A woman has 2 children- Ram and Shyam. One fine day Shyam developed measles having fever with rash. After 4 days of this, Ram also developed the same symptom complex. Ram was then reported to the village sub-center. Which among the following is the correct statement? 
(i) Ram is the index case 
(ii) Shyamm is the primary case 
(iii) Ram got infected by Shyam 
(iv) If the mother had reported when Shyam got infected, Ram could have been vaccinated.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are : (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Explanation:

1. Ram is the index case because he was the first case to be reported to the health authorities. 
2. Shyam is the primary case because he was the first to develop measles symptoms.
3. Ram got infected by Shyam because he developed the same symptoms after Shyam.
4. If the mother had reported when Shyam got infected, Ram could have been vaccinated, which would have potentially prevented him from getting infected.

Therefore, option 4 is the correct answer.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 164-168.

questions.text: A patient came with a clean, non-lacerated wound. He has received a full course of TT vaccination more than 10 years ago. What will you do now?
questions.solution:
A clean, non-lacerated wound can be categorized as a “not tetanus-prone” wound.

  • In a patient with a previous history of a complete course of TT vaccination taken >10 years back, the appropriate management of this wound shall be to administer a single dose of TT.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 2nd Edition, Page. No- 273.

questions.text: Identify the disease transmitted by vector shown below?
questions.solution:
The following image is Trombiculid mite which causes Scrub Typhus.
Causative agent is Orientia tsutsugamushi.
It also causes Rickettsial Pox.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page. No- 906.

questions.text: A worker in a sugarcane factory is at risk of developing?
questions.solution: • A person working in a sugarcane factory is at risk of developing Bagassosis. This respiratory condition is caused by the inhalation of dust from bagasse, which is the fibrous residue left after extracting juice from sugarcane. Prolonged exposure can lead to lung inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in symptoms such as coughing, shortness of breath, and other respiratory issues. Proper protective measures and workplace safety protocols are essential to mitigate this risk.

questions.text:
An HIV-positive patient has the following serology results. What is the management of this patient?
Markers Result ;
HBsAg: Positive. Anti-HBc: Positive. IgM Anti-HBC :Positive. Anti-HBs: Negative
questions.solution:
The patient is HIV-positive and has acute hepatitis B infection based on serology:

  • HBsAg: Positive

  • Anti-HBc: Positive

  • IgM anti-HBc: Positive (indicates acute infection)

  • Anti-HBs: Negative

Key points for management:

  1. HIV/HBV co-infection: Therapy must cover both viruses.

  2. Drugs active against both HIV and HBV:

    • Tenofovir (TDF or TAF)

    • Lamivudine (3TC)

    • Emtricitabine (FTC)

Recommended regimen:

  • Tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir is a preferred first-line ART in HIV/HBV co-infection.

  • Avoid using only lamivudine or emtricitabine monotherapy for HBV due to rapid resistance.

  • Nevirapine is hepatotoxic and not preferred in acute hepatitis B.

  • Abacavir has no activity against HBV.

  • Efavirenz-based regimens are acceptable, but dolutegravir-based regimens are preferred due to better efficacy and safety.

Hence, the correct management is Tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir.

questions.text: A person had a dog bite. Vaccination is up to date for both the dog and the man. The person‘s history is significant for having undergone splenectomy five years ago. What is the best management in this case?
questions.solution:
• Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) is the preferred antibiotic for this patient.

Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in the following cases:
 
  • High-risk animal bites: This includes cat bites at any location and bites to the hand from any animal, including humans. Cat and human bites have a higher risk of infection compared to dog bites. Hand bites, in particular, are prone to infections due to the closed spaces within the hand.
 
  • High-risk patients: Individuals with comorbidities such as diabetes, liver disease, or asplenia (lack of a functional spleen) are at greater risk. Those without a functional spleen are especially vulnerable to overwhelming sepsis, particularly from Capnocytophaga species.
 
  • Pasteurella species is the most common pathogen found in cat and dog bites while Streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus and Eikenella corrodens are typically associated with human bites. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line treatment for prophylaxis. For patients allergic to penicillin, alternative regimens include clindamycin combined with doxycycline, cotrimoxazole, or a fluoroquinolone.



Reference: Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2023, Page no 1283,1284 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a first-line antitubercular drug prescribed in the initial 2 months of treatment?
questions.solution:
The first-line antitubercular drug prescribed during the initial 2 months of treatment is ethambutol.



All newly diagnosed cases are treated for a total duration of 6 months, which consists of two phases: the intensive phase and the continuation phase.

Intensive phase: This lasts for 8 weeks and includes a regimen of isoniazid (H), rifampicin (R), pyrazinamide (Z), and ethambutol (E), all administered under direct observation with daily dosages.

Continuation phase: This phase lasts for 16 weeks and involves isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol in daily dosages. In certain forms of TB, such as CNS TB, skeletal TB, and disseminated TB, this phase may be extended by an additional 12-24 weeks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male presents with 2 weeks of cough, fever and night sweats. Investigations reveal a CD4 count of <100 /pL. Which of the following infections is most likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
In HIV patients with CD4 <100/µL, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely opportunistic infection.

Presents with fever, night sweats, cough, and weight loss. Diagnosed by blood or bone marrow culture showing acid-fast bacilli.
Treatment: Azithromycin or clarithromycin with ethambutol.
Prophylaxis: Azithromycin weekly when CD4 <50/µL.

Other options:

  • S. aureus: Causes bacterial pneumonia, not linked to CD4 count.

  • Candidiasis: Common when CD4 <200/µL, presents with oral or esophageal lesions, not pulmonary disease.

  • Pneumocystis jiroveci: Seen when CD4 <200/µL, causes interstitial pneumonia, not usually night sweats or systemic symptoms.



Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - page no. 1431

choices.text: What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
Wound care with single dose tetanus toxoid
Wound care with tetanus lg and TT vaccine
Wound care with full course of TT vaccine

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a clean crush injury on his hand. He says that he received his last dose of TT vaccination at the age of 23. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has a clean, minor wound and received his last TT dose 7 years ago.

  • According to WHO and CDC guidelines:

    • Clean, minor wound + last TT >10 years ago → TT booster

    • Clean, minor wound + last TT 5–10 years ago → TT booster not always needed, but giving a booster is safe and recommended.

    • Dirty or high-risk wound + last TT >5 years ago → TT booster

    • If immunization status is unknown or incomplete → TT series + tetanus immunoglobulin if high-risk wound

Other options:

  • Wound care only → Not sufficient; last TT was >5 years ago.

  • Wound care with tetanus immunoglobulin + TT → Only for high-risk wounds or unknown immunization.

  • Wound care with full TT course → Only if never immunized.



Reference:
Park's Textbook of preventive and social Medicine,25th edition, Page no 144

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. What is the investigation of choice to test for TB in this patient?
questions.solution:
• CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test, e.g., GeneXpert) is the investigation of choice for tuberculosis (TB) in HIV-positive patients.

  • It detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA and also provides rifampicin resistance status within 2 hours.

  • Highly sensitive and rapid, especially important in immunocompromised patients, where sputum smear may be negative.

Other options:

  • Chest X-ray: Useful for screening but cannot confirm TB.

  • Sputum culture: Gold standard but takes weeks, not ideal for rapid diagnosis.

  • PCR: Similar to CBNAAT but not standardized or widely available for routine TB diagnosis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, p. 1434.

questions.text: Which of the following solutions is recommended as the diluent for the BCG vaccine ?
questions.solution:
The BCG vaccine is supplied as a freeze-dried preparation and should be reconstituted with sterile normal saline provided by the manufacturer. Using distilled water is not recommended in routine practice because the vaccine vial is specifically formulated to be mixed with normal saline to maintain its stability and potency.

Reference:The ICU book 4th edition-Page no 218-225

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In school-age children (typically around 10 years), the Tetanus Toxoid (TT) or Tetanus-Diphtheria (Td) booster is given as part of the national immunization schedule to maintain immunity against tetanus and diphtheria.

Other options:

  • BCG: Given at birth, not repeated at 10 years.

  • MMR: Given at 9–15 months (1st dose) and 15–18 months or at 4–6 years (2nd dose), usually not specifically at 10 years.

  • DPT: Completed in infancy and early childhood; boosters may be given in school but usually covered under TT/Td at 10 years.



Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25thedition Page no 1011

questions.text: Which of the following water-associated diseases is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
• Water-based disease: Diseases caused by pathogens living in water; infection occurs when humans contact or ingest contaminated water. Example: Schistosomiasis. 

  • Water-washed disease: Caused by inadequate water for personal hygiene, leading to skin or eye infections. Example: Trachoma, scabies. Cholera is not water-washed. 

  • Water-borne disease: Caused by ingestion of water contaminated with pathogens. Example: Typhoid, cholera. 

  • Water-related vector-borne disease: Diseases transmitted by vectors that breed in water. Example: Malaria (Anopheles mosquito). 





Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 24th edition-

questions.text: A patient from a North-Eastern state was diagnosed to have an infection with P. falciparum malaria. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Plasmodium falciparum malaria is known for chloroquine resistance, particularly in North-Eastern states of India.

  • As per National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) and WHO guidelines, the first-line treatment for uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria in such regions is:

    Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT)
    → Specifically: Artemether + Lumefantrine

    Why other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Mefloquine:

    • Previously used in ACT (artesunate + mefloquine), but not preferred due to neuropsychiatric side effects and regional resistance patterns.

  • 2. Chloroquine:

    • Not effective against P. falciparum in most of India due to widespread resistance, especially in NE India.

  • 3. Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine (SP):

    • Was part of older ACT regimens (artesunate + SP), but SP resistance has developed, especially in NE states.

      Additional Point:

  • ACT is combined with a single dose of primaquine to clear gametocytes and reduce transmission (except in G6PD deficiency).

questions.text: When quarantine was introduced in the 14th century for plague, how many days were people who were suspected to have the infection quarantined for?
questions.solution:
• Definition: Restriction of movement of individuals, animals, or goods exposed to a communicable disease to prevent its spread.

  • Historical Origin: Introduced in the 14th century during the plague; people were isolated for 40 days (hence "quarantine" from quaranta = 40).

  • Difference from Isolation:

    • Quarantine = for exposed but not yet symptomatic individuals.

    • Isolation = for confirmed cases of illness.

  • Level of Prevention:

    • Primary prevention, specifically specific protection.

      Types of Quarantine

  1. Absolute Quarantine:

    • Total movement restriction for exposed persons.

  2. Modified Quarantine:

    • Partial movement restriction, usually based on risk stratification.

  3. Segregation:

    • Group separation with observation (e.g., keeping contacts under watch).

      Modern Relevance

  • Widely used during COVID-19 (e.g., home quarantine for contacts of confirmed cases).

  • Continues to be an essential public health strategy in outbreak control.


Reference: Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 24th edition page no 958

questions.text: A 20 year old female with a history of recent sexual intercourse presents to the Suraksha clinic of the local Primary Health Centre with complaints of vaginal discharge and lower abdominal pain. Based on the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections which of the following kits will you prescribe to treat this patient?
questions.solution: Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page 475

questions.text: Re-infection with which of the following will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies?
questions.solution:
Even with antibodies, a re-infection with the Dengue virus will cause disastrous symptoms.

The risk of DHF is 500 times higher for infections caused by the DENV-1/DENV-2 sequence than for primary infections. The risk of DHF is 150 times higher for the DENV-3/DENV-2 sequence and 50 times higher for the DENV-4/DENV-2 sequence due B cell activation and cytokine storm following B cells activation. 

This demonstrates that severe forms of dengue, such DHF/DSS, are caused by repeated infections with distinct dengue virus serotypes.

Recent news: Dengvaxia, the first dengue fever vaccine approved by the WHO, is presently available for purchase in 20 nations.

Other options: If antibodies are present, re-infection with Zika, Japanese encephalitis, and yellow fever won't result in severe symptoms.

Reference: Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 270

questions.text: What is the annual new case detection rate for leprosy as of March 31st, 2016?
questions.solution:
• Annual new case detection rate of leprosy as on 31st March, 2016 was:
        9.7/1,00,000 population.
 
  • Current annual new case detection rate of leprosy is 5.52( Target-<10 per 1 lakh population).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 363.

questions.text: Which of the following is not evidence of decreased risk of cardiovascular disease?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin E does not have any overall benefit in reducing mortality or decreasing the risk of heart death or stroke, and thus should not be recommended for heart disease prevention.
  • On the other hand, drinking in moderation may help protect against cardiac diseases and death, and regular physical activity has been proven to decrease risk of cardiovascular diseases.
  • Furthermore, optimal levels of potassium are critical for CVD health and for the prevention of arrhythmias.
  • Amongst option 1 and 2, 1 is a better answer.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 418.

questions.text: The number of vision centres to be constructed, and as per the National Program for Control of Blindness are:
questions.solution:
Under National Program for Control of Blindness, number of vision centres to be established are 20,000.
Each with one Ophthalmic Assistant or equivalent (Community based MLOP) covering population of 50,000.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 504.

questions.text: The following is the name of the upcoming new mental health act in India:
questions.solution:
Recent mental health act in India is designated as the Mental Health Care Act, 2012.
  • This bill aims to provide access to Mental Health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill the rights of persons with mental illness during delivery of mental health care and services and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 545.

questions.text: The value of lethal BMI is:
questions.solution:
The value of lethal BMI is 12.

BMI is a measure of body fat based on weight in relation to height and is used to classify individuals into different weight categories.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 454.

questions.text: According to the NPCB, the screening technique for preventing diabetic retinopathy-related blindness entails:
questions.solution:
The National Program for Control of Blindness (NPCB) emphasizes the importance of regular screening for diabetic retinopathy to prevent vision loss. High-risk screening typically involves examining individuals with diabetes at regular intervals to detect early signs of retinopathy. This can include:

  1. Dilated Eye Examinations: Optometrists or ophthalmologists examine the retina for any changes.
  2. Fundus Photography: Capturing images of the retina for analysis.
  3. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Non-invasive imaging to assess retinal layers and detect swelling.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 503.

choices.text: Monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease

questions.text: What is the WHO- MONICA project for cardiovascular diseases associated with?
questions.solution:
• MONICA (Monitoring Trends and Determinants in Cardiovascular Disease) is a long-term, multi-centre, population-based research programme with the primary aim of monitoring risk factors, trends and determinants of cardiovascular diseases (CVD) in Europe.
  • The project is coordinated by the World Health Organisation (WHO) Regional Office for Europe and includes 24 cohorts from 26 countries.
  • The MONICA project focuses on the epidemiology of CVD, the identification of factors associated with atherosclerosis and its risk factors, the development and evaluation of prevention strategies, health education and public health policies.
  • It also provides data from mortality and morbidity surveillance allowing for a comprehensive assessment of the impact of interventions on mortality, morbidity and health-related quality of life.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 419.

questions.text: What is an example of the most recent surge in NCDs?
questions.solution:
Based on the frequency of disease in a population in relation to time distribution, diseases can have :

  • Short term fluctuations (Epidemics) ,
  • Periodic fluctuations (Cycles or Seasonal) and
  • Long term fluctuations (Secular Trends).

NCDs have shown secular trend of increase in number of cases.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text:
Which of the following criteria must be met for a primary diagnosis of diabetes mellitus?
A. HbA1C> 6.5
B. FBS > 126
C. RBS > 200
D. 2hr PPBS > 200
questions.solution:
DM CRITERIA IN PRIMARY SETUP:
WHO 1999 Criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes 
IFG (Impaired Fasting Glucose) • Fasting glucose 6.1 to 6.9 mmol/l
(110mg/dl to 125 mg/dl)
• 2-h P glucose <7.8 mmol/l 
(140 mg/dl)
IGT (Impaired Glucose Tolerance) 
(Fulfill both criteria)		 •Fasting glucose <7.0 mmol/l 
(126mg/dl)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (3) 75% premium borne by the family. This is a false statement. 75% of premium is borne by Central Government - not by the family as given in the option.

RSBY- The Scheme
  • RSBY has been launched by Ministry of Labour and Employment, Government of India to provide health insurance coverage for Below Poverty Line (BPL) families.
  • The objective of RSBY is to provide protection to BPL households from financial liabilities arising out of health shocks that involve hospitalization.
Eligibility
Unorganized sector workers belonging to BPL category and their family members (a family unit of five) shall be the beneficiaries under the scheme.
The beneficiaries will be issued smart cards for the purpose of identification.

Benefits
The State Governments are advised to incorporate at least the following minimum benefits in the package / scheme:
1. The unorganised sector worker and his family (unit of five) will be covered.
2. Total sum insured would be Rs. 30,000/- per family per annum on a family floater basis.
3. Cashless attendance to all covered ailments
4. Hospitalization expenses, taking care of most common illnesses with as few exclusions as possible
5. All pre-existing diseases to be covered
6. Transportation costs (actual with maximum limit of Rs. 100 per visit) within an overall limit of Rs. 1000.

Funding Pattern
1. Contribution by Government of India: 75% of the estimated annual premium of Rs. 750.
2. Contribution by respective State Governments: 25% of the annual premium, as well as any additional premium.
3. The beneficiary would pay Rs. 30 per annum as registration/renewal fee.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 719.

questions.text: What does the WHO consider to be blindness?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO's definition, blindness is defined as having a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.
  • This means that a person who is blind can only see at less 3 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 456.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a group of people was collected at a young age. Later on, it was found that participants with higher BP at younger ages also have comparatively higher BP at an older age. This is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Blood pressure tracking

The above phenomenon is best described as the "tracking" of blood pressure. The blood pressure of individuals when followed over a period of years from early childhood into adulthood. The BP in individuals with low BP levels tend to remain low, and in those with high BP levels, they tend to remain high. This phenomenon of persistence of rank order of blood pressure has been described as "tracking".



Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 404.

questions.text: A male patient presented to the OPD with a rash on his trunk. On examination, there is an eschar in the trunk region. Regional lymphadenopathy can also be noted. He reports that he recently experienced a mite bite during a camping trip in that area. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a history of a mite bite during camping, a rash on the trunk, an eschar at the bite site, and regional lymphadenopathy.
These features are classic for scrub typhus, which is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).

The hallmark finding is an eschar, a dark scab-like lesion at the site of the mite bite. The illness typically begins with fever, headache, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash that starts on the trunk and may spread to the limbs. Regional lymphadenopathy is also common.

Other rickettsial infections can be ruled out:

  • Epidemic typhus (by lice) and endemic typhus (by fleas) do not produce an eschar.

  • Rocky Mountain spotted fever (by ticks) presents with a rash that begins on the wrists and ankles, not the trunk, and eschar formation is rare.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with skin lesions that are associated with loss of sensation. What is the most unstable form of the disease this patient has?
questions.solution:
The image depicts punched-out anesthetic lesions characteristic of the borderline spectrum of leprosy, specifically the borderline-borderline (BB) type.

Key Features of Borderline Leprosy:
This form is considered the most unstable, often transitioning either towards the tuberculoid (TT) or lepromatous (LL) forms depending on the individual's immune status.
Clinical manifestations may not align with immunological and histological findings, resulting in a mixture of skin lesions reflecting both ends of the spectrum.
Stability of Leprosy Types:
Lepromatous (LL) and tuberculoid (TT) types are the most stable forms of leprosy.

Classification Systems of Leprosy:
1. Ridley-Jopling Classification:
Tuberculoid (TT)
Borderline tubercular (BT)
Borderline (BB)
Borderline lepromatous (BL)
Lepromatous (LL)

2. Madrid Classification:
Lepromatous (LL)
Tuberculoid (TT)
Borderline/dimorphous
Indeterminate (early unstable type)

3. Indian Classification:
Incorporates categories from the Madrid classification and adds the pure neuritic type.

4. WHO Classification: Provides additional guidelines and classifications for leprosy.

These classifications help in understanding the spectrum of leprosy and guiding treatment approaches.

questions.text: Which among the following is not part of STEP approach by WHO?
questions.solution:
The WHO STEPwise approach (STEPS) is a standardized method for chronic disease risk factor surveillance — mainly focusing on non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease.

It includes three steps:

  • Step 1: Questionnaire — behavioral information (tobacco, alcohol, diet, physical activity)

  • Step 2: Physical measurements — height, weight, blood pressure, waist circumference

  • Step 3: Biochemical measurements — blood glucose and blood lipid profile

Blood grouping is not a part of the WHO STEPS approach, as it is not related to NCD risk assessment.


Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition - Page no 413

questions.text: Which of the following carcinomas is least likely to be seen in a patient on oral contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptives (OCs) have a protective effect against endometrial cancer due to the progestin component, which counteracts estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation.

Other options:

  • Oral cavity cancer: Not significantly influenced by OCs.

  • Cervical cancer: Slightly increased risk with long-term OC use, especially with persistent HPV infection.

  • Breast cancer: Small increase in risk observed with current or recent OC use.

Hence, endometrial cancer is least likely in OC users.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics - 14th Edition, p. 976.

questions.text: Which indicator is used in RNTCP to measure the impact of the control measures?
questions.solution:
Incidence of new cases is the key indicator in program like RNTCP.
 

Importance of Incidence as an Indicator

  1. Monitoring Program Effectiveness:

    • A decrease in the incidence of new cases suggests that the control measures are effectively reducing transmission within the community.

  2. Assessing Impact of Interventions:

    • Tracking incidence helps evaluate the impact of specific interventions, such as improved diagnostic methods, treatment adherence initiatives, and public awareness campaigns.

  3. Resource Allocation:

    • Understanding incidence rates helps health authorities allocate resources more effectively, targeting areas with higher rates of infection.

  4. Public Health Planning:

    • Incidence data inform public health strategies and policy decisions, guiding interventions and funding priorities.

  5. Global and National Comparisons:

    • Incidence rates allow for comparisons across regions and countries, helping to identify successful strategies and areas needing improvement.

Measuring Incidence

  • New Cases: The incidence typically refers to the number of newly diagnosed cases within a specific time period, usually reported annually.
  • Surveillance Systems: Effective surveillance systems are essential for accurately capturing new cases, ensuring timely reporting and follow-up.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an objective of Mental Health Act, 1987.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 3
 
  • Promote community participation: Yes, this is an objective of the Act. It encourages the involvement of the community in caring for individuals with mental illnesses.
  • Application of mental health knowledge in general health care: Yes, this is an objective. The Act aimed to integrate mental health into general healthcare services.
  • Minimal mental health care for all: This is not an objective of the Act. The focus of the Act is on providing adequate and appropriate mental health care, not minimal care.
  • Human rights for mentally ill: Yes, protecting the human rights of mentally ill individuals is a significant part of the Act. It aims to safeguard the rights, dignity, and freedom of mentally ill persons, ensuring they are treated with respect and without discrimination.

questions.text: Choose the option that is an output indicator for NPCB.
questions.solution:
An output indicator measures the direct results of activities or services provided, such as the number of services delivered or the number of actions completed.
  • Number of cataract surgeries leading to sight restoration: This is an output indicator because it directly measures the result of a specific service provided (cataract surgery) and its immediate impact (sight restoration).
  • Decrease in prevalence of blindness: This is an outcome indicator because it measures the broader, long-term effect of interventions on public health.
  • Number of school children provided glasses for refraction correction: While important, this is also an output indicator but specific to another service. However, it's not the most direct output linked to the primary goal of NPCB, which focuses on reducing blindness, with cataract surgery being a major intervention.
  • Number of eye surgeons trained: This is an input indicator, as it measures the resources or activities invested in the program, not the direct result of services provided.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 458, 503.

questions.text: All vaccines are new or recently approved except which among the following:
questions.solution:

  • The dengue vaccine is known as Dengvaxia (CYD-TdV).It is a live recombinant vaccine as a 3-dose series on a 0/6/12 months schedule in Phase-II clinical studies. It has been registered for use in individuals 9-45 years of age living in endemic areas.
  • The RTS,S malaria vaccine, also known as Mosquirix, was developed by GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in partnership with the PATH Malaria Vaccine Initiative and is designed to target the Plasmodium falciparum parasite that causes malaria, which is spread by anopheles mosquitoes.
