questions.text: Which of the following best fits the description of a social worker?
questions.solution:
The role of a social worker in health care is a multifaceted one.
  • A social worker's primary responsibility is to help patients, their families, and caregivers work through emotional, financial, and social issues that accompany a diagnosis.
  • They also provide information about community resources, coordinate care, and help patients and their families access services.
  • This includes promoting patient and family involvement in health care decisions and supporting their utilization of available health care resources.
  • As part of their role, social workers also assess a patient's personal role performance, interpersonal skills, and family functions.
  • They provide emotional support, psychoeducational interventions, and systemic advocacy in order to improve quality of life and promote better health outcomes.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 808, 809.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the oral polio vaccine (OPV)?
questions.solution:
Regarding oral polio vaccine (OPV), excretion of virus in stools may cause disease to the unimmunized is not correct statement.

Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV):
  • The OPV progeny excreted in the feces and secondary spread occurs to household contacts and susceptible cont in the community.
  • This property of OPV has been exploited in controlling epidemics of polio by administering the vaccine.
  • Nevertheless, several studies show that among breastfed infants, who are fed OPV in the first three days of life 24 simultaneously in a short period to all susceptibles in a community. percent develop serum antibodies and 30-60 percent excrete vaccine virus.
  • Colostrum produced in the first three days after child-birth contains secretory IgA antibody which might intern with the production of immune response to "OPV "
  • The OPV progeny excreted in the feces and secondary spread occurs to household contacts and susceptible contacts i community. Non-immunized persons may therefore be immunized.
  • Thus, widespread 'herd immunity' results, even approximately 66 percent of the community is immunized.
  • This property of OPV has been exploited in controlling epidemi polio by administering the vaccine simultaneously in a short period to all susceptibles in a community.
  • This procedure ima eliminates the wild polio strains in the community and replaces them with attenuated strains.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 241, 242.

WHO Measles Elimination Strategy comprises a 3-part vaccination strategy:

1. Catch up:

- One time nationwide vaccination campaign targeting all children 9 months to 14 years of age irrespective of history of measles disease or vaccination status.

2. –ö–µ–µ—Ä u—Ä:

3. Follow up:

ASHA does not have adequate training to do so.

  • An Accredited Social Health Activist(ASHA) is a community health worker employed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare as a part of India's National Rural Health Mission.
  • The various functions of ASHA worker include the ones given in other options.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: Which of these is not the purview of a psychiatrist
questions.solution:
Psychiatrist is not available at PHC.

Manpower available at PHC—

  • As per minimum requirement, a PHC is to be manned by a medical officer supported by 14 paramedical and other staff.
  • Under NRHM, there is a provision for two additional staff nurses at PHCs on contract basis.
  • No specialist is posted at PHC.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: At PHC, ABC and VED analyses are performed for:
questions.solution:
Important methods of inventory control include

  • A - B - C analysis
  • Periodic revision of classification
  • VED analysis.
 
  • VED analysis is based on critical values and shortage cost of the item. Based on their criticality, the items could be classified into three categories: Vital, essential and desirable, i.e., VED.
  • In materials management, ABC analysis is an inventory categorisation technique. ABC analysis divides an inventory into three categories—"A items" with very tight control and accurate records, "B items" with less tightly controlled and good records, and "C items" with the simplest controls possible and minimal records. 

Online reference: https://www.iptsalipur.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BP703T_PP_V.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following will not receive financial remuneration as ASHA under NRHM,?
questions.solution:
• Asha workers under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) are entitled to receive a monthly financial incentive of Rs.1000 from the government.
  • They are also entitled to receive additional incentives from the State Government and Community Health Center (CHC) for their work in providing primary health care at the village and block level.
  • The Government of India also provides resources for Asha facilitators for capacity building, training and additional support.

The incentives are included for all the options except zero doses of DPT and OPV.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text:
A rural hospital in India expects an ophthalmologist to carry out which procedure the most
frequently?
questions.solution:
Under NPCB, training of ophthalmologists is done on multiple topics.
The universal training, for ophthalmologists at sub-district hospital and district hospital level includes- 
  • ECCE/IOL implantation
  • SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
  • Phacoemulsification

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 458, 503.

choices.text: High-level expert group of universal health program for India

questions.text: Which of the aforementioned panels has suggested a three-year a bachelor's degree in medical education for services in rural health?
questions.solution:
Concept of 3 years bachelor paramedical course for rural health service was proposed by Ministry of Health and family welfare and received backing of Planning Commission of India's High level expert group of universal health program.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 505.

questions.text: What is the number of 'Millennium Development Goals' directly related to health?
questions.solution:
The 8 Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), established in 2000, strive to achieve the world's main development challenges by 2015.
These 8 objectives encompass
  • 21 quantifiable targets and
  • 60 indicators,
  • with 3 of the goals,
  • 8 targets, and
  • 18 indicators related to health.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 695.

questions.text: Which disease is not included in the "Integrated Disease Surveillance Project"?
questions.solution:
Under IDSP Clinical data collection has been simplified as only the number of the cases of disease under surveillance is to be reported.

As of the latest updates, the IDSP focuses on around 33 specific diseases. These include high-priority diseases like:

  1. Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI)
  2. Tuberculosis
  3. Malaria
  4. Dengue
  5. Leptospirosis
  6. Cholera
  7. Hepatitis
  8. Typhoid
  9. Japanese Encephalitis
  10. Zika Virus, among others.
 

Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP)

Objectives
  • To strengthen/maintain decentralized laboratory-based IT enabled disease surveillance system for epidemic-prone diseases to monitor disease trends and to detect and respond to outbreaks in early rising phase through trained Rapid Response Team (RRTs).
Programme Components
  • Integration and decentralization of surveillance activities through the establishment of surveillance units at Centre, State and District level.
  • Human Resource Development – Training of State Surveillance Officers, District Surveillance Officers, Rapid Response Team and other Medical and Paramedical staff on principles of disease surveillance.
  • Use of Information Communication Technology for collection, collation, compilation, analysis and dissemination of data.
  • Strengthening of public health laboratories.
  • Inter sectoral Co-ordination for zoonotic diseases.

Hence, the option (1) is correct. Snake bite is not included under IDSP.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 546.

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines is used as the foundation for growth monitoring by Anganwadi staff under the ICDS programme?
questions.solution:
• The earlier growth charts had been using Who recommended US national Cancer for Health Statistics (NCHS) growth references since the late 1970s  but these references did not adequately represent early childhood growth.
     
  • So new WHO growth standards were generated for boys and girls aged 0-60 months, based on data from the WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 622.

It is linked with vitamin A supplementation programme

questions.solution:

  • It should not be given below 1 yr of age.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 533.

choices.text: The plan is to implement the programme in 10 districts across the 5 states during 2010-2012
The diagnosis or treatment of non-communicable diseases to be carried out at the subcentre level
Coronary care unit and cancer care facility to be established at the district level hospital
All the components of the programme to be addressed separately-cancer, diabetes, CVD and stroke

questions.text: Which of the following claims is accurate about the National Program for Non- Communicable Diseases— Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD), and Stroke (NPCDCS)?
questions.solution:
• As part of the National Program for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS), efforts will be made to set up Coronary Care Unit and Cancer Care Facilities at the District Level Hospitals of 21 States in the next 3 years.
  • This program seeks to optimize resources by merging the two components, cancer and diabetes, CVDs, and stroke, at all levels, including the State, District, CHC, and Sub Centre, where the implementation and monitoring of the strategies proposed will be diligently supervised by the NCD cells.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 416.

questions.text: ASHA is posted at which level?
questions.solution:
Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a community health worker instituted by the government of India as part of the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • ASHA workers are posted at the village level to act as a bridge between the community and the healthcare system, ensuring that health services are accessible to the rural population.
  • Their role includes promoting healthy behaviors, ensuring immunization, assisting with healthcare access, and promoting institutional deliveries.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: What does "JSY" stand for?
questions.solution:
Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.
  • JSY provides financial incentives to encourage women to give birth in healthcare facilities rather than at home, where risks to mother and child can be higher.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 521.

questions.text: The following made primary healthcare available:
questions.solution:
BHORE COMMITTEE : Had proposed PHC at 1/40,000 population and social physicians.
 
  • The Bhore Committee, formally known as the "Group on Medical Education and Support for Health," was established in 1946 in India.
  • Chaired by Dr. A. Lakshmanaswamy Mudaliar, the committee aimed to reform medical education and healthcare delivery in the country.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 693.

choices.text: Intervention based on assessment of community needs

questions.text: Which of the following best exemplifies the highest level of community involvement?
questions.solution:
The highest level of community involvement is when the community itself is actively involved in the planning of interventions.
  • This level of participation indicates that the community members are not just recipients of services or passive participants but are actively engaged in identifying issues, deciding on the interventions, and planning how to implement these interventions.
  • This represents a high degree of ownership, empowerment, and sustainability of the initiatives.
Intervention based on assessment of community needs (Option 2) typically involves external agents assessing the needs and designing interventions accordingly, which may or may not fully involve the community in the decision-making process.

Provision of resources by community (Option 3) shows a significant level of involvement, but it focuses on the community contributing resources rather than being involved in planning.

Community supports and cooperates with workers (Option 4) is a lower level of involvement, where the community cooperates with interventions designed and implemented by others but does not lead or plan them.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't constitute a necessary part of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Primary health care is based on principles such as
  • accessibility,
  • community participation,
  • health promotion, and
  • the provision of essential services like immunization, health education, and essential drugs.


While cost-effectiveness is important in healthcare delivery, it is not specifically defined as a fundamental component of primary healthcare.
The other options (provision of essential drugs, immunization, and health education) are core elements of primary healthcare as outlined by the Alma-Ata Declaration.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which of the following encapsulates a recent medical trend?
questions.solution:
Community participation has become a prominent trend in modern healthcare, emphasizing the involvement of the community in health planning, decision-making, and intervention strategies.
  • This trend reflects a shift towards empowering communities to take an active role in their health, ensuring that healthcare interventions are more effective, sustainable, and culturally appropriate.
  • While qualitative inquiry, equitable distribution, and primary healthcare are all important concepts, community participation represents a specific trend in the evolving landscape of public health.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

choices.text: Children from 9 months to less than 15 years vaccinated
Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), responsible for irreversible birth defects
India has not yet launched this campaign
Will replace routine immunization for measles vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the MR vaccination campaign launched by the WHO is false?
questions.solution:
MR vaccination campaign 2021 by WHO includes 11 nations ,including India. 
 
  • Children from 9 months to less than 15 years vaccinated.
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is responsible for irreversible birth defects.
  • 2 dose vaccine schedule is added which will replace routine immunization for measles vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 508.

choices.text: Emphasis on management of sick neonates over sick older children
Treatment is aimed at more than one disease at a time

questions.text: IMNCI is distinct from IMCI in every way with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) and the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) are approaches designed to reduce child mortality and improve child health.
  • IMNCI is an expansion of IMCI that includes a focus on the neonatal period (0-7 days) and emphasizes the management of sick neonates.
  • However, both approaches share the principle of addressing multiple diseases and health issues simultaneously rather than focusing on just one disease at a time.
  • This holistic approach is a cornerstone of both IMNCI and IMCI, making option 4 the correct answer.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 655.

questions.text: India aims to eliminate which of the following diseases by 2015:
questions.solution:
India set the goal to eliminate Kala Azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis) by 2015.
  • Kala Azar is a parasitic disease transmitted by sandflies, and it primarily affects the poor in rural areas. The elimination target refers to reducing the incidence of Kala Azar to less than 1 case per 10,000 population at the sub-district level.
  • Malaria and Tuberculosis are significant public health challenges, but the target for elimination of these diseases was set for later years, not 2015.
  • Filariasis elimination was also targeted for a later date, with the goal being extended to beyond 2015.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 480.

choices.text: Size of bars in the cross in equal horizontally and vertically
Can be used by personnel of United Nations Organizations (UNO)
Misuse of emblem is punishable offense under Indian Law

questions.text: Everything regarding the "Red Cross" insignia is accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Can be used by personnel of United Nations Organizations (UNO)
 
  • The Red Cross insignia, consisting of a red cross on a white background, is an internationally recognized symbol of protection and neutrality for medical and humanitarian personnel during armed conflicts and disasters.
  • The International Committee of the Red Cross is based out of Geneva, Switzerland.
  • The UNO is not a part of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, so its personnel are not authorized to use the Red Cross emblem.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 1032.

choices.text: Child age less than 14 carrying serious work earn more money
Less than 14 yr are not allowed to work  as per factory act

questions.text: Which of the following claims about the Factory Act is true?
questions.solution:
Under the Factories Act, children below 14 years of age are prohibited from working.
  1. Provisions of the Factories Act, for adolescents between 15 and 18 years:
  • They can work only between 6 AM and 7 PM.
  • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
  • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.
  • They are restricted from working in dangerous occupations.
  • Adolescents should be duly certified regarding their fitness for work.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 942.

questions.text: Which vaccine does Mission Indradhanush not include at the national level
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Japanese Encephalitis
  • Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on).
  • 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).
  • The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are: TB, Polio , Hep B, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Measles, Japanese Encephalitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis included in the Indradhanush Mission but it is not a nationally-notifiable disease in India so given only in endemic areas .
  • This means that there is not enough data to show that Japanese Encephalitis is a major public health problem in India.
  • However, the Mission Indradhanush does provide vaccines against Japanese Encephalitis in selected districts/states of the country where the disease is endemic.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 508.

questions.text: Mission IndraDhanush is for:
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush is an immunization program launched by the Indian government in 2014.

  • It aims to immunize all children against seven preventable diseases, which are Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis (whooping cough), Polio, Tuberculosis, Hepatitis B, and measles.
  • The program is targeting children under two years old who are either unvaccinated, vaccinated but incompletely vaccinated or whose vaccination has been delayed.
  • It aims to reach children in remote and hard to reach areas and increase the routine immunization coverage in India by providing additional doses of vaccines.
  • The Mission targets to immunize over 80% of children by 2020, so that the loss of life due to these vaccine-preventable diseases can be reduced.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 508.

questions.text: The monetary advantage is determined by:
questions.solution:
Cost benefit analysis (CBA) measures the monetary benefits of a program by comparing program costs to anticipated benefits.

  • The analysis involves determining a specific economic value for both the costs incurred to set up and operate a program and the potential gains that can be achieved. By assigning a monetary value to both inputs and outcomes.
  • CBA allows program planners to weigh the true monetary costs and benefits of a program to determine whether the benefits outweigh the costs.
  • Benefits can be both direct (such as improved educational outcomes) or indirect (such as environmental benefits).
  • Understanding the full scope of likely gains allows decision-makers to determine whether the program is worth the investment.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 999.

questions.text: You work as a PHC medical officer. Which of the following regimens would you recommend for mass anaemia prophylaxis
questions.solution:
Ferrous sulfate and folic acid is advisable to be given for mass prophylaxis of anemia.

Option (1) is most appropriate answer.


Anemia prophylaxis refers to measures taken to prevent anemia, especially in populations at higher risk, such as pregnant women, young children, and individuals with chronic illnesses.

Nutritional Interventions:

  • Iron Supplementation: Providing iron supplements to at-risk groups, particularly pregnant women and children.
  • Folic Acid: Ensuring adequate intake of folic acid, which is essential for red blood cell formation.
  • Vitamin B12: Monitoring and supplementing vitamin B12, particularly in populations at risk of deficiency.
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 775.

questions.text: As part of an audit, you visited a sub centre. How many newborns ought to be listed on a health worker's roster there?
questions.solution:
Subcenters are the peripheral outposts of the existing health delivery system in rural areas, with one subcenter per 5000 population in general and one for every 3000 population in hilly, tribal and backward areas.
  • Taking the birth rate of India as 20.4/1000 population and infant mortality rate as 34/1000 live births from the SRS September 2017 data, the estimated number of infants catered to by a health sub center with a population of 5000 can be calculated to be 100 (102 live births minus the 4 infant mortalities).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 555.

questions.text: Which group within the National Health Mission develops plans for village health?
questions.solution:
The National Health Mission develops plans for village health through the active participation of the VHSNC.
 
  • The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee (VHSNC) is a practical means for providing communities, particularly impoverished families and children, with the opportunity to assume responsibility for their own welfare and have their voices heard.
  • This committee serves as a catalyst to support the initiating of fundamental change at a grassroots level.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 700.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is used to assess a vaccine's heat sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Vaccine vial monitors (VMs) are used to track the cumulative heat exposure of vaccines during their transportation in the supply chain.
  • VVMs are placed on vaccine containers by manufacturers and allow users to check the colour of the indicator label to determine if the vaccine has been exposed to heat above a certain threshold and should be discarded.
  • This provides a reliable and effective way to monitor temperature to ensure sensitive vaccines remain safe.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 122.

questions.text: What are the components of a pentavalent vaccine?
questions.solution:
Pentavalent vaccine provides protection to a child from 5 life-threatening diseases –

  • Diphtheria,
  • Pertussis,
  • Tetanus,
  • Hepatitis B and
  • Hib.

DPT (Diptheria+Pertussis+Tetanus), Hep B and Hib vaccine are part of it.

Dose: 0.5 IM at anterolateral aspect of left thight at 6, 10 and 14 weeks after birth.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 507.

questions.text: Which vaccine is associated with intussusception?
questions.solution:
1. Rotavirus vaccine
  • The main cause of severe diarrhoea in young infants is rotavirus infections, which are prevented by the rotavirus vaccine.
 
  • After it was determined that the vaccination may have increased the risk of intussusception, or intestinal obstruction, in one of every 12,000 vaccinated infants, the vaccine was withdrawn off the market.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 130.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the SAFE strategy for trachoma?
questions.solution:
1. SAFE strategy, which has been endorsed by the WHO, in an effort to avoid trachoma infections and blindness.
  2. It includes:
  • Surgery (Tertiary prevention), 
  • antibiotic use (Secondary prevention), 
  • facial cleanliness/hygiene (Primary prevention)
  • environmental changes (Primordial prevention)
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 357.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about mobile medical units is/are True?
A. MMU are government-operated
B. MMU run by an external agency with medical supplies given by the government
C. MMU run by government and medical supplies also by the government
D. MMU run by external agency and medical supplies also by an external agency
questions.solution:
1. The operationalization of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs) as part of the NRHM (National Rural Health Mission) was a significant endeavor with the main goal of bringing healthcare service delivery to the doorsteps of populations living in rural, inaccessible, un-served, and underserved areas. 

Generally speaking, there are 3 models for operationalizing MMUs: 
 

  • MMUs run by the government.
  • Government-provided medications, CAPEX and supplies are used in MMU which are operated by external agencies.
  • MMU services, including CAPEX and OPEX are outsourced but drugs and supplies must be given by the government.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 516.

questions.text: Which vaccine must be administered to a 10-year-old school student as part of the school health programme?
questions.solution:
TT, Td should be administered.
 
  • Older children require the Tdap vaccination, which contains a full dose of tetanus but a lesser dosage of diphtheria and pertussis since protection to tetanus declines with age.
  • Preteen children should have a Tdap vaccination as part of their routine annual checkups until they are 18 years old.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text:
In a neighbourhood under attack from an encephalitis outbreak with numerous cases.
The route of vaccine administration for the anticipated infection as per the universal immunisation schedule is:
questions.solution:
Live JE vaccine and subcutaneous route of administration are required for JE vaccination.

The Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine is used to protect against Japanese encephalitis, a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily in rural and agricultural areas of Asia and the Western Pacific.
Live Attenuated Vaccines: These vaccines contain a weakened form of the virus and include options like:
  • SA 14-14-2: A live attenuated vaccine that is also used in some regions.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text:
You were handed control of the adjacent school's health department.

questions.solution:
School health services are at the PHC level.
FACT BASED.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 658.

questions.text: What is the most crucial factor in determining how well a health centre operates in terms of evaluation of clinical management?
questions.solution:
Outcome is the most important determinant for assessing clinical management.

The effectiveness of medical treatment has typically been evaluated by the
  • patient's recovery,
  • return to normal function, and
  • survival.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 1003.

questions.text: Identify the HIV sentinel not included in India:

HIV sentinel surveillance in India does not include STD clinic attendant.

  • single migrant male, ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

questions.text: What is excluded from RBSK is:
questions.solution:
RBSK does not include congenital glaucoma.
 
  • Under RBSK we have various conditions under 4 sub groups which include identified health conditions for child health screening and early intervention services.
  • The sub-groups are:
  • Defects at birth

And congenital glaucoma is not included in these health conditions.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 529.

questions.text: IFA tablet dosage for a teenage girl under Anemia Mukt Bharat:
questions.solution:
Dose of IFA tablet for adolescent girl under Anemia Mukt Bharat is 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid weekly once.

 Doses of IFA tablet for various age groups under Anaemia Mukt Bharat:

  • 5-10 years : 45mg of elemental iron and 400mcg of folic acid

  • Pregnant and lactating women : 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid
  • Women of reproductive age : 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid

DPT (Diphtheria+Pertussis+Tetanus), Hep B and Hib vaccine are part of it.

questions.text: What vaccinations will you suggest for a 13-month-old child who is unvaccinated based on the most recent immunisation schedule?
questions.solution:
A baby that is 13 months old and unvaccinated coming to the clinic for the first time should receive
  • three doses of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV),
  • three doses of Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV),
  • three doses of Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus (DPT) vaccine, and
  • three doses of Hepatitis B (Hep-B) vaccine.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about OPV?
questions.solution:
• Maternal antibody interferes with immune response is the incorrect statement. 
  • Although the immune response of IPV may be affected by maternal antibodies, the response of OPV is NOT affected. 
  • Rest all statements are true regarding OPV.

questions.text: In accordance with international health regulations, yellow fever cannot spread if the aedes aegypti index stays below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 1%
 
  • Aedes aegypti index, i.e., the ratio between the number of houses in an area where breeding of Aedes are found and the total number of houses examined in that area. This index is kept at zero at all ports.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that the Aedes aegypti index be kept below 1% to prevent the spread of yellow fever.
  • If the Aedes aegypti index is above 1%, it means that there is a high risk of yellow fever transmission in the area. This is because Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the main vector for yellow fever.
  • There are a number of things that can be done to keep the Aedes aegypti index below 1%, including:
  1. Eliminating mosquito breeding sites
  2. Using insect repellent
  3. Wearing long sleeves and pants
  4. Getting vaccinated against yellow fever

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 329.

questions.text: In the absence of microscopy, what is the preferred treatment for falciparum malaria when bivalent RDT is employed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ACT + Primaquine
 
  • When the microscopy is not available, a bivalent RDT (Rapid Diagnostic Test) can be employed to diagnose malaria by detecting specific antigens produced by the Plasmodium falciparum parasite.
  • If a bivalent rapid diagnostic test (RDT) is positive for Plasmodium falciparum malaria, the preferred treatment is an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) + primaquine.
  • ACTs are the most effective treatment for falciparum malaria.
  • Primaquine is effective in preventing relapses.

Rx of P. falciparum:

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Didactic communication is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Democratic
 
  • Didactic communication is a one-way communication process, where information is imparted from the speaker (or teacher) to the audience (or learners) without active participation or feedback from the audience.
  • Didactic communication is not characterized by democratic or participatory interactions. It is the opposite, where the communication is primarily top-down, with the speaker being the sole authority delivering information to the audience.

choices.text: An individual having a cough of 2 weeks or more

questions.text: Except for____, all of the following are considered "pulmonary TB suspects" according to RNTCP.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Contacts of smear-positive TB patients having cough of 2 weeks or more 


According to the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP),
  • a pulmonary TB suspect is an individual who has a cough of 2 weeks or more, and who has any of the following risk factors:
  • HIV infection
  • Recent contact with a smear-positive TB patient
  • Recent travel to a TB-endemic area
  • Immunocompromised state
 
  • Contacts of smear-positive TB patients are considered to be at high risk of TB, but they do not necessarily have a cough of 2 weeks or more.
  • Therefore, they are not considered to be pulmonary TB suspects according to the RNTCP.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210, 211, 212.

questions.text: Which of the following is not definition of a problem village in the National Water Supply and Sanitation program ?
questions.solution:
• The National Water Supply and Sanitation Program (NWSSP) is a program launched by the Government of India to provide safe drinking water and sanitation facilities to rural communities.
  • The program identifies problem villages based on certain criteria, and provides assistance to improve their water supply and sanitation facilities.
  • The correct option, 4, is not a definition of a problem village in the NWSSP.
  • Guinea worm disease is caused by a parasitic worm called Dracunculus medinensis, which is transmitted through contaminated drinking water. However, the disease has been eradicated from India since 2000.
  • Therefore, the presence of Guinea worm infestation in a village is not a current problem in the context of the NWSSP.
  • On the other hand, the other three options are criteria used to identify problem villages in the NWSSP.
  • Option 1 states that if the distance of the safe water source is greater than 1.6 km, it is considered a problem village. Option 2 states that if the water source is exposed to the risk of cholera, it is considered a problem village.
  • Option 3 states that if the water source has excess iron and heavy metals, it is considered a problem village.
  • Therefore, based on the criteria used by the NWSSP to identify problem villages, option 4 is not a definition of a problem village, while options 1, 2, and 3 are.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 549.

questions.text: Which insect amongst the following has not developed resistance to DDT
questions.solution:
Kala-azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a serious parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species, primarily Leishmania donovani. The disease is transmitted through the bites of infected sandflies, specifically the Phlebotomus species in the Old World and Lutzomyia in the New World.
Control measures often include the use of insecticides, and DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) has been historically used in mosquito control programs.

questions.text: A vaccine is useable, in accordance with the Vaccine Vial Monitor, if:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Outer Circle Dark; Inner Square Light
 
  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

questions.text: Which vaccination among the following was discontinued due to a higher risk of intussusception?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Rota Virus Vaccine
 
  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a risk of developing intussusception, usually within a week after the first or second dose.
  • Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection.
  • The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a very minimal risk of intussusception.

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) per 100000 population
Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases

questions.text: Which of the following is a quality service indicator under NLEP?
questions.solution:
Under the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP), quality service indicators focus on the effectiveness of early diagnosis, treatment quality, and prevention of disabilities. The proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases indicates the efficiency of early detection efforts in preventing severe disabilities caused by leprosy.


Other indicators:
 

  1. Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) per 100,000 population:
    This measures the burden of leprosy but is more of an epidemiological indicator than a quality service indicator.

  2. Proportion of multi-bacillary among new cases:
    This tracks the proportion of severe forms of leprosy but is not a direct quality service indicator.

  3. Proportion of treatment defaulters:
    This is a measure of adherence and service coverage but not primarily a quality service indicator.

  4. Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases (Correct):
    A higher proportion reflects delayed diagnosis, while a lower proportion indicates better service quality in identifying cases early, making it a key quality service indicator under NLEP.




Reference:  Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 372.

questions.text:
Which of the following requirements should be met to start a person on leprosy chemoprophylaxis? 
(i) Age > 2 years 
(ii) Living with the patient for >6 months 
(iii) Close contact for >20 hours per week 
(iv) Sharing the same clothes and towels
questions.solution:
Inclusion criteria to be considered for receiving Post-exposure Chemoprophylaxis with single dose Rifampicin in leprosy:

(i)Age > 2 years 
(ii)Living with the patient for >3 months in the past 1 year
(iii)Close contact for >20 hours per week (eg sharing clothes)

Hence, option (3) is correct( [ii] is wrong - it should be 3 months, not 6)

Exclusion Criteria
(i) Pregnancy
(ii) Received Rifampicin in the past 2 years(eg for TB)
(iii) Signs and symptoms of TB
(iv) Signs and symptoms of Leprosy
(v) Acute febrile illness. 
(vi) History of hepatic disorder
 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 366.

choices.text: Involving in planning of health related campaigns

questions.text: Which among the following is highest level of community participation?
questions.solution:
Highest level of community participation is when the community itself is involved in planning of health related campaigns.

*Extra Edge:

Notwithstanding the overall responsibility of the Central and State Governments, the involvement of individuals, families, and communities in promotion of their own health and welfare, is an essential ingredient of primary health care. Countries are now conscious of the fact that universal coverage by primary health care cannot be achieved without the involvement of the local community. There must be a continuing effort to secure meaningful involvement of the community in the planning, implementation and maintenance of health services, besides maximum reliance on local resources such as manpower, money and materials. In short, primary health care must be built on the principle of community participation (or involvement).
One approach that has been tried successfully in India is the use of village health guides and trained dais. They are selected by the local community and trained locally in the delivery of primary health care to the community they belong, free of charge. By overcoming cultural and communication barriers, they provide primary health care in ways that are acceptable to the community. It is now considered that ASHA and Anganwadi workers are an essential feature of primary health care in India. These concepts are revolutionary. They have been greatly influenced by experience in China where community participation in the form of bare-foot doctors took place on an unprecedented scale.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No: 952.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a ten-year-old school child will receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine combines tetanus and diphtheria components, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) suitable for older children and adults. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) recommends replacing the TT vaccine with the Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 ml is administered intramuscularly in the upper arm.

The Td vaccine is scheduled to be given at ages 10 and 16 years.

For pregnant women:

• Td-1: Administered early in pregnancy.
• Td-2: Given 4 weeks after Td-1.
• Td (Booster): Administered if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and if 2 Td doses were received.

choices.text: Organize and conduct tubectomy and vasectomy camps

Act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits
Review and consolidate reports received from the health workers

questions.text: Which among the following is a role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA)?
questions.solution:
The role of an Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) includes acting as a depot holder for essential provisions like condoms and drug kits.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist who resides in her village and has formal education up to the eighth grade. Ideally, she should be between 25 to 45 years old and possess good communication and leadership skills. The general guideline is to have one ASHA for every 1,000 people, although in tribal, hilly, and desert regions, this can be adjusted to one ASHA per habitation.

Other Roles of ASHA:
• Create Awareness: Provide information to the community on nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygiene practices.

• Counsel Women: Offer guidance on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breastfeeding, complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception.

• Infection Prevention: Advise women on preventing common infections, including reproductive tract and sexually transmitted infections.

• Facilitate Access: Help community members access healthcare and related services.

• Escort Services: Accompany pregnant women and children who need treatment or admission to the nearest health facility.

Report Health Events: Inform the sub-center or primary health center about births, deaths, and unusual health problems or disease outbreaks in the community.

Promote Sanitation: Advocate for the construction of household toilets under the Total Sanitation Campaign.

These responsibilities highlight the vital role ASHAs play in improving community health and promoting health education.

questions.text: Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat programme (AMB), the Government of India advocates giving
questions.solution:
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program, the government of India promotes the administration of iron and folic acid for six months before childbirth and six months after.

IFA Tablet Distribution under Anemia Mukt Bharat:

• Lactating Mothers (0-6 months postpartum): Receive a daily red IFA tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid.
• Women of Reproductive Age (20-49 years): Get weekly red IFA tablets with the same composition (60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid), intended for non-pregnant, non-lactating women.
• Children (5-9 years): Are provided weekly with pink sugar-coated IFA tablets containing 45 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid.
• Adolescents (10-19 years): School-going and out-of-school girls and boys receive weekly blue IFA tablets, each containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid.

questions.text: A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?
questions.solution:
Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) focuses on maternal and neonatal health, primarily promoting institutional deliveries and reducing maternal and infant mortality.

Services provided under JSY:

  • Cash incentives for institutional delivery.

  • Safe abortion services (as part of maternal health care in government facilities).

  • Antenatal and postnatal care under maternal health programs.

Not covered:

  • STD counseling is not a component of JSY; it is addressed separately under Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) programs.

questions.text: Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Yojna is related to which of the groups of people?
questions.solution: • The Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Yojna focuses on training healthcare professionals—including doctors, nurses, and Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs)—in essential newborn care, early diagnosis, and effective management of common childhood ailments.

questions.text: Project "Axshya" is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya is an initiative by The Stop TB Partnership and Indian National TB Program to enhance TB awareness and case detection among marginalized and vulnerable populations.

Key points:

  • Focuses on community engagement, awareness generation, and active case finding.

  • Aims to reduce TB incidence and mortality by targeting hard-to-reach groups.

  • Not related to diabetes, malaria, or Zika virus.

questions.text: How often should health check-ups be conducted for children aged 9-18 years under the RBSK program?
questions.solution:
According to the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) program, health check-ups for children aged 9 to 18 years should be conducted semi-annually.

This frequency enables healthcare providers to thoroughly evaluate multiple facets of a child's health, including physical, mental, and emotional well-being. By conducting check-ups every six months, it allows for the early identification of any developing health concerns, facilitates timely interventions, and ensures continuity of care. This proactive strategy not only promotes overall health but also contributes to better health outcomes for children.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide vaccine?
questions.solution:
• Hepatitis B is a recombinant Protein Vaccine.
  • Other Recombinant protein vaccine include- HBV, HPV,Covid-19, Cholera toxin-B.
  • Polysacharide vaccine - Pneumococcus, Meningococcus and Haemophilus Influenza
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page No 111.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of RCH program?
questions.solution:
The Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program does not encompass women's education and empowerment as a specific component.

The RCH program focuses on the health status of young women and children, aiming to achieve key objectives such as reducing the total fertility rate, infant mortality rate, and maternal mortality rate.

The primary components of the program include:
  • Essential and emergency obstetric care
  • Control of reproductive tract infections (RTI) and sexually transmitted diseases (STD)
  • Safe abortion services
  • A comprehensive range of family planning services, including laparoscopic procedures
  • Essential newborn care and immunization
  • Emergency care for sick children, specifically addressing diarrheal and acute respiratory diseases
  • Prevention and control of vitamin A deficiency and anemia in children.

questions.text: School health service should include all the following except
questions.solution:
The school health service encompasses all aspects mentioned, excluding the requirement for a doctor to be present on school premises.

School health service programs are designed to promote positive health, prevent diseases, diagnose issues, treat conditions, and provide follow-up care for defects.

Health appraisal services within the program are managed by doctors at primary health centers (PHCs). Teachers receive training to conduct daily inspections, administer first aid, and provide emergency care when needed, making a doctor's presence at the school unnecessary.

The main components of this program include:
  • Screening for general health assessments, including anemia and nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing issues, dental check-ups, physical disabilities, learning disorders, and behavioral problems.
  • Prevention of communicable diseases through immunization.
  • Ensuring a healthful school environment.
  • Nutritional services.
  • First aid and emergency care.
  • Education for children with disabilities.
  • Health education.
  • Maintenance and utilization of school health records.

The system has been developed jointly by the Central TB Division of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and National Informatics Centre.
NIKUSTH is the new online software home monitoring leprosy patients.

questions.text: A primigravida at a PHC was advised that she was entitled for free check up on the 9th of every month under a particular scheme launched by the government. What is the scheme?
questions.solution:
Under the Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month. This is undertaken as part of the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child Plus Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy. The scheme aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services.

Under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) a cash incentive of 5000 is provided in instalments to all pregnant women and lactating mothers for the first living child of the family.

Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN) provides at least four antenatal checkups, and six home-based newborn care visits.

Under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) a cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who had an institutional delivery in low performing states.

Ref- https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1308&lid=689

questions.text: What is the delivery criteria in a Type A PHC?
questions.solution:
According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS):

  • Type A PHC – Conducts < 20 deliveries per month (limited obstetric services).

  • Type B PHC – Conducts ≥ 20 deliveries per month (provides 24×7 delivery services).

Hence, PHCs with fewer than 20 deliveries monthly are classified as Type A PHCs.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - Page no 994

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl came for a health checkup. She doesn't go to school. Which government program will benefit her?
questions.solution:
• Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a child health screening and early intervention program for children aged 0–18 years, especially targeting those who do not attend school.

  • It focuses on defects at birth, deficiencies, diseases, and developmental delays including disability.

  • Children are screened in schools, community centers, and health facilities, and interventions are provided as needed.

Other options:

  • Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram → Focuses on newborn care and resuscitation.

  • Janani Suraksha Yojana → Promotes institutional deliveries and maternal health.

  • Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman → Focuses on nutrition for children and women, not comprehensive health screening.


Reference
1.Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - Page no 506, 507

questions.text: 6x6x6 strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat includes all except:
questions.solution:
The 6x6x6 strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat focuses on six key components in six areas across six target groups to reduce anemia prevalence. The six components include:

  1. Institutional mechanism – Strengthening governance and monitoring

  2. Interventions – Iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, dietary measures

  3. Capacity building – Training of frontline workers

  4. Community mobilization and behavior change

  5. Monitoring and evaluation

  6. Coordination/Ministries – Inter-sectoral collaboration

Beneficiaries are not part of the 6x6x6 framework; they are the target group but not a component of the strategy.






Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition - Page 281

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?
questions.solution:
The Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) provides health insurance coverage of up to 5 lakh per family per year. Its primary objective is to build a comprehensive, need-based healthcare system for India.

 Key Components
The program is built on two key initiatives aimed at creating a "New India" by 2022:

1. Health and Wellness Centres:
- Establishment of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres across the country.
- These centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering maternal and child health services, non-communicable diseases, and offering free essential drugs and diagnostic services.

2. National Health Protection Mission (NHPM)*:
- NHPM provides health protection coverage for poor and vulnerable families.
- Health and Wellness Centres will also create awareness about AB-NHPM, conduct screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow up on hospitalization cases.

Additionally, *School Health Programs* will promote age-appropriate health awareness, conduct health screenings, and provide iron and folic acid supplementation through health centres.

 Benefits of the Ayushman Bharat Scheme:
- Insurance Coverage:
- 5 lakh coverage per family annually for health treatments.
- All families listed in the SECC (Socio-Economic Caste Census) database based on specific criteria are eligible.
- No cap on family size or age of family members.
- Priority is given to girl children, women, and senior citizens.

- Access to Care:
- Free treatment at all public and empaneled private hospitals.
- Covers both secondary and tertiary care hospitalizations.

- Comprehensive Coverage:
- 1,350 medical packages covering surgeries, medical treatments, day care treatments, diagnostics, and the cost of medicines.
- All pre-existing conditions are covered, and hospitals are prohibited from denying treatment.

- Cashless & Paperless:
- Beneficiaries receive cashless, paperless access to quality healthcare services.
- Hospitals are not allowed to charge additional money for treatments provided under the scheme.

- Support:
- A 24/7 helpline (14555) is available for information, assistance, and grievance redressal.

Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th edition page no 547,660-661

questions.text: Which of the following terms refers to instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
Health Propaganda
Health propaganda refers to the act of instilling a specific point of view in people's minds, often inhibiting independent thought. It involves using information to promote a particular, systematized doctrine related to health.

Approaches to Health Education

1. Regulatory Approach:
Government intervention aimed at altering human behavior. This can range from prohibition to punitive measures, focusing on compliance and behavioral change.

2. Service Approach:
Providing essential health services directly to individuals at their location, based on the belief that accessibility will encourage usage and improve health outcomes.

3. Health Education Approach:
Emphasizes planned learning experiences to inform and empower individuals. This approach encourages people to make informed choices for a healthier life through education and support.

4. Primary Health Care Approach:
Advocates for full community participation and active involvement in the planning and delivery of health services. This approach is rooted in principles of community engagement and intersectoral coordination, aiming for holistic health care delivery.

These approaches collectively aim to enhance public health understanding and promote healthier choices within communities.


Reference:Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 922

questions.text: The Human Developmental Index (HDI) is a composite measure that includes:
questions.solution:
The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic of life expectancy, education, and income indices used to rank countries into four tiers of human development.
 
It consists of three parameters- 
  • A long and healthy life: Life expectancy at birth 
  • Education index: Mean years of schooling and Expected years of schooling
  • A decent standard of living: GNI per capita in purchasing power parity of US dollars.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the calculation of HDI?
questions.solution:
The Human Development Report of 1997 presented a Human Poverty Index (HPI) that amalgamated a variety of elements reflecting the quality of life to accurately judge the magnitude of poverty experienced by a population.
HPI-1's development in less economically developed countries is based on three particular dimensions:
a) life expectancy at birth and the risk of premature mortality,
b) adult literacy rates, and
c) access to adequate sanitary facilities and an appropriate standard of living, as illustrated by the two indicators of the percentage of people not using improved water sources and the percentage of children below their proper weight-for-age.

HDI Components:

1) life expectancy- min of 20 to max of 85 yrs,
2)Expected years of schooling- min is 0 to max of 18,
3) Mean years of schooling -min of zero to max of 15 yrs,
4) GNI per capita- min of 100 and max of 75,000.

questions.text: According to the SDGs, the goal for MMR is to reach maternal mortality rates of:
questions.solution:
• The Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) is an agenda of global goals created by the United Nations in 2015 that outlines a plan of action for countries, international organizations and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to end poverty, protect the environment, and promote peace and prosperity through sustainable development.
  • As part of the SDG 2030, the target for Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is to achieve maternal deaths of no more than 70 per 100,000 live births by 2030. This means that for every 100,000 live births, there should be 70 or fewer maternal deaths.
  • This goal is part of the UN's aim to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio by at least three quarters between 2015 and 2030. This target will help to reduce maternal mortality and ensure better access to healthcare for mothers around the world.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 825.

choices.text: a, b, c and d are correct

questions.text:
How is cause of death noted in India?
a. Sample registration system
b. Census
c. Death declaration and medical certification
d. Lay information
questions.solution:
Causes of death are assessed by-
  • Verbal autopsy: Using death reports and a review of causes,
  • The routine, representative, resampled household interview of mortality with medical evaluation, or RHIME, has improved the equality of cause-of-death information.
  • The death certificate

In India, the cause of death is primarily noted through c. Death declaration and medical certification. This process typically involves medical professionals certifying the cause of death, which is then recorded in official documents.

Additionally, the Sample Registration System (SRS) also plays a role in gathering mortality data, but the direct recording of causes is primarily through medical certification.




Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 968.

questions.text: The Human Development Index consists of:
questions.solution:
Human Development Index (HDI) is an indicator used in assessing the overall well being of a population. It is a geometric mean. It has the following components—

1. Life expectancy at birth.

2. Knowledge—Mean schooling years and Expected years of schooling.

3. Decent Standard of living : Income (Gross National Income per capita).Range of HDI— 0 to 1.

questions.text: Which of the following does not affect the equilibrium in Hardy-Weinberg's law?
questions.solution:
Random mating does not affect the equilibrium in Hardy-Weinberg's law.
  • The Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium is a principle stating that the genetic variation in a population will remain constant from one generation to the next in the absence of disturbing factors.
 
  • Five conditions are required in order for a population to remain at Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium—
• ‚ÄãA large breeding population
•‚Äã Random mating
• ‚ÄãNo change in allelic frequency due to mutation
• No immigration or emigration
•‚Äã No natural selection
 

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardy%E2%80%93Weinberg_principle

questions.text: In order to compare the mortality rates between two nations, direct standardisation is used because of the differences__________ in this is done.
questions.solution:
Direct standardization is used to compare the mortality rates between two countries.
  • This is done because of the difference in age distributions.
  • In the direct standardization method, the rate that we would expect to find in the populations under study if they all had the same composition according to the variable which effect we wish to adjust or control (such as age, socioeconomic group, or other characteristics) is calculated.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which stage of the demographic cycle is characterized by a zero growth rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Fourth stage
 
  • The demographic cycle refers to the different stages of population growth and demographic transition that a country goes through.
  • The model divides population growth into five stages:
  1. Pre-industrial: High birth and death rates, with little to no population growth.
  2. Early expanding: Birth rates remain high, but death rates decline, resulting in rapid population growth.
  3. Late expanding: Birth rates begin to decline, but death rates remain low, resulting in slower population growth.
  4. Low stationary: Birth rates and death rates are both low, resulting in zero population growth.
  5. Decline: Birth rates fall below death rates, resulting in population decline.






Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 554.

questions.text: How much progesterone does Mirena release per day?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 20 µg

Mirena IUD and Levonorgestrel:
  • Mirena, an intrauterine device (IUD), uses synthetic progesterone called levonorgestrel to prevent pregnancy.
  • About 20 µg of levonorgestrel is released daily, effectively stopping pregnancy despite the small dose.

Mechanism:
  • Levonorgestrel in Mirena thickens cervical mucus, making it challenging for sperm to reach eggs.
  • It also thins the uterus lining, reducing chances of egg implantation.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 571.

This can include heavy bleeding, prolonged bleeding, or irregular bleeding.

Other reasons for discontinuing IUCD use include:
  • Pain- most common symptom 
  • Expulsion
  • Infection
  • Unwanted pregnancy

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 572.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ectopic pregnancy risk factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Condom

Ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy that occurs outside of the uterus. It is a serious medical condition that can be life-threatening.
Some risk factors for ectopic pregnancy include:
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Infection
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Endometriosis
  • Tubal ligation
  • Infertility treatment
  • Condoms are not a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy.

Other options:
  • OCP (Birth Control Pills): Birth control pills can lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy, but they do not entirely eliminate the possibility. The overall risk of ectopic pregnancy while on the pill is relatively low.
  • IUD (Intrauterine Device): While rare, IUDs can increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy, especially if they fail to prevent pregnancy, and fertilization occurs outside the uterus.
  • Tubal ligation can also significantly reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy, as it involves blocking or sealing the fallopian tubes to prevent the egg from reaching the uterus, where ectopic pregnancies typically occur.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 573.

questions.text: All of the following indicators represent Human Development Index, Except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Life Expectancy at 1 year of age 

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.
Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:
 
  • A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth
  • Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and
  • A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.





Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 17.

choices.text: Interference with implantation of a fertilized ovum

questions.text: What is not true about the mechanism of action of OCP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Interference with the placenta formation

Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) function: to prevent ovulation, fertilization, and implantation.
OCPs do not interfere with placenta formation.

OCP MOA:
  • Inhibiting ovulation: OCPs contain hormones that halt monthly egg release, preventing fertilization.
  • Preventing fertilization: OCP hormones cause thick, sticky cervical mucus that hampers sperm movement.
  • Interfering with implantation: OCP hormones thin the uterine lining, deterring fertilized egg attachment.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 576.

questions.text: What is the life span of Cu-380?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 10 yrs 
 
  • Cu-380 is a copper-containing intrauterine device (IUD) known for its high effectiveness in contraception, with a failure rate of less than 1%.
  • It releases copper ions that incite an inflammatory response in the uterus, hampering sperm survival and fertilization.
  • Its life span extends to 10 years, rendering replacement unnecessary within this time frame.
  • Over the 10-year span, copper within the IUD may degrade, potentially impacting its contraceptive efficacy.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 571.

  • Until 20 weeks of gestation opinion of one doctor and opinion of two doctors for 20-24 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Except for________, all of the following are dimensions for gender empowerment measures.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Decent Standard of Living
 
  • Gender empowerment measures serve as vital tools to advance gender equality. They aid progress tracking, highlight improvement gaps, and inform policy and program development for gender parity.
  • The four dimensions of gender empowerment measures are:
  1. Political Participation and Decision-making:  women's involvement in politics and decision-making across different levels, local to national.
  2. Economic Participation and Decision-making: Gauges women's engagement in the economy and their authority in economic choices.
  3. Control over Economic Resources: Assesses women's dominance over economic assets like land, property, and income.
  4. Time Allocation: Evaluates women's allocation of time to unpaid responsibilities like caregiving.
  • Decent Standard of Living is not a dimension of gender empowerment measures. It is a measure of poverty, and it does not specifically address gender inequality.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 20.

questions.text: What among the following has nothing to do with Durkheim?
questions.solution:
Emile Durkheim is most known for his theories regarding "functionalism, division of labor, solidarity, and anomie".
  • He theorized that individual behavior is not only influenced by internal factors but also by external societal factors.
  • He is most well known as the author of On the "Division of Social Labor, The Rules of Sociological Method, Suicide, and The Elementary Forms of Religious Life".

Functionalism, in social sciences, is theory based on the premise that all aspects of a society—institutions, roles, norms, etc. —serve a purpose and that all are indispensable for the long-term survival of the society.
Emile Durkheim's theory of suicide defined anomic suicide as resulting from a lack of societal rules and norms. This happens during great social or economic change when people struggle to adjust. They feel overwhelmed and hopeless.


Online reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89mile_Durkheim

questions.text: India is a diverse country with a wealth of different cultures and languages. Correct statement among the following?
questions.solution:
The correct statement among the options provided is:

3. Due emphasis should be given to the patient's cultural background.

India's diversity extends to its cultural and linguistic aspects. When providing healthcare services, it is essential for physicians to recognize and respect the cultural background of their patients. This includes understanding their beliefs, customs, and practices that may impact their healthcare decisions and preferences. By giving due emphasis to a patient's cultural background, healthcare providers can ensure that care is provided in a culturally sensitive and appropriate manner, promoting effective communication and patient-centered care.

questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Infant mortality rate

The infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and quality of primary health services, particularly perinatal care.
  • It is the most important indicator of the health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of mother and child health services in general, which are a core component of primary health services.
  • It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.


Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 622.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate is not a component of the Global Hunger Index (GHI).

Global Hunger Index (GHI): • Dimensions: The GHI is based on three dimensions, each measured by specific indicators:
• PUN: Proportion of the population that is undernourished.
• CWA: Prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age.
• CST: Prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age.
• CM: Proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years.
GHI Calculation:
The GHI score is calculated using the formula:

GHI score=(1/3×standardized PUN)+(1/6×standardized CWA)+(1/6×standardized CST)+(1/3×standardized CM)

Scoring:
• The GHI score ranges from 0 to 100, where 0 indicates no hunger and 100 represents the worst score.
• The GHI is published by the International Food Policy Research Institute.
India's GHI:
• In 2021, India's GHI was 27.5, ranking 101 out of 116 countries.
• In 2022, India's GHI increased to 29.1, with a ranking of 107 out of 121 countries.

questions.text: What is the desirable Total Fertility Rate in India at present?
questions.solution:
The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the average number of children a woman would have during her reproductive years.

Key points:

  • Replacement-level fertility is approximately 2.1, meaning each couple has just enough children to replace themselves in the population without causing population growth.

  • India’s current demographic goal is to achieve TFR ≈ 2.1 to stabilize the population.

  • A TFR >2.1 leads to population growth; <2.1 may eventually cause population decline.

choices.text: Formation, contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution, complete contraction
Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction
Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.text: What is the correct order of a family cycle?
questions.solution:
The family cycle refers to the life cycle of a contractile protein filament (e.g., actin-myosin interaction) or cellular contractile structures, often described in cytology or muscle physiology. The cycle proceeds as:

  1. Formation: Filaments or contractile units assemble.

  2. Extension: Filament or structure elongates.

  3. Complete Extension: Full elongation achieved.

  4. Contraction: Filament begins to shorten, generating force.

  5. Complete Contraction: Maximum shortening achieved.

  6. Dissolution: Filaments disassemble or relax, returning to baseline.

Key concept: This sequential order ensures efficient contraction-relaxation cycles, seen in muscle physiology and cell motility.
