questions.text: A patient presented with diarrhea, irritability and loss of tolerance to heat. Which of the following antibodies is seen in the given disease?
questions.solution:
The patient has heat intolerance associated with diarrhea and irritability.
The image shows a patient with a staring look, likely representing Stellwag’s sign/ Kocher’s sign seen in thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy.
  • Graves’ disease is caused by thyroid stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs) which are synthesized by lymphocytes in the thyroid gland as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes.
  • It is thus characterized as an autoimmune disorder involving the production of autoantibodies against multiple thyroid proteins, most importantly the TSH receptor - TRAb.
  • Lid retraction, causing a staring appearance, can occur in any form of thyrotoxicosis and is the result of sympathetic overactivity.
  • However, Graves’ disease is associated with specific eye signs that comprise Graves’ ophthalmopathy. This condition is also called thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy, because it occurs in the absence of hyperthyroidism in 10% of patients.
  • Most of these individuals have autoimmune hypothyroidism or thyroid antibodies. The onset of Graves’ ophthalmopathy occurs within the year before or after the diagnosis of thyrotoxicosis in 75% of patients but can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis by several years, accounting for some cases of euthyroid ophthalmopathy.

* The “NO SPECS” scoring system to evaluate ophthalmopathy is an acronym derived from the following changes:
0 = No signs or symptoms
1 = Only signs (lid retraction or lag), no symptoms
2 = Soft tissue involvement (periorbital edema)
3 = Proptosis (>22 mm)
4 = Extraocular muscle involvement (diplopia)
5 = Corneal involvement
6 = Sight loss

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2939.

questions.text: The average dietary requirement needed to fulfill the demand of 97.5%of healthy population is known as:
questions.solution:
Answer: 2. Recommended Dietary Allowance

Recommended dietary allowance (RDA) – The RDA is the level of dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the daily nutrient requirements of 97 percent of individuals in a specific life stage group.
It is the average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group. 
RDA presents the level of the nutrient to be consumed daily to meet all the requirements of most of the individuals in a given population. However, it must be recognized that the RDA is not meant to be used as a standard to determine whether or not a given individual requirement has been met, since it is a level above the requirement of most individuals in a given population. RDA value of a nutrient is valid only when all other dietary nutrient intakes are satisfactory.

Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 689.

questions.text: In a village of remote rural areas with poverty, people consume pulses and rice as staple food. Many people presented with spasticity of legs with  crossed lower legs, tip toe walking and walking with sticks. Which of the following can prevent the illness?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Vitamin C

In a poor village with people consuming pulses and rice as staple food suffering from spasticity of legs and gait dysfunction requiring sticks to walk likely suffer from neurolathyrism. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus that contains Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOA).
The condition is believed to be irreversible, in certain cases the damages could be reversed by:
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 
    • Daily administration of 500 mg - 1 gram of ascorbic acid for around 7 days
    • The prevention of the damage has also been demonstrated in guinea pigs and monkeys by the generous provision of ascorbic acid in lathyrogenic diet.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page. No- 702.

choices.text: Aim is to improve Quality of life
Death should neither be prolonged or hastened

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Palliative care?
questions.solution:
Palliative care aims to improve the quality of life.
Most palliative patients have chronic conditions.
Palliative care supports patients and caregiver also.

* Extra Edge:
 

Palliative care is focused on improving quality of life for people with serious illnesses and their care partners. It is available to people of any age who need it, not just older adults. The major elements of palliative care include managing a person’s symptoms effectively and ensuring that their care is coordinated.

Palliative care is interdisciplinary, which means that it involves multiple types of doctors and other care providers. These providers work together with patients and their families and care partners to ensure that the treatment plan reflects the person’s goals and values.

Reference: Temel JS, Greer JA, Muzikansky A, et al. Early palliative care for patients with metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. New England Journal of Medicine 2010; 363(8):733-742.

questions.text: A 60-year-old vegetarian presents with fatigue and weakness that have been present for a few months. On physical examination, pallor is noted. Hemoglobin is 9 g/dL and MCV is increased at 110 fL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 60-year-old vegetarian with fatigue, pallor, anemia (Hb 9 g/dL), and macrocytosis (MCV 110 fL).

Key points:

  • Megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytic anemia (MCV >100 fL) due to impaired DNA synthesis.

  • Common causes: Vitamin B12 deficiency (especially in strict vegetarians) and folate deficiency.

  • Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pallor; may also have neurological signs in B12 deficiency.

  • Lab findings: Macrocytosis, hypersegmented neutrophils, low reticulocyte count.

Other options:

  • Aplastic anemia: Pancytopenia with normocytic or slightly macrocytic RBCs, not specifically high MCV.

  • Iron deficiency anemia: Microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia.

  • Thalassemia: Usually microcytic, hemolytic anemia; not associated with high MCV.

Hence, the most likely diagnosis is megaloblastic anemia, most likely due to vitamin B12 deficiency in this vegetarian patient.

questions.text: A child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around hair follicles and is not allowing anyone to move his limbs because of pain. He also has tender nodules over the chest, as seen in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The child presents with:

  • Pinpoint ecchymoses around hair follicles (perifollicular hemorrhages)

  • Painful limbs (pseudoparalysis)

  • Tender nodules over the chest (subperiosteal hemorrhages, scorbutic rosary)

These are classic features of scurvy (vitamin C deficiency).

Key features of Scurvy:

  • Cause: Deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid) → defective collagen synthesis → weak capillaries and connective tissue

  • Clinical findings:

    • Perifollicular hemorrhages

    • Bleeding gums

    • Subperiosteal hemorrhages → limb pain, pseudoparalysis (“scorbutic rosary”)

    • Anemia and poor wound healing

  • Radiological findings:

    • White line of Fraenkel, Pelkan’s spur, Trümmerfeld zone, Wimberger’s ring sign

questions.text: A patient presented with cheilitis, stomatitis, and a glove and stocking pattern of neuropathy. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The triad of cheilitis (fissures at the lip corners), stomatitis (inflammation of the oral mucosa), and glove-and-stocking neuropathy is characteristic of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

Key clinical features of Vitamin B2 deficiency:

  • Angular cheilitis

  • Glossitis (magenta-colored tongue)

  • Seborrheic dermatitis

  • Photophobia and corneal vascularization

  • Peripheral neuropathy (glove-and-stocking type, due to impaired flavoprotein enzymes in energy metabolism)

Biochemical basis:
Riboflavin is a precursor of FMN (flavin mononucleotide) and FAD (flavin adenine dinucleotide), essential cofactors for redox reactions in the electron transport chain. Its deficiency impairs energy production and affects rapidly dividing tissues.

Differentiation from Other B Vitamins:

  • B1 (Thiamine): Beriberi, Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

  • B3 (Niacin): Pellagra — dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia.

  • B12: Megaloblastic anemia and subacute combined degeneration.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The history and clinical features provided are indicative of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can lead to pellagra, as corn has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Additionally, jowar (sorghum) contains high levels of leucine, which inhibits quinolinic acid phosphoribosyltransferase (QPRTase), an enzyme involved in niacin synthesis.

Niacin deficiency results in a condition known as pellagra, characterized by the classic triad of:
  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia
A notable skin lesion associated with pellagra is the Cassal's necklace pattern, which presents as an erythematous pigmented rash resembling a broad collar, typically affecting the skin in the distribution of the C3 and C4 dermatomes.

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with profuse bleeding after minor trauma (IV cannula removal), which suggests a coagulation defect.

Key points in history:

  • Recent surgery (small bowel resection) → may impair absorption of fat-soluble vitamins.

  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics → disrupt gut flora, which normally synthesizes vitamin K.

  • Vitamin K deficiency leads to defective gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, resulting in bleeding tendency.

    Other options:

  • Niacin (Vitamin B3): Deficiency causes pellagra (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia), not bleeding.

  • Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency causes angular cheilitis, glossitis, ocular changes, not bleeding.

  • Vitamin E: Deficiency can cause neuromuscular symptoms (ataxia, neuropathy), not coagulopathy.

questions.text: Where and how often is the Village Health Nutrition Day conducted?
questions.solution:
Village Health Nutrition Day is held monthly at Anganwadi centers within the village, facilitating direct interaction between villagers and health workers. During these sessions, community members receive essential services and information regarding health care.

The awareness program aims to enhance understanding of health, nutrition, and sanitation among women, children, and the broader community. This regular scheduling fosters ongoing engagement and education on various health topics, including maternal and child health, nutrition, hygiene practices, and disease prevention.

questions.text:
Which among the following is true about keto diet ?
A. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat
B. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
C. Diet should contain 80% fats
D. Diet should contain total 1000 kcal
questions.solution:
According to the FDA, a high-fat diet or keto diet should provide a total of 1000 kcal. These diets are characterized by low carbohydrate intake, less than 50 grams per day, which equates to less than 250 kcal from carbohydrates, not 400 kcal (as mentioned in option B). More than 50% of the calories should come from fats (option C), translating to around 500-600 kcal from fats (option A). The total caloric intake should range between 800 and 1000 kcal.

Ketogenic diets, which are low in carbohydrates (under 50 grams/day), low in protein, and high in fats, rely on fat oxidation and gluconeogenesis from glucogenic amino acids to fulfill the body‘s energy requirements. These diets are particularly effective in managing intractable epilepsy.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Page no 146 .

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding management of snake bite ?
questions.solution:
-Incisions are not part of managing a snake bite. The first aid for a snake bite can be remembered using the mnemonic “carry no right”:

Carry: The victim should not walk, as movement increases muscle activity, which can spread the venom throughout the body.

No: Avoid using a tourniquet, electrotherapy, cutting, pressure immobilization, or suction at the bite site.

R: Reassure the patient, as 70% of snake bites come from non-venomous species.

I: Immobilize the affected limb similar to a fractured limb, using a splint to limit movement and keep it in a neutral position at heart level.

GH: Get the victim to a hospital immediately. Rapid transport to a medical facility with the capability to provide appropriate care is crucial.

T: Inform the doctor of any systemic symptoms that have developed while en route to the hospital.


Note that for envenomations from elapid snakes, which are mainly neurotoxic with minimal local tissue effects, pressure immobilization may be used. This involves wrapping the entire limb with a bandage to limit lymphatic drainage and delay venom absorption. However, this technique should only be applied if the snake has been identified as neurotoxic and the rescuer is trained in the procedure.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3597,3598 .

questions.text: The incisors of a child who had white patches on them which later turned brown are due to excessive supplementation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The provided scenario describes dental fluorosis, a condition caused by excessive fluoride supplementation.

Key Points about Dental Fluorosis:
Definition: Dental fluorosis is characterized by mottling of tooth enamel resulting from the ingestion of excessive fluoride during the calcification of teeth in childhood.
Causes: It typically occurs when drinking water contains high levels of fluoride, specifically in the range of 3-5 mg/L. Certain regions in India, such as Andhra Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu, experience endemic fluorosis.
Presentations of Fluorosis:

1. Dental Fluorosis (at 1.5 mg/L):
Most evident on upper incisors and permanent teeth.
Mottling of dental enamel occurs, resulting in chalky-white patches that lose their shiny luster.
The white spots can progress to yellow, brown, or black discolorations, giving the teeth a corroded appearance.

2.Skeletal Fluorosis (at 3-6 mg/L):
Characterized by heavy fluoride deposition in bones, stimulating osteoblastic activity and affecting bone turnover.
It can lead to osteoporosis due to increased osteoclast activity and may cause ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments.

3.Crippling Fluorosis (at >10 mg/L):
Can result in permanent disability, often involving skeletal deformities.

Newer Forms of Fluorosis:
Conditions such as genu valgum and lower limb osteoporosis may arise, particularly in individuals consuming jowar (sorghum), which increases fluoride retention.

Recommendations:
Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children in endemic areas who consume fluoridated water or use fluoride toothpaste.
Interventions for Fluorosis:
Change in Water Source: Switch to drinking water with lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Surface water often contains less fluoride compared to groundwater.
Chemical Treatment: Utilize techniques like the Nalgonda technique in water treatment plants, which involves lime and alum to reduce fluoride levels.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes xeropthalmia, a condition which causes dry eyes?
questions.solution:
Xerophthalmia, which initially manifests as dry eyes, is caused by a deficiency of vitamin A.

Vitamin A plays a crucial role in maintaining healthy vision, particularly in the function of the retina and the production of tears.

Clinical features of vitamin A deficiency may progress from dry eyes to more severe ocular conditions, such as:
  • Night blindness
  • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • Corneal ulcers or scarring
Early recognition and treatment of vitamin A deficiency can help prevent long-term complications, including blindness.

questions.text: What is the target Maternal mortality rate and neonatal mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 ?
questions.solution:
The target, maternal mortality rate and neonatal mortality rate to be achieved by 2030 is 70/100,000 live births and 12/1000 live births respectively .

Ref- Parks textbook of PSM 25th edition page 523-524

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding BCG vaccine?
questions.solution:
BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine.
The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable. The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally.
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition • Page 231, 232

questions.text: Recommended daily protein intake (high quality) for an adult male weighing 55 kg is
questions.solution:
The 2007 FAO/WHO standards state that people should consume 0.83 g/kg of protein per day. This corresponds to roughly 46 g of protein per day (55 x 0.83 g) for a 55 kg male. On the other hand, adult men and women who consume a mixed Indian cuisine are recommended to meet a daily protein requirement of 1 g/kg according to the 2010 ICMR guidelines.

Nutritional Reference Amounts

The term "recommended dietary allowance" (RDA) refers to the average daily consumption that is sufficient to meet almost all members of a given group's nutritional needs.

The term "estimated average requirement" (EAR) refers to a level of nutritional intake that is predicted to meet the needs of half of the members of a group.

The EAR for energy for senior individuals over 60 is 1700.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, p. 692.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a part of urban health care system?
questions.solution:
In the urban health care system, the tiers include:

  • Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) – First point of contact in urban areas

  • Community Health Centre (CHC)/Urban Community Health Centre – Provides specialist care and referral services

  • District Hospital – Provides secondary and tertiary care

Subcenters are part of the rural health care system, serving as the first contact in villages. They are not included in the urban health care setup.

Other options:

  • Primary healthcare center: Urban equivalent → part of urban health care

  • Community healthcare centre: Part of urban referral system

  • District Hospital: Part of tertiary urban care


Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - Page no 502

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with complaints of bleeding gums. Blood investigations showed iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with bleeding gums along with iron deficiency anemia.

  • Bleeding gums and easy bruising are classic features of scurvy, which is caused by vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency.

  • Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to fragile capillaries, causing gum bleeding.

  • Iron deficiency anemia may coexist due to poor dietary intake.

Other options:

  • Vitamin A: Deficiency causes night blindness, xerophthalmia, not bleeding gums.

  • Vitamin D: Deficiency causes rickets/osteomalacia, not gum bleeding.

  • Vitamin B1 (thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi or Wernicke’s encephalopathy, not bleeding gums.



Reference: Nelson's textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 388

questions.text: Identify the given logo below:
questions.solution:
The Bureau of Indian Standards is identified by the given logo.

The BIS Act of 2016 established the National Standard Body of India (BIS) with the aim of promoting the harmonious growth of the standardization, marking, and quality certification of goods operations.

Through standardization, certification, and testing, BIS has been able to control the proliferation of varieties, minimize health hazards to consumers, promote export and import substitutes, and provide traceability and tangibility benefits to the national economy in a number of ways.

Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Pg:402

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given: should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 10th standard. What is this health worker called?
questions.solution:
An ASHA worker is a trained female community health activist who:

  • Is a woman resident of the village

  • Aged between 25 to 45 years

  • Has formal education up to at least 8th or 10th standard

  • Is married/divorced/widowed, preferably with children (so she is familiar with maternal and child health issues)

    Role of ASHA:

  • Acts as a link between the community and health services

  • Promotes maternal and child health

  • Encourages institutional deliveries

  • Educates on family planning, immunization, sanitation, and nutrition

    Why not the others?

  • Nurse: Requires formal nursing training and registration, not limited to village residents.

  • Anganwadi worker: Works under the ICDS scheme, mainly for nutrition and preschool education, not primarily a health activist.

  • Midwife: Trained in childbirth assistance, often more technically skilled, not selected based on residency or age criteria like ASHA.


Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 959

questions.text: An 8 months old baby on examination shows signs of Vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of Vitamin A to be administered to the baby?
questions.solution:
The treatment of Vitamin A deficiency is age-specific and the dosage is given according to WHO and IAP (Indian Academy of Pediatrics) guidelines.

For a child aged 6–11 months:

The recommended dose of Vitamin A for treatment is:

  • 100,000 IU orally, given immediately,

  • Repeat the same dose on Day 2,

  • A third dose after 2 weeks, if needed (depending on severity).

    Summary of Therapeutic Doses (WHO Guidelines):

Age Vitamin A Therapeutic Dose (oral)
<6 months 50,000 IU
6–11 months 1,00,000 IU
≥12 months (1 year +) 200,000 IU

  • Oral route is preferred due to better absorption and ease of administration, especially in public health settings.

  • IM (intramuscular) Vitamin A is not routinely recommended for deficiency treatment — it's considered only when oral administration is not possible (e.g., severe vomiting, malabsorption).



Reference: Comprehensive opthalmology by AK khurana 6th edition page no 469

questions.text: If Bajra is mixed with black seeds, what is used to separate it?
questions.solution:
When Bajra (pearl millet) is mixed with black seeds (often weed seeds or other unwanted seeds), separation is done based on difference in specific gravity using salt water flotation.

  • 20% salt water is used because:

    • Bajra (heavier) sinks.

    • Black seeds (lighter, low density) float.

This method is commonly used in seed processing to purify crop seeds by removing lighter contaminants.

Incorrect Options:

  • Normal saline (0.9% NaCl) and water: Too dilute — no effective separation.

  • 10% salt water: Might not be dense enough to float all light contaminants.

Hence, 20% salt solution is ideal for separating Bajra from black seeds.


Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 24th edition page no 695

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to you for advice regarding his diet. You advise him to include foods with a low glycemic index in the diet. Which of the following would you advise him for the same?
questions.solution:
In diabetics, low glycemic index (GI) foods are preferred as they cause a slower and smaller rise in blood glucose levels.

Let’s assess the options:

Food Item Glycemic Index Comment
Papaya Low (~60) Good choice for diabetics
Brown rice Medium (~68–72) Better than white rice, but not low
Sucrose High (~65) Simple sugar, not recommended
Corn flakes High (~80–85) Causes rapid glucose spike

Papaya is a low GI fruit rich in fiber and antioxidants, making it suitable for diabetics.



Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 671

questions.text: Highest Sodium content is present in which of the following foods:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, canned soup contains the highest sodium content due to added salt (sodium chloride) used as a preservative and flavoring agent.

Comparison:

Food Item Sodium Content Remarks
Barley Low (~9 mg/100g) Naturally low in sodium
Canned soup High (~300–900 mg per serving) Due to preservatives and salt
Sugar cane Very low Naturally low in sodium
Fresh fruit juices Low (~1–10 mg/100 ml) No added salt

Processed foods like canned soup are a major dietary source of excess sodium, increasing the risk of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases.
Reference Online Resource - https://www.cdc.gov/salt/food.htm

choices.text: It involves mixing the waste with cement before disposal

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about inertization.
questions.solution:
In order to reduce the chance that harmful materials included in the wastes may migrate into the surface water or groundwater, the process of "inertization" is done.
  • It entails mixing trash with cement and other materials before disposal.
  • It decreases the chances of water pollution, not increase it. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text: Which natural disaster is responsible for the most fatalities?
questions.solution:
• Hydrological disasters, such as floods, storm surges, and mudslides, are among the most destructive and far-reaching natural disasters due to their widespread impact. Unlike earthquakes or volcanic eruptions, which can be very localized, hydrological disasters affect a large area and can cause significant long-term damage.
  • In addition to the physical damage they can cause to infrastructure, hydrological disasters can destroy crops, destroy homes and businesses, and create dangerous conditions such as contaminated drinking water and the spread of waterborne diseases.
  • Hydrological disasters can also cause psychological damage, as the disruption to people’s livelihoods can be devastating. Furthermore, their unpredictability and wide-ranging effects often make them difficult to prepare for. This can lead to a wide-spread loss of life and further economic hardship.
  • Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 922.

questions.text: According to the triage system used in disaster management, which of the following color codes and explanations matches correctly?
questions.solution:
A quick classification of the injured based on the seriousness of their conditions and their chances of survival is called triage.
The second priority color is yellow, and if the patient is stable, observation is needed.

Triage classification:
 
  • Red color : First priority and signifies a critical patient
  • Yellow color : Urgent, second priority
  • Green color : Minor injuries, ambulatory patient, third priority
  • Black color : Expectant or dead patients.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive indication of an iodine shortage in the environment?
questions.solution:
Urinary iodine excretion is the principal impact indicator and neonatal hypothyroidism rates is  the most sensitive indicators. 

Following indicators are useful in assessment of iodine deficiency:
  • prevalence of goitre
  • prevalence of cretinism
  • urinary iodine excretion
  • measurement of thyroid function.
  • prevalence of neonatal hypothyroidism

Since, the objective of goitre control program is to increase iodine intake ,indices of urinary excretion are particularly recommended for use in surveillance.


 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 739.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot cause an epidemic in the post-disaster period?
questions.solution:
• Leishmaniasis is not a cause of epidemic after a disaster.
        As all of the other options has risk factors that increases due to disaster.
 
  • The strategies for avoiding and curbing the spread of communicable illnesses in the wake of a disaster can be summarized as follows:
  • (a) Establish immediately all necessary public health procedures to reduce the risk of disease transmission.
  • (b) Establish an efficient illness notification protocol to detect outbreaks and begin control measures quickly.
  • (c) Execute detailed investigations for all reported cases of illness quickly.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 925.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common cause of epidemics after a disaster?
questions.solution:
Leishmaniasis is not a common cause of epidemic after a disaster.
  • In the immediate aftermath of a disaster, acute respiratory infections are more prevalent among the displaced population.
  • It may take many weeks for the prevalence of vector-borne diseases to reach epidemic levels.
  • The risk of zoonoses spreading increases when domestic and wild animals are relocated. Some of these animals might act as reservoirs for diseases including rickettsiosis and leptospirosis.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 925.

questions.text: Insecticides that are classified as highly harmful by the WHO are coded as?

Is concerned with psychology of individuals living in the society
Changes in disease pathology due to social factors

questions.text: What does social pathology deals with?
questions.solution:
The meaning of social pathology has shifted over time, now including the concept of how diseases can be related to certain social conditions.
Recent research has highlighted the link between social pathology and illnesses such as accidents, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and chronic bronchitis.

This analysis is done through 'social surveys', a process of looking at how social situations can impact the health and well-being of certain individuals and populations.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 788.

choices.text: Probability at birth of not surviving till age 40 years
Percentage of population not using an improved water sources

questions.text: All of the following are included in the human poverty index (HPI), with the exception of:
questions.solution:
HPI for developing countries includes-
1. Probability at birth of not surviving to age 40.
2. Adult literacy rate
3. Unweighted average of two indicators:
  • % population not using improved water source
  • % children underweight for age
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 816.

questions.text: Due to exposure to _____, cutis marmorata develops.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Cold temperature.
  • Cutis marmorata is a benign finding in a newborn. It refers to the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of skin (reticular pattern) due to dilatation of superficial capillaries and veins that occur due to cooler surrounding temperature.
  • It is seen throughout infancy and in 50% of children. It is caused by simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries.
  • Rewarming restores the skin to normal.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 609.

questions.text: All of the following are Synthetic Pyrethroid Compound, except:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: DDT.
 
  • Synthetic Pyrethroids are a class of insecticides that are modeled after the natural pyrethrins derived from chrysanthemum flowers.
  • Synthetic pyrethroids are widely used for their effectiveness against a broad spectrum of insects and their low toxicity to humans and other mammals.
  • DDT, on the other hand, is not a synthetic pyrethroid but rather an organochlorine insecticide.
  • DDT was widely used in the past but has been banned or restricted in many countries due to its persistence in the environment and potential harm to wildlife and human health.
Synthetic insecticides:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 909.

questions.text: Which of the aforementioned is a form of chlorination that is active?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Hypochlorous acid.
 
  • Chlorination is a common method used to disinfect water and eliminate harmful microorganisms.
  • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
    • HOCl → H + OCl
  • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
  • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 841.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to water hardness?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Calcium carbonate. Calcium carbonate does not cause hardness of water. Hardness of water is caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Water hardness is determined by the concentration of calcium and magnesium ions in water.


There are two types of hardness of water:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 853, 854.

questions.text: Maximum labour hours under the factories act, including overtime:
questions.solution:
Under Factories Act,
  • upto 48 hours/week (9 hours/day) allowed, however after overtime hours maximum limit is 60 hours/week (12 hours/day including 4 hours/day overtime). 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 942.

choices.text: Vaccination against typhoid and cholera in community
Vaccination against tetanus, typhoid and cholera for health workers

questions.text: Vaccine to given after disaster:
questions.solution:
Vaccination against tetanus, typhoid, and cholera is important for health workers after natural disasters as it reduces the risk of these diseases spreading through an already weakened and vulnerable population.
  • After disasters, clean water sources can be contaminated with bacteria and viruses, leading to outbreaks of these diseases.
  • Vaccination reduces the risk of contracting any of these illnesses and restricts the spread in communities that have already suffered from the disaster.
  • Additionally, it helps protect health workers from becoming infected and spreading the disease to those who are already vulnerable.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 924.

questions.text: Which of the following is a strategy or method that is based on behavioural sciences?
questions.solution:
• Management by objectives (MBO) is a behavioural science-based technique used by managers to set and pursue goals.
  • The technique focuses on aligning individual goals and expectations with the company's organisational goals and objectives, encouraging individuals to become involved in the decision-making process and encouraging them to take ownership of the results.
MBO is an ongoing feedback-based process that involves the following steps:
 

1. Establish goals: Prioritise organisational goals and instructions, design measurable objectives and challenge objectives for each employee.

 

2. Participation: Involvement of employees in setting goals, as well as in the decision-making process helps to ensure that individual goals remain realistic, achievable and are properly aligned with organisational objectives.

 

3. Feedback: Ongoing evaluation of progress with regular feedback from employees and managers helps to reinforce the goal-setting process and ensure employees remain motivated and keep progressing.

 

4. Measurement: Clear criteria must be established to measure the success of the objectives in order to allow for meaningful feedback and assessment.

 

5. Rewards: Rewards should be offered to encourage employees to reach goals, and motivate them to continue working towards organisational objectives.

 

MBO is an effective tool to optimize productivity, performance and motivation. By understanding the individual performance and linking it to the objectives of the organisation, managers can foster a better understanding of their employees and promote collaboration, growth and success.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 999.

questions.text:
The most effective way to regularly check air pollution
1. CO + CH3 + CFC
2. H2S
3. Suspended particles
4. SO2 + Dust and smoke
questions.solution:
• Best indicator of air pollution are SO2 + Dust and smoke.
  • Sulfur dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, and carbon monoxide are all highly toxic gases that can be released into the atmosphere by industrial processes and combustion sources such as vehicle exhaust and power plants.
  • These gases act as indicators of air pollution because they are toxic, easy to detect, and generally more common in polluted air as compared to clean air.
  • Once released into the atmosphere, these gases can react with natural compounds in the air and form secondary pollutants such as ground-level ozone, acid rain, and fine particulate matter.
  • These pollutants pose a significant health risk by exacerbating respiratory and other illnesses like asthma.
  • In addition, sulfur dioxide, hydrogen sulfide, and carbon monoxide are also both greenhouse gases, further increasing their importance as indicators of air pollution.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 863.

questions.text: A chart showing the post-Diwali air pollution index was made. Plots were made of the air quality index values for 4 separate days. Which level of air pollution is indicated by an AQI rating of 407?
questions.solution:
AQI 470 indicates severe air pollution

Classification of AQI:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 863.

questions.text: In Kerala, after flood, people were complaining of fever. Doxycycline prophylactically distributed, along with it which insecticide is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: ZINC PHOSPHIDE
 
  • In Kerala, people experiencing fever after food consumption are suspected to have ingested contaminated food, possibly contaminated with rodent droppings.
  • To prevent the spread of foodborne diseases, prophylactic distribution of doxycycline, an antibiotic, is given to potentially affected individuals.
  • In addition to the antibiotic, Zinc phosphide is the preferred insecticide used for controlling rodent populations in the affected area.
  • Zinc phosphide is a rodenticide used to kill animals like mice and rats. It is a highly toxic compound and can produce toxicity by oral ingestion, inhalation, and through damaged skin.
Acute or single-dose rodenticides are classified according to the precautions that need to be taken before their use:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 913.

questions.text: Due to exposure to_______, farmer's lung develops.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Thermoactinomyces sacchari.
 
  • Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Thermoactinomyces sp. like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula (formerly known as Micropolyspora faeni).
  • It occurs due to inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction.
  • Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism. The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis. If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 934.

questions.text: Except for_______, all of the strategies listed below are antilarval defences.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Malathion.
 
  • Malathion is an insecticide used for adult mosquito control and is not considered an antilarval defense.
  • The other options (Intermittent irrigation, Paris green, and Gambusia affinis) are strategies used to control mosquito larvae, which are the immature stages of mosquitoes.
  • Intermittent irrigation is a technique where water is periodically drained from breeding sites, disrupting the mosquito life cycle.
  • Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.
  • The larvivorous fishes that can be used for biological control include:
    • Gambusia affinis
    • Lebister reticulatus (Barbados Millions)
    • Poecilia 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 898.

questions.text: Which triage category is designated for ambulatory walking wounded patients?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Green.
 
  • Triage is the process of sorting patients based on the severity of their condition to prioritize medical care during mass casualty incidents or disasters.
  • The Green triage category is designated for "walking wounded" or ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses that do not require immediate medical attention.
  • These patients can be treated on-site or referred to less critical areas for medical evaluation and care.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 923.

questions.text: For casual reading, what level of illumination (lux) is advised:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: 100.
 
  • For casual reading or general indoor activities, a recommended level of illumination is around 100 lux.
  • Lux is a unit of measurement for illuminance, which is the amount of light falling on a surface.
  • Adequate lighting is important for reading and other activities to reduce eye strain and ensure a comfortable environment.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 868.

questions.text: Which of the following trace element deficiencies and the clinical syndrome are not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Zinc - Night Blindness.
The other options are all correctly matched.
 
  • Zinc deficiency can cause a number of health problems, including growth retardation, impaired immune function, and diarrhea. 
  • However, night blindness is not a symptom of zinc deficiency. Night blindness is caused by a deficiency of vitamin A.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. 
  • Fluoride deficiency can cause dental caries
  • Chromium deficiency can cause glucose intolerance, and
  • Selenium deficiency can cause cardiomyopathy.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 756.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is recommended in a case where a sewage worker presents to the Emergency department with fever and jaundice. Laboratory findings reveal an elevated BUN and serum creatinine suggestive of renal failure. Which of the following antibiotics is recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Penicillin G.
 
  • In this scenario, a sewage worker presenting with fever and jaundice and laboratory findings suggestive of renal failure raises suspicion of leptospirosis, a bacterial infection caused by the Leptospira interrogans
  • Leptospirosis is commonly transmitted through contact with water or soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals, and sewage workers are at increased risk.
  • The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 339.

questions.text: What does the Ortho toluidine test detect?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Chlorines.
 
  • Ortho toluidine test is used to measure the free and combined chlorines present in the water. 
  • A reading within the first 10 seconds signifies free chlorine, while a reading taken after 15 minutes signifies the total amount of chlorines in the water (free and combined). 
  • Ortho toluidine -arsenite test is able to measure the free and combined chlorines separately in the water.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 842.

questions.text: Which is the least likely causes of indoor air pollution ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Mercury vapour.
 
  • Mercury vapor is not typically a common cause of indoor air pollution.
  • Indoor air pollution is primarily caused by various factors such as cooking, heating, smoking, use of certain household products, and building materials that release harmful pollutants like carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and particulate matter.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 860.

questions.text: If the water's Level of Hardness is 50–150 mg/L, how would you categorise it?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Moderately hard water.
 
  • Water hardness is determined by the concentration of calcium and magnesium ions in water.
  • A water hardness level of 50-150 mg/L is considered to be in the range of moderately hard water.
  • Moderately hard water may have some hardness effects, such as scaling in pipes and reduced soap lathering, but it is generally suitable for most domestic purposes.


There are two types of hardness of water:


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 853, 854.

questions.text: Green color in triage indicates:
questions.solution:
Green color in triage includes ambulatory patients.

Triage colour coding:





Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 449.

questions.text:
You are posted as a Medical Officer in a PHC in a seismic area. To handle emergencies, which of the following actions will you take? 
A. Preparedness to handle any emergency 
B. Ensure resources and funds are available for quick mobilization at the time of emergency 
C. Disaster simulation programs 
D. Give instructions over loudspeakers

1- A,B,C,D
2-B,C,D
3-A,B,C
4-A,B,D
questions.solution:
Steps 1,2 and 3 are done as part of preparedness for an emergency in a high seismic zone. 

Giving instructions over phone is done when the emergency strikes and not a part disaster preparedness.
 

To handle emergencies effectively in a seismic area, the following actions are essential:

  • Preparedness to handle any emergency (A): Being ready with plans, protocols, and resources to address emergencies is crucial in such high-risk areas.
  • Ensure resources and funds are available for quick mobilization (B): Proper allocation of resources and funds ensures a swift response when emergencies occur.
  • Disaster simulation programs (C): Regular training and simulation exercises help staff and the community stay prepared for real-life scenarios.
 

While giving instructions over loudspeakers (D) might be useful during an actual disaster, it is not a key preparatory action. Hence, it is not included in the best choice for overall emergency readiness.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 926, 927.

questions.text: An army recruit presented with myalgia, fever and rashes. There were no rashes on palms and soles. Many soldiers from his battalion were found to be infested with louse. What could be the causative organism related to his clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of epidemic or louse borne typhus which is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. 
 
  • Rickettsia prowazekii causes epidemic typhus, a disease transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Epidemic typhus typically presents with fever, myalgia, and a maculopapular rash, which commonly spares the palms and soles.
  • The context of many soldiers being infested with lice strongly suggests a louse-borne illness.
 

Other options:

  • Rickettsia typhi: Causes endemic (murine) typhus, which is transmitted by fleas, not lice.
  • Rickettsia tsutsugamushi: Causes scrub typhus, which is transmitted by chiggers (mite larvae) and is more common in rural and scrubland areas.
  • Rickettsia conorii: Causes Mediterranean spotted fever, transmitted by dog ticks, and its rash often involves the palms and soles.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 414.

Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition, Page no 358, 359.

  • large in culex
  • shorter in aedes


Comparison of different mosquitoes:

questions.text: Which among the following does not require a comprehensive Geriatric evaluation?
questions.solution:
Age, history of falls and episodes of confusion require a comprehensive geriatric assessment.

Comprehensive geriatric assessment (CGA) is the most comprehensively researched model for healthcare delivery to frail older patients. It has been shown, through a series of high-quality research studies and subsequent meta-analyses, to deliver measurable health improvements for frail older people. Although it is well understood by specialists in care of older people, it remains unrecognised by many non-specialists. Because it is a multifaceted complex intervention, whose title and acronym do not convey its full meaning, it may be misunderstood by those unfamiliar with it.

Reference: Welsh TJ, Gordon AL, Gladman JR. Comprehensive geriatric assessment--a guide for the non-specialist. Int J Clin Pract. 2014 Mar;68(3):290-3. doi: 10.1111/ijcp.12313. Epub 2013 Oct 7. PMID: 24118661; PMCID: PMC4282277.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to kill the larvae of mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Gambusia fish, commonly known as mosquito fish, are effective biological control agents for eliminating mosquito larvae in water bodies. By feeding on these larvae, they help reduce mosquito populations, aiding in overall mosquito control efforts.

Comparison with Other Mosquito Control Methods:
Option (d): Indoor sprays are designed to repel or kill adult mosquitoes, not specifically targeting larvae.

Option (a): Mosquito nets provide a physical barrier to prevent bites from mosquitoes but do not address the larvae in water sources.

Option (b): Repellents are applied to the skin or clothing to deter mosquitoes from biting, but they do not eliminate larvae in water.

In summary, Gambusia fish directly target mosquito larvae, while other methods focus on preventing adult mosquito bites or managing existing populations.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument which is used to measure air humidity. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, which is used to measure the humidity or moisture content in the air.

The Sling Psychrometer consists of two mercury thermometers: one for the wet bulb and one for the dry bulb. To use it, the wet bulb is first moistened with distilled water, and then the instrument is whirled while standing with the back to the sun. The readings are taken twice.

After taking the readings for the wet bulb, the dry bulb reading is then noted. The relative humidity is calculated using appropriate tables and charts based on these measurements.

questions.text: After a war, the residents of that region were shifted to another area. Which of the following latrines would be suitable in this condition?
questions.solution:
Methods of Excreta Disposal:

Unsewered Areas
1. Service Type Latrines (Conservancy System): Nightsoil is manually collected and disposed off through burial or composting.
2. Non-Service Type Latrines (Sanitary Latrines):
• Borehole Latrine: A latrine with a deep hole to collect waste.
• Dug Well or Pit Latrine: A latrine with a shallow or deep pit to collect waste.
• Water-Seal Latrines: Latrines that use water to seal the waste from the surrounding environment (e.g., PRAI, RCA, Sulabh Shauchalaya).
• Septic Tanks: Tanks that use bacteria to decompose waste.
• Aqua Privy: A latrine that uses water to flush waste into a pit.
• Latrines for Camps and Temporary Use: Temporary latrine solutions designed for specific needs.

Sewered Areas
Water Carriage System and Sewage Treatment:
• Primary Treatment: Removal of solids and grit from wastewater.
• Secondary Treatment: Biological breakdown of organic matter in wastewater.
• Other Methods: Disposal of treated wastewater into bodies of water, agricultural land, or through oxidation ponds.

questions.text: Which of the following steps of disaster management is in correct order?
questions.solution:
Disaster management involves a systematic approach to reduce the impact of disasters and restore normalcy. The correct sequence of steps is:

  1. Disaster Impact: The event occurs causing destruction, loss of life, or disruption.

  2. Response: Immediate actions to save lives, provide medical aid, and protect property.

  3. Rehabilitation: Restoration of normal life, including rebuilding infrastructure, healthcare, and livelihoods.

  4. Mitigation: Long-term measures to reduce future disaster risk, such as planning, education, and structural interventions.

Incorrect sequences fail to respect the logical temporal flow from occurrence → immediate response → recovery → prevention.

questions.text: During a vaccination drive, a male patient asks the presiding doctor if the recommended vaccine can lead to impotency. What type of barrier will the doctor be addressing?
questions.solution:
In this case, the doctor is addressing a cultural barrier.

The patient believes that vaccination might cause impotence, which likely stems from his personal beliefs, understanding, or knowledge regarding vaccines, all of which are aspects of a cultural barrier.

Communication failures between healthcare providers and communities can impact health education, counseling, and motivation. These barriers can be categorized as:

1. Physiological barriers, such as hearing or speech difficulties.

2. Psychological barriers, including emotional issues, neuroses, varying levels of intelligence, and language or comprehension difficulties.

3. Environmental barriers, such as noise, poor visibility, or overcrowding.

4. Cultural barriers, which encompass factors like illiteracy, limited knowledge, customs, beliefs, religious views, attitudes, socioeconomic differences, and language or cultural variations.

questions.text: The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom should be
questions.solution:
Per capita space for students in a classroom should be 10 square feet.
A healthful school environment includes the following features:
  • Location: Accessible by proper roads and situated away from noisy surroundings.
  • Site: 5 acres for primary schools; 10 acres for higher elementary schools.
  • Structure: Exterior walls should be at least 10 inches thick and heat-resistant.
  • Classroom: Maximum of 40 students per classroom; Per capita space should be greater than 10 square feet.
  • Furniture: Minus-type desks with proper back-rests.
  • Doors and windows: The total area of doors and windows should be more than 25% of the floor area.
  • Wall color: The inside walls should be painted white.
  • Lighting: Natural light should come from the sides, not from the front.
  • Water supply: Safe, potable, and continuous water supply through taps.
  • Lavatory: 1 urinal per 60 students and 1 latrine per 100 students.

questions.text: A surveyor visits a household consisting of a 35-year-old man, his wife who is 6 weeks pregnant and a 3-year-old child. The man's brother along with his wife is currently visiting them for a month owing to winter vacation. What type of family would the surveyor classify the household?
questions.solution:
A surveyor would classify this household as a nuclear family.

A nuclear (or elementary) family includes a married couple and their children, as long as the children are considered dependents. In this type of family, visitors may come and go, but they do not live permanently in the household or share common property, which are characteristics of a joint or extended family.

In a joint or extended family, several married couples and their children live together in the same household, sharing common property. The senior male member of the family is typically regarded as the head.

A third-generation family includes three generations of direct descendants living in the same house. This setup often occurs when young couples continue living with their parents while raising their own children.

questions.text:
A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?
RIG- Rabies immunoglobulin
questions.solution:
This patient should receive 2 doses of the vaccine on days 0 and 3, as he has received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) more than 3 months ago.

In India, monkeys are recognized as potential transmitters of rabies. Therefore, the national rabies control program recommends a complete course of PEP for individuals bitten by monkeys. Since this patient was bitten by a monkey 6 months ago, he would have received PEP for rabies.

The management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual (who has had either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)) is as follows:

Category I: Only wound treatment is required.

Category II/III:
Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes, followed by the application of an antiseptic.
Administer Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV): 2 doses via intradermal (ID) route (0.1 ml at 1 site) or 2 doses via intramuscular (IM) route (1 vial at 1 site) on days 0 and 3.
Rabies immunoglobulin is not administered for any category if the individual has completed a full course of PEP.

Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals does not significantly influence the decision to initiate prophylaxis in humans.

questions.text: Giving class in a village for wound care after a dog bite by enacting it is which mode of health communication?
questions.solution:
The most effective way to conduct a class on wound care after a dog bite in a village setting is through demonstration.

Demonstration serves as a group-oriented approach to health communication, where the audience learns how to implement the advice by observing it being enacted. In this method, the procedure is carried out step by step in front of the audience or target group. This approach can facilitate behavioral changes in practices by generating interest and engagement.

Other options:

  • Lecture: One-way communication, teacher talks, audience listens.

  • Group discussion: Interactive, exchange of ideas among participants.

  • Flash cards: Visual aids for health education.

questions.text: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?
questions.solution:
Establishing tobacco control laws serves as a method of primary prevention.

These laws specifically target smokers who are already at risk but have not yet developed any tobacco-related diseases. The primary goal is to reduce smoking rates, which effectively decreases the associated risk factors—an essential aspect of primary prevention strategies.

Primary prevention is defined as actions taken before the onset of a disease, aimed at preventing its occurrence. The target population for these interventions consists of healthy individuals. Primary prevention typically includes activities designed to limit risk exposure or enhance the immunity of individuals at risk to prevent disease progression.

Approaches to primary prevention can include:
  • Population (mass) strategy: This targets the entire population.
  • High-risk strategy: This focuses on individuals who are most at risk of developing a particular disease.

questions.text: Hand washing during COVID-19 is what level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Hand washing during COVID-19 is a form of primary prevention.

COVID-19 is an infectious respiratory illness caused by the coronavirus. Infection control measures, including immunization, hand washing, personal hygiene, and public health initiatives such as sanitation, collectively form a comprehensive primary prevention strategy.

Primary prevention refers to actions taken before the onset of a disease, with the goal of preventing its occurrence. This strategy targets healthy individuals and typically involves activities that either limit exposure to risk factors or enhance immunity in individuals at risk, preventing disease progression. The approaches can be categorized as follows:

Population (mass) strategy: This targets the entire population to implement broad prevention measures.
High-risk strategy: This focuses on individuals who are at the greatest risk of developing a specific disease.

choices.text: It aids in developing a reflective behavior

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about health propaganda?
questions.solution:
• Health propaganda = method of health communication that is emotion-centered, not knowledge-centered.

  • It uses emotional appeal, slogans, posters, and persuasive messages to influence behavior quickly.

  • Other options:

    • Behavior-centered: Describes health education, not propaganda.

    • Developing reflective behavior: Achieved by health education (critical thinking).

    • Actively acquired: Again a feature of health education, while propaganda is passively received.

So, health propaganda = appeals to emotions.

questions.text: The process in the oxidation pond is
questions.solution:
Oxidation ponds (also known as stabilization ponds or lagoons) are used in sewage and industrial waste treatment. They are shallow, open pools that typically measure around 1-1.5 meters in depth, and they rely on the interaction of algae, saprophytic bacteria, and sunlight to treat waste.

Process:
The organic matter in the sewage or waste is broken down by bacteria, producing carbon dioxide, ammonia, and water. The algae in the pond use these products for growth through photosynthesis, with the help of sunlight, which in turn helps maintain the oxygen balance in the system.

During the day, when sunlight is available, aerobic conditions predominate, as the algae produce oxygen for the bacteria to break down organic matter. This oxygen sustains aerobic bacteria in the breakdown process.

At night, when photosynthesis ceases, the oxygen levels drop, and anaerobic conditions can develop, especially in the deeper layers of the pond. The bottom layers are more likely to remain anaerobic during nighttime hours.

Effluent Use:
The effluent from oxidation ponds can be used for land irrigation or forwarded for further treatment depending on the quality of the treated water.
This cyclical aerobic and anaerobic process helps in the natural breakdown of waste, providing a cost-effective method of sewage treatment, especially in areas with sufficient land and sunlight.

questions.text: Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used to evaluate
questions.solution:
Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is indeed a valuable metric used to evaluate their health.
Sickness absenteeism refers to the self-reported absence of employees from work due to health issues. It is important to note that the reasons for absenteeism may not always be due to genuine health problems. 
 

Other options:

  • Health of the family: Measured by indicators like IMR, MMR, child morbidity.

  • Industrial environment: Assessed by occupational hazard surveys, not absenteeism.

  • Community health: Assessed by mortality, morbidity, life expectancy, etc.

questions.text: Confidentiality is maintained in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Confidentiality is always upheld during counseling sessions.

It is defined as the condition of maintaining privacy, which involves protecting patients' personal and sensitive information from unauthorized access. This principle is inherently understood in the doctor-patient relationship, where the physician is obligated to keep all information learned about the patient during their professional duties confidential.

The importance of confidentiality lies in its role in encouraging patients to share complete and honest information during consultations, particularly regarding intimate details. If patients feel their privacy is not safeguarded, they may withhold vital information, potentially leading to an incomplete or inaccurate clinical history. The attending physician carries a significant responsibility in this aspect, as the trust placed in them by the patient facilitates more effective communication and counseling.

For instance, when counseling individuals with HIV/AIDS, a confidential dialogue allows patients to discuss their risks of infection, manage associated stress, and make informed personal decisions regarding their health.

It's worth noting that group discussions, panel discussions, and seminars are collective approaches to health education and typically do not raise concerns regarding confidentiality.

questions.text: Eligible couple registers are maintained at which of the following centres?
questions.solution:
Eligible couple registers are maintained by Female Health Workers (FHW) at sub-centers.

A sub-center serves as a crucial link to the community at the grassroots level, offering a range of primary health care services. They can be categorized into two types:
  • Type A: Lacks facilities for conducting deliveries.
  • Type B (MCH sub-center): Equipped with facilities for conducting deliveries.
For effective service delivery at the sub-center level, 1 FHW is required in Type A, while 2 FHWs and 1 Male Health Worker (MHW) are necessary in Type B.

questions.text: The heart of the activated sludge process is:
questions.solution:
The activated sludge process is a part of the secondary sewage treatment and the heart of this process is the aeration tanks.
Steps in Modern sewage treatment
Primary treatment
(1)screening.
(2)Grit chamber.
(3)primary sedimentation.
Secondary treatment.
(1)Trickling filter method.
(2) Activated sludge process.
(3) Secondary sedimentation.
(4) Sludge digestion.
(5) disposal of effluent .

Ref - Parks textbook of PSM 25th edition page 824

questions.text: The insecticide in the given image is used to eliminate the larval form of which of the following species?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Paris green which is a commonly used larvicide agent against surface feeders like anopheles larvae.

questions.text: Skeletal fluorosis occurs at what level of fluoride intake?

questions.text: Which of the following terms refers to instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought?
questions.solution:
When information is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine it is called health propaganda. It is the act of instilling a particular point of view in people's minds and inhibiting their independent thought.
Health awareness aims at promoting positive health behaviors and reducing the burden of disease through education and preventive measures. Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention and is the process of enabling people to increase control over and improve health. This can be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions, or lifestyle changes.

Ref: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition • Page No: 922

upper zone as it is heat sensitive
upper zone as it is freeze sensitive
lower zone as it is freeze sensitive

questions.text: Hepatitis B vaccine is stored in which part of an ice lined refrigerator ?
questions.solution:
Ice lined refrigerators are the main method of vaccine storage in public health care centres. ILRs require a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines. ILRs have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone in the ILR is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera vaccine, hepatitis B vaccine, and rotavirus vaccine (liquid), while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV and measles vaccine.
Ref- Parks textbook of PSM 27th edition page 118-119

choices.text: Recording and analyzing blood pressure levels over an extended period to identify patterns and predict future readings
Observing changes in blood pressure throughout a 24-hour period
Comparing blood pressure values between different populations
Assessing blood pressure during exercise to evaluate cardiovascular

questions.text: What does the term "tracking" refer to in relation to blood pressure?
questions.solution:
When blood pressure levels are observed from childhood through to adulthood, individuals with higher blood pressure early on typically maintain higher levels, while those with lower levels tend to stay lower as they age.
This consistent ranking of blood pressure over time is called "tracking." This helps identify children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 27th Edition • Page no: 425-428

questions.text: What is the maximum working hours for an industrial worker as per the factory act?
questions.solution:
As per the factory act of 1948 maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week.
Factories act, 1948 defines -
(1)defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used.
(2)Age of employment should be >14 years of age.
(3)Adolescents between 15-18 years can be employed -
  • only in certain industries and work between 6 AM - 7 PM.
  • should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
  • entitled for leave once in 15 days and can accumulate leave upto 40 days.
(4) Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week.
(4) Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 - min 500cuft / person.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition • Pg no 876

questions.text: Urinary catheter bags are disposed in which of the following containers?
questions.solution:
Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves. The waste is managed by Autoclaving/Microwaving/Hydroclaving followed by Shredding/mutilation.

Ref- Park textbook of PSM 25th edition Page 853

questions.text: Lifestyle modification to prevent coronary artery disease is indicative of which level of prevention
questions.solution:
Lifestyle modification belongs to primordial prevention strategy as prevents the emergence or development of risk factors.
Levels of Prevention
1. Primordial prevention:
• Involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.
Example - lifestyle modification
2. Primary prevention:
• These are defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur"
• It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of the disease
3. Secondary prevention:
• This is defined as "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.".
• The specific interventions are early diagnoses like screening tests adequate treatment
4. Tertiary treatment includes methods to reduce level of disability.

Ref - Park Textbook of PSM 25th edition page 48

questions.text: All of the following modalities are mass approaches for communication, except
questions.solution:
Roleplay is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it. It is a participatory method of learning and communication where individuals act out scenarios to simulate real-life situations. Role play is a group approach of communication. 

Ref- Park's Textbook of PSM 25th edition Page 926

questions.text: If morbidity of a disease increases, Which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution:
Morbidity refers to any deviation, whether subjective or objective, from a state of physical well-being. It encompasses conditions such as sickness, illness, and disability. Morbidity is typically measured by morbidity rates or ratios, which include frequency, duration, severity and duration of hospital stay.

Ref- Parks textbook of PSM 25th edition Page 26

questions.text: A woman arrived at the hospital wth liver failure after consuming peanuts bought from a nearby vendor.On investigating it was found that there was improper storage of peanuts at the vendors stall. Which of the following contaminants is most likely the cause for the given condition ?
questions.solution:
Aflatoxins are produced by certain fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, are the most potent hepatotoxins.
These fungi can contaminate food grains such as groundnut, maize, parboiled rice, sorghum, wheat, and tapioca. It is mainly due to improper storage. It can be prevented by proper storage after drying. Moisture content should be kept below 10%.

Sanguinarine causes Epidemic Dropsy.
• Contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil.
• Toxic compound: Sanguinarine. Sanguinarine interfers with the oxidation of pyruvic acid which in turn accumulates in the blood and causes symptoms.

questions.text: What is the most common cancer among women in India?
questions.solution:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in India. It is also the most common cause of cancer among women throughout the world. Lip and oral cavity is the most common cause of cancer among men in India.
