questions.text: Name the international agency that aids India in the construction of sanitary latrines.
questions.solution:
The Ford Foundation is actively engaged in improving family planning and rural health care through a number of initiatives, as well as designing and building sanitary latrines in rural regions. They have made the following efforts:
  • establishing orientation centers for the purpose of training paramedics and doctors
  • carrying forth initiatives to deal with fundamental environmental sanitation problems
  • Creating initiatives for rural health services
  • The National Institute of Health Administration and Education was founded.
  • initiating programs to address Calcutta's water problems
  • providing fellowship programs for family planning

Additionally, a number of additional organizations support related objectives:
  • Grants and loans are provided by USAID (United States Agency for International Development) to help India's health system develop.
  • In partnership with the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) program, CARE (Cooperative for aid and Relief Everywhere) focuses on providing food aid for children.
  • The Red Cross
Reference
Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 26th Edition - Page 1018, 1019

questions.text: A middle-aged man working in sandblasting developed hemoptysis, and a productive cough. Chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is the pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of free crystalline silica dust, commonly seen in occupations such as sandblasting, mining, stone cutting, and quarry work.

Why Silicosis?

  • Sandblasting → high exposure to silica particles

  • Leads to fibrosis of the lung parenchyma

  • Increases the risk of pulmonary tuberculosis (called silicotuberculosis), due to impaired macrophage function

  • Pathogenesis:

    • Silica particles → phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages → release of inflammatory cytokines

    • Leads to fibrosis and nodule formation in lungs

  • Clinical features:

    • Chronic dry cough

    • Exertional dyspnea

    • Fatigue

    • May progress to respiratory failure

  • Radiological features:

    • Upper lobe nodules

    • Eggshell calcification of hilar lymph nodes (classic but uncommon)

    • HRCT: better sensitivity than X-ray

  • Treatment: Remove from exposure

    • Symptomatic treatment (bronchodilators, steroids in some cases)

    • Oxygen therapy if needed

    • Monitor for TB and other complications

  • Other Options:

  • 1. Asbestosis

    • Linked to shipbuilding, insulation, construction

    • Associated with mesothelioma and bronchogenic carcinoma, not TB

  • 2. Siderosis

    • Caused by iron dust (e.g., welding)

    • Usually benign, not associated with fibrosis or TB

  • 4. Anthracosis

    • Inhalation of carbon particles (e.g., coal dust)

    • Common in coal workers; rarely leads to TB

    • Severe form: Coal workers' pneumoconiosis, but TB link is weaker than in silicosis

questions.text: To avoid overcrowding, what is the maximum number of people allowed to live in a house with 2 rooms?
questions.solution:
These standards are part of housing and urban health guidelines in India (also referenced in Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine).

Number of Rooms Permissible Occupants (Without Overcrowding)
1 room 2 persons
2 rooms 3 persons
3 rooms 5 persons
4 rooms 7 persons
≥5 rooms 10 persons

This standard is specifically for urban housing regulation and slum clearance planning, used by municipalities.
 

  • This is not the same as the standard used in the Health Room Area Standard (e.g., 110 sq. ft. per person), which is a different criterion.

  • Children <1 year of age are not counted; children 1–10 years count as ½ person.



Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 24th edition page no 789

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping (also known as sanitary landfilling) is a method of solid waste disposal where refuse is systematically deposited in trenches or pits, compacted, and covered with earth. This prevents nuisance from flies, rodents, and smell, and reduces environmental contamination.

There are 3 main types of controlled tipping:

  1. Trench method – best for level ground with low water table

  2. Ramp method – used where land has a natural depression

  3. Area method – used when landfilling over existing ground surface

    Trench Method – Key Features

  • Trenches of suitable dimensions (usually ~2 m deep and 4–10 m wide) are dug.

  • Garbage is deposited daily and compacted.

  • At the end of the day, a layer of earth (15–30 cm) is used to cover the refuse (this prevents pests and odor).

  • The trench is filled over time and then covered permanently with soil.

  • The decomposition is anaerobic.

    Land Requirement – Based on Standard Estimates

The typical land requirement for the trench method is:

Population Duration Land Required
10,000 1 year  1 acre
10,000 5 years ≈ 5 acres

Thus, for a population of 10,000, for a single year, the required land area for controlled tipping by the trench method is: 1 acre


Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 814

questions.text: A patient presents to an ESI hospital for treatment. Under the ESI Act, he/she is treated under which benefit ?
questions.solution:
Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act, when a patient (insured person) presents to an ESI hospital for treatment, it falls under the category of Medical Benefit.

Key Points:

  • Medical Benefit:

    • Covers medical treatment and care provided to insured persons and their families.

    • Includes outpatient, inpatient, and specialist care in ESI dispensaries/hospitals.

  • Sickness Benefit:

    • Cash compensation for loss of wages due to certified illness lasting more than 3 days.

  • Maternity Benefit:

    • For insured women during confinement, miscarriage, or related conditions.

  • Dependant’s Benefit:

    • Paid to dependants of an insured person who dies due to an employment injury.


Reference:Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 877

questions.text: Lung malignancy is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis and Associated Diseases
Asbestosis is primarily linked to asbestos exposure and is associated with various asbestos-related diseases, including:

- Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
- Pleural effusion
- Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
- Lung carcinoma
- Mesotheliomas
- Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

 Asbestosis 
-Definition: Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis resulting from asbestos exposure, typically occurring after 5-10 years of exposure. Once developed, it can progress even after removal from exposure.
- Pathophysiology: It primarily affects the lower lobes of the lungs, causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
- Asbestos Types:
- Serpentine (Chrysotile)
- Amphibole Types:
- Crocidolite (blue)
- Amosite (brown)
- Anthophyllite (white)

 Clinical Presentation
- Symptoms: Cough and exertional dyspnea.
- Sputum Analysis: Shows asbestos bodies (asbestos fibers coated with fibrin).
- Pulmonary Function Testing: Typically reveals a restrictive pattern, with decreased lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

Imaging Findings
-X-ray: Shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower lung zones.
- HRCT: Reveals subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement typically occurs after at least 10 years of exposure.

Complications
-Pulmonary fibrosis
- Lung carcinoma
- Gastrointestinal tract malignancies
- Pleural mesothelioma

 Preventive Measures
- Use of Safer Asbestos Types: Prefer chrysotile and amosite.
- Substitution with Safer Materials: Use alternatives like glass fiber, mineral wool, calcium silicate, and plastic foams.
- Dust Control Measures
- Periodic Health Examinations for Workers
- Ongoing Research into safer practices and materials.

These measures aim to mitigate the risks associated with asbestos exposure and protect worker health.
Reference: Park's textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 868

questions.text: In which color-coded bin are blood bags disposed of after a transfusion?
questions.solution:
Following blood transfusion, blood bags are disposed in yellow colour coded bin.

Incineration is the preferred technique for disposing of yellow bags, and since blood bags are not composed of PVC, they may burn safely without releasing dangerous gasses into the environment.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 919.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding screw feed technology is false?
questions.solution:
Screw-Feed Technology is suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps. But it should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic, or radioactive waste.

Screw-Feed Technology:
• A non-burn, dry thermal disinfection process that reduces waste by 80% in volume and 20-35% in weight
• Suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps
• Should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic, or radioactive waste.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text: Which strategy is used to dispose of cytotoxic and outdated medications?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Landfill.
  • Cytotoxic medications and outdated drugs are considered hazardous pharmaceutical waste.
  • The preferred method for disposing of such waste is through landfill disposal in specifically designated hazardous waste disposal sites.
  • Proper disposal of pharmaceutical waste is crucial to prevent environmental contamination and potential harm to human health.
  • Dumping is not an acceptable method of disposing of hazardous waste.
  • Autoclaving and burning are effective methods of destroying cytotoxic and outdated medications, but they are not practical for large quantities of waste.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text:
A RTA case is admitted, and blood spills onto the hospital floor.
Which disinfectant will you use to the floor to clean it?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite is used in blood spill management.
Saturate the spilled area with sodium hypochlorite 0.5% (10 000 ppm available chlorine). This is a 1:10 dilution of 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach, which should be prepared daily.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which bag is used to dispose of the pacemaker?
questions.solution:
Pacemaker is disposed in blue bag.

  • Metallic body implants: body implants, plates, screws, wires

questions.text: How are anatomical wastes disposed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Incineration.
 
  • In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. 
  • This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. 
  • It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 916.

questions.text: What is a sterilising technique called incineration used for?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Human anatomical waste.
 
  • In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. 
  • This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. 
  • It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 916.

questions.text: What is the best way to dispose broken glass injection vitals?

A broken vaccine vial is disposed of in a puncture-proof blue bin, according to biomedical waste management.

questions.text: According to the latest biomedical waste management guidelines, used syringes with fixed needles of pentavalent vaccines are discarded into which bins?
questions.solution:
According to the latest guidelines, waste sharps, including used and discarded needles as well as contaminated metal sharps, should be disposed of in the white bin.

The current colour-coded bin system is as follows:

Yellow: Anatomical waste, masks, etc.
Red: Recyclable contaminated waste.
White: Waste sharps, including metal sharps.
Blue: Glassware and metallic body implants.

questions.text: Identify the correct combination regarding the disposal of expired drugs
questions.solution:
According to the Biomedical Waste Management Rules (2016, amended 2018):

  • Yellow bag → Used for pharmaceutical waste, including expired or discarded medicines.

    • Method of disposal: Incineration or plasma pyrolysis.

  • Red bag → For contaminated recyclable waste (like IV sets, catheters, tubing).

    • Method of disposal: Autoclaving / Hydroclaving, followed by shredding and recycling.

Hence, expired drugs → Yellow bag → Incineration.



Reference
Park Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine - 24th Edition - Page no: 830

questions.text: According to the biomedical waste disposal guidelines, the used cotton swabs should be disposed of in the __ colored bag.
questions.solution:
According to the Biomedical Waste Management Rules (2016, revised 2018 and 2019) by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Government of India, biomedical waste is segregated using a color-coded system.

Yellow Bag – Used for:

Includes infectious, soiled, and anatomical waste:

  • Human and animal anatomical waste

  • Soiled waste (items contaminated with blood, body fluids) like:

    • Used cotton swabs

    • Bandages, gauze

    • Plasters

    • Disposable items contaminated with body fluids

  • Expired or discarded medicines

  • Chemical waste (in some cases)

Treatment: Incineration or deep burial

Red Bag:

  • Used for infected recyclable waste such as:

    • IV tubing, catheters

    • Gloves, syringes (without needles)

    • Plastic items

Treatment: Autoclaving, microwaving, or hydroclaving followed by shredding and recycling.

Blue Bag:

  • Glassware and metallic body implants

    • Broken glass

    • Vials, ampoules

      Transparent (White puncture-proof container):

  • Sharps: Needles, scalpels, blades

     

    Color Code Type of Waste Examples Disposal Method
    üü° Yellow Soiled, Infectious & Anatomical Waste Used cotton swabs, dressings, body parts, blood-soaked items, expired drugs Incineration or deep burial
    üî¥ Red Contaminated Recyclables (Infectious plastics) IV sets, catheters, gloves, syringes without needles Autoclave/microwave/hydroclave, then shred
    üîµ Blue Glassware, metallic body implants Broken glass, ampoules, medicine vials Disinfection, then recycling
    ‚ö™ White (Translucent, puncture-proof) Sharps (used/discarded with potential for cuts/puncture) Needles, scalpels, blades Autoclaving/dry heat, then encapsulation/shredding


Reference:Parks textbook of preventive and social medicine 25th edition page no 853
